site_title: Chinese investors on global real estate buying spree
summary: Chinese investors increased their global real estate buying by 17% in the first half of 2014, with residential investments rising 84%. The majority of the investments, totaling US$5.4 billion, were made in commercial properties, particularly in core office and mixed-use development projects in global gateway cities. London, San Francisco, and Chicago were the top destinations, with Spain also attracting investors due to its Golden Visa program. This surge in overseas investments reflects Chinese investors' pursuit of opportunities outside their home market, driven by tight financing and high inventories.

site_title: Obsession with short term getting out of hand
summary: The increasing popularity of short-term investments, such as weekly options, is raising concerns about the growing obsession with short-term gains. This trend is evident in the growing demand for instruments with limited lifespans, like weekly options, which can be traded in just seven days. As a result, investors are prioritizing quick profits over long-term value, potentially leading to decreased market efficiency and reduced investment returns. This phenomenon is seen as a retrograde outcome in the investment arena, where retail investors are opting out due to the complexity and speed required to succeed in such a market.

site_title: SIAS raises issue over Top Global's acquisition
summary: Concerns have been raised by the Securities Investors Association Singapore (SIAS) over Top Global Ltd's acquisition of a 71.52% stake in PT Suryamas Dutamakmur Tbk, an Indonesia-based property developer, for SGD 153 million. The deal includes an allotment of 19 billion new shares and 5 billion options to Sukmawati Widjaja, the majority shareholder, with no change in the purchase consideration. SIAS president David Gerald has criticized the inevitable equity dilution suffered by minority shareholders, prompting a meeting with Top Global's board on August 8 to discuss the issues.

site_title: Ah, the taste of Chablis and Pouilly-Fuisse
summary: NK YONG compares Chablis and Pouilly-Fuisse, two budget white burgundies. Chablis, a northernmost Burgundy appellation, is considered a good value-for-money, but often overlooked. In contrast, Pouilly-Fuisse, located in the Maconnais district, is softer and richer, with better drinkability even when young. The author praises Chateau de Fuisse, a top producer in Pouilly-Fuisse, and notes that their wines are available at affordable prices. Both Chablis and Pouilly-Fuisse have aging potential, but Chablis requires longer storage, typically 15 or more years.

site_title: Mayoral mansion dresses down for new occupant
summary: New York Mayor Bill de Blasio's family has renovated Gracie Mansion with a more casual, midcentury-style decor, courtesy of West Elm. The $65,000 worth of furniture, donated by the home furnishings company, replaces the mansion's ornate and formal interior. The redesign, overseen by de Blasio's wife Chirlane McCray, features plain sofas, striped accent beanbags, and Capiz orb pewter pendant lights. The change aims to reflect the family's simpler, fresher vibe, a stark contrast to the mansion's previous baroque look.

site_title: Karting track to be built inside Turf Club
summary: A S$2 million karting facility, the KF1 Karting Circuit, will be built on the grounds of the Singapore Turf Club by Arina International Holding. Funded by renowned F1 track designer Hermann Tilke, the 960m-long track will be Singapore's first permanent CIK-certified facility, allowing for international races. The facility will include team garages, a viewing gallery, and a members lounge, and will be lit by the same type of lights as the F1 street circuit. The track is expected to be ready by the time the Singapore Grand Prix is held next month.

site_title: Quotation of taxable book-entry Singapore Government Bonds (July 31, 2014)
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed, while US stocks opened lower due to a fresh tariff salvo from Trump on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall in H2 and operating loss similar to H1. Meanwhile, Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case, and London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10b upgrade. Singapore stocks rallied for the fifth consecutive day ahead of GDP data, with OCBC's incoming CEO Tan Teck Long set to take the reins. MAS and PBOC will deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: OUE Commercial Reit's Q2 DPU beats forecast
summary: OUE Commercial Reit reported a 5.1% increase in its distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.43 Singapore cents for its Q2, beating forecasts. Net property income rose 4.6% to S$14.3 million, driven by lower property expenses. The Reit's portfolio, comprising two office buildings, saw positive rental reversions, with average passing rents increasing 6.1% and 4.3% at its properties. Units rose to 83 Singapore cents, their highest since listing, driven by bullish forecasts for Singapore's office property sector and herd instinct among investors.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: Malaysia Airlines is expected to submit a private revival plan to Prime Minister Najib Razak, amid intense pressure. Singapore's life insurers will be required to sell protection up to S$400,000 under a government-mandated scheme. The National Research Foundation in Singapore will invest S$100 million in energy R&D. Researchers are close to finding a dengue antiviral drug. Singapore Airlines saw a 71.4% drop in Q1 net profit due to lower revenue and associates' losses. Reforms in Tianjin are expected to bring new opportunities for Singapore companies.

site_title: Accordia Golf Trust starts trading today
summary: Accordia Golf Trust, a business trust with golf courses in Japan, starts trading on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) after a public offering of approximately 41 million units in Singapore at S$0.97 each. The offering was 0.7 times subscribed, with 70% of units offered to Japanese investors. The trust aims to diversify the SGX's business and real estate trust offerings, despite a lacklustre demand from local investors due to unfamiliarity with the brand. The trust offers an annual distribution yield of up to 9.1% for the forecast year 2015.

site_title: Classic Indian poetry inspires two new plays
summary: Singaporean playwright Haresh Sharma is producing two new plays, "Gitanjali" and "Cloud Messenger", inspired by Indian poetry by Tagore and Kalidasa. "Gitanjali" combines dance, drama, and traditional singing to tell a story of tradition versus modernity, while "Cloud Messenger" is a multi-narrative play about a nature spirit's quest to reunite with his wife. The productions, by The Necessary Stage, mark Sharma's attempt to explore Indian culture and identity in his work.

site_title: OUE Hospitality Q2 DPS beats forecast
summary: OUE Hospitality Trust announced a 2.5% increase in its second-quarter distribution per stapled security (DPS) to 1.64 Singapore cents, beating forecasts. The Reit's net property income rose 1.2% to S$25.2 million, while gross revenue was marginally below forecast at S$28.3 million. Mandarin Orchard's RevPAR fell short of forecast, but its food and beverage segment performed better than expected. The Reit also reported stable income from Mandarin Gallery and plans to acquire more prime-location assets. Its units finished trading higher at S$0.905.

site_title: KKR's Goodpack acquisition terms 'fair'
summary: KKR's proposed acquisition of Goodpack is deemed "fair and reasonable" by independent financial adviser Provenance Capital. The acquisition terms offer S$2.50 per share, a 23.3% premium, valuing the company at S$1.4 billion. Goodpack's independent directors have recommended shareholders vote in favor of the scheme, and a majority of shareholders must approve the deal for it to succeed. The acquisition will see shares transferred to IBC Capital Limited, a company affiliated with KKR. A meeting is scheduled for August 14 to give shareholders their approval.

site_title: All Kaye up close and personal
summary: Singer Mina Kaye is set to debut her new one-woman cabaret-style show, "The Mina Kaye Show," in Singapore, featuring a mix of show tunes and diva impersonations. The intimate performance will be a farewell concert as she prepares to leave for the Boston Conservatory's Master of Fine Arts in Musical Theatre program, where she aims to raise S$200,000. The show, which includes surprise guest performers and a range of musical genres, will be held at TAB Bar and Restaurant on August 1, with tickets available through Kaye's crowdfunding site.

site_title: Tiger Airways sees brighter skies ahead
summary: Tiger Airways CEO Lee Lik Hsin believes the worst is over for the airline after divesting loss-making units. The carrier has recorded an operating loss of S$19.8 million in the first quarter, but aims to improve yields and load factor. Tiger has sold stakes in Tigerair Philippines and Australia, and grounded eight planes to address overcapacity. The airline plans to deepen strategic alliances, restructure its network, and implement cost-saving initiatives to turn itself around.

site_title: SGX's Q4 profit falls 12% on weak securities markets
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) reported a 12% decline in Q4 net profit to S$77.42 million, and a 15% drop in revenue to S$172.6 million, due to weak securities markets and low volatility. The company's securities revenue fell 32% to S$53 million, while its derivatives business saw a 3% increase in revenue to S$208.7 million. Despite a tough year, SGX CEO Magnus Bocker remains confident in the market's recovery and expects investors to return.

site_title: Labour market still tight in Q2, layoffs down
summary: Singapore's labour market remained tight in Q2, with an unemployment rate of 2% in June, unchanged from the previous quarter. Job creation fell 22% to 22,000, the lowest since the first quarter. Manufacturing jobs declined by 2,600, the largest quarterly drop since 2009. Redundancies also decreased, with 2,300 workers released, down from 3,110 in the previous quarter. Experts attribute the slowdown to economic slowdown and the impact of sunset industries on job creation.

site_title: Industrial land being released by JTC won't affect us: Aims AMP trust
summary: Aims AMP Capital Industrial Reit remains unaffected by JTC Corporation's release of industrial land, as the Reit focuses on medium to large enterprises and multinational corporations. The Reit's distribution per unit increased 2% to 2.55 Singapore cents, with gross revenue rising 11.6% and net property income up 23.9%. The Reit has also made a 49% stake in Optus Centre in Sydney, which contributed to its improved revenue and income. CEO Koh Wee Lih stated that the Reit does not compete with JTC in certain segments and that the government's land allocation is pre-committed, limiting the impact of JTC's land release.

site_title: Air India staff nabbed for smuggling gold
summary: Indian authorities have found 13 cases of gold smuggling by Air India employees over the past three years, with an estimated 200-250 tonnes of gold entering the country illegally. The smuggling is believed to be done by hiding gold in imported vehicles and using human mules. Disciplinary action has been taken against the employees, but no amount of gold smuggled was disclosed. The Indian government's efforts to curb gold smuggling come after imposing a 10% import duty and making it mandatory to export a fifth of all bullion imports to reduce the trade deficit.

site_title: Ezion shares up as group delivers strong Q2 results
summary: Ezion Holdings' stock rose 2% to S$2.15 after posting strong Q2 results, with net profit increasing 3.58 US cents a share to US$45.4 million and revenue rising 37.8% to US$92.6 million. The company expects to deliver robust H2 results, driven by the deployment of more service rigs and increased chartering revenue. Analysts also anticipate strong H2 results, citing the growing focus on platform and well-related work by oil majors.

site_title: Australian digital ad firm invests in iProperty
summary: REA Group, an Australian digital advertising firm, has invested in iProperty Group, becoming its second-largest shareholder. REA Group acquired French property portal SeLoger.com's 17.2% stake, valued at A$106 million. This deal values iProperty at A$616 million. REA Group sees the acquisition as a strategic foothold in Asia, complementing its existing online real estate businesses in Hong Kong and China. iProperty serves over four million consumers monthly and partners 30,000 agents and 400 developers.

site_title: Reflections on life, death and solitude
summary: Artist Michael Lee's solo exhibition "Machine for (Living) Dying In" explores the concept of home and solitude through a video featuring 45 places where people have died alone. The exhibition includes collages, sculptures, and installations that challenge traditional notions of home and comfort. Lee's work is inspired by the death of a former army mate and the idea that home is not just a physical space, but also a metaphor for human existence. The exhibition runs from August 16 to September 21 at Yavuz Fine Art in Singapore.

site_title: Sentiment for services, manufacturing diverges
summary: Singapore's services sector has become more optimistic about the second half of 2014, with 21% of firms expecting business to pick up, up from 15% in April. In contrast, manufacturing firms have become less optimistic, with a net weighted balance of 6% positive about the next six months, down from 7% a quarter ago. The global economic recovery is driving the positive outlook for some sectors, such as banks and precision engineering firms, while others, like real estate and restaurants, are still gloomy due to domestic constraints.

site_title: Aussie project go-ahead a revenue boost for Linc
summary: The Australian government approved the development of the Carmichael coal mine in Queensland, generating A$133 million (S$154.1 million) in annual revenue for Linc Energy, which owns royalty over the coal. The value of the royalty contract will also increase. The mine, expected to produce 60 million tonnes of thermal coal a year, will contribute A$3 billion to the Queensland economy and generate thousands of jobs. Environmentalists oppose the project, citing threats to the Great Barrier Reef.

site_title: Sanctions will hit Russia hard, but Europe also under strain
summary: The European Union has imposed sanctions on Russia, restricting its access to European capital markets, banning broking services, and imposing an embargo on the arms trade. The measures are expected to hit the Russian economy hard, potentially sending it into recession, which could impact European nations such as Germany. Analysts fear the sanctions could worsen the economic situation, with some speculating Russia may turn to China for finance or cut oil-and-gas sales to Europe. The sanctions are set to be reviewed in three months, and business leaders warn of a "painful" cost to European business and German exporters.

site_title: Passionate about porcelain
summary: A new exhibition at the Asian Civilisations Museum in Singapore explores the history of porcelain, dating back to the 9th century in China. Over 180 pieces from around the world, including original Chinese pieces and imitations, will be on display until December. The exhibition highlights the cultural interactions and influences that shaped the global trade of porcelain, which was a highly prized and lucrative commodity for centuries. The show aims to demonstrate the dynamics of trade and how economic exchanges influenced cultures, with examples including European copies of Chinese porcelain and the adaptation of porcelain designs for local markets.

site_title: Biggest amount of Gulf refineries' fuels Asia-bound this year
summary: Persian Gulf oil refineries are set to ship the largest amount of fuels to Asia in eight months, with 3.91 million tonnes of refined petroleum scheduled for the four weeks to Aug 10. Middle East nations, led by Saudi Arabia, are increasing their refining capacity, adding 815,000 barrels a day by the end of the year. This surge in fuel production is driven by rising demand in Asia, as Russia increases fuel shipments to Europe and the US reduces its dependence on foreign energy.

site_title: Zhong Jun says it's able to repay banks
summary: Zhong Jun Resources, a Chinese firm linked to a metal financing fraud probe, has asked a Singapore court to reject a liquidation order sought by HSBC, citing sufficient cash and assets to repay banks. The company has US$86.4 million of goods at bonded warehouses and US$18.4 million in properties in Singapore. Despite a complex shareholding structure linking it to a suspect, Zhong Jun claims to be a profitable business with a 2013 gross profit of US$13.4 million. The company has asked the court to stop HSBC from taking further action for six months while it restructures and sells assets.

site_title: Mind the GAAP with tech firms
summary: Twitter's second-quarter results sparked debate over its net loss of US$145 million versus its non-GAAP net income of US$14.6 million. The tech firm's share price soared 29% after hours. Non-GAAP metrics, excluding large stock-based compensation expenses, are common in tech firms and often preferred by investors due to the unknowns of the industry. Twitter's monthly active users (MAUs) grew 24% to 271 million, and its ad revenue per 1,000 timeline views rose 100% for the second quarter. The use of unconventional metrics like MAUs and ad revenue per 1,000 timeline views may eventually gain legitimacy.

site_title: UOB's Q2 profit beats forecast
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) posted a Q2 net profit of S$808 million, beating forecast by 2.5%. Higher net interest income and investment gains drove the increase, with annualized earnings per share reaching S$1.97. Customer loans rose 11.7% year-over-year, and the bank declared an unchanged interim dividend of 20 Singapore cents. UOB chief executive Wee Ee Cheong attributed the results to a more stable global economy, with the US economy recovering from quantitative easing tapering concerns.

site_title: OSIM Q2 profit rises 13% to S$29.5m
summary: OSIM International reported a 13% year-on-year increase in Q2 net profit to S$29.53 million, driven by higher consumer demand for its products and nutritional supplements. Revenue rose 10% to S$182.66 million, with TWG Tea contributing significantly to sales. The company expects its business to remain strong for the rest of the year, with plans to open new outlets and grow sales through new products. A second interim dividend of two Singapore cents per share was proposed.

site_title: Looking at history through a contemporary lens
summary: Malaysian artist Yee I-Lann's solo exhibition at Silverlens Gallery features her works from 2007 to 2013, showcasing her use of archival images to construct narratives about culture and power. The exhibition includes photomontages, ceramic dinner plates, and photographs that explore identity politics, colonialism, and neo-colonialism. Yee's works, including "Tabled" and "Picturing Power," have been exhibited internationally but are being shown in Southeast Asia for the first time. The exhibition runs until September 2, with an opening reception and artist's talk scheduled.

site_title: A waste of everybody's star wattage
summary: Rob Reiner's romantic comedy "And So It Goes" underperforms despite enjoyable performances from Michael Douglas and Diane Keaton. The film follows a grumpy old man who helps his neighbor care for her newborn and finds love in the process. However, the script is dated and lacks humor, making the film feel predictable and underwhelming. Reiner's direction is heartwarming, but the movie fails to live up to its potential, making it a waste of its star wattage.

site_title: SIA Q1 profit hit by lower revenue, associates' losses
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) reported a 71.4% drop in net profit to S$34.8 million for the first quarter ended June 30, 2014, due to lower revenue and associate companies' losses. Revenue declined 4.1% year-over-year, primarily driven by weaker yields and softer travel demand from key Asian markets. Operating profit slumped nearly 52% to S$39.5 million, while fuel costs decreased. SIA attributed the challenges to the uncertain global economic climate, geo-political concerns, and elevated fuel prices.

images.alt_text: SINGAPORE Airlines (SIA) chalked up a 71.4 per cent drop in net profit to S$34.8 million for the first quarter ended 30 June, 2014, as revenue declined and share of losses of associated companies soared - PHOTO: REUTERS

site_title: Premiums of insurance bought directly expected to fall 5-10%
summary: Insurance premiums bought directly are expected to fall 5-10% in Singapore, as consumers may opt for cheaper products. This comes after a government-mandated direct-purchase scheme will require insurers to sell protection up to S$400,000 from next year. CEO Khoo Kah Siang of Great Eastern Life Assurance expects this change to reduce premiums, but emphasizes the importance of financial advisers providing value-added services to ensure consumers choose the right products. The direct-purchase scheme aims to balance between convenience and affordability.

site_title: Crowdfunding goes specialist
summary: Crowdfunding has evolved into niche platforms catering to specific industries, offering customized services. Platforms like Haystakt, Publishizer, and StartMyGig provide value-added solutions for designers, authors, and concert organizers, respectively. These platforms aim to provide tailored services to meet the unique needs of their respective niches, potentially reducing the risk of oversaturation as they target specific audiences.

site_title: Irreverent humour saves the plot
summary: The article discusses the movie Guardians of the Galaxy, the 10th installment in the Marvel Cinematic Universe, which has received praise for its entertaining and irreverent take on the superhero genre. Director James Gunn brings a low-budget, B-movie vibe to the film, incorporating a retro-cool soundtrack and a cast of lovable misfits, including Chris Pratt, Zoe Saldana, and Bradley Cooper. Despite a predictable plot, the movie's zany spirit and humor make it a standout in the Marvel franchise, promising box-office success.

site_title: Favourable market conditions lift Great Eastern's Q2 profit
summary: Great Eastern Holding's second-quarter earnings surged to S$244.6 million, up from S$18.6 million a year ago, driven by significant unrealised mark-to-market gains and a sharp turnaround in its non-participating fund. The insurance unit's profit rose to S$228.8 million, while the non-operating profit increased mainly due to a higher non-participating fund.

site_title: Banks' surge swells July market cap
summary: Singapore's stock market value rose 1.3% in July to S$979 billion, driven by strong gains in shares of three banks: DBS, UOB, and OCBC. DBS made the largest gains, increasing its market cap by 8.8% to S$44.9 billion. UOB and OCBC also saw significant gains, with UOB's market cap rising 7.3% to S$39 billion and OCBC's increasing 4.5% to S$34.9 billion. This follows the announcement of OCBC's takeover of Hong Kong's Wing Hang Bank.

site_title: SMRT's Q1 net jumps 36.8% to S$22.36 million
summary: SMRT Corp's net profit jumped 36.8% to S$22.36 million for the first quarter, driven by growth in ridership and average fare, as well as the rental, advertising, and taxi businesses. Revenue rose 4.3% to S$297.13 million, while total operating expenses increased 3.1% to S$280.61 million. The company expects a challenging fare business environment but expects growth in its non-fare business.

site_title: Hitting the high notes at Singapore Lyric Opera Gala
summary: The Singapore Lyric Opera Gala will feature international opera stars Kishani Jayasinghe and Arthur Espiritu in their Singapore debut. Jayasinghe, a UK-based soprano, has performed at the Royal Opera House and Buckingham Palace, while Espiritu, a Filipino-American tenor, has performed in the US and Europe. The gala, held on August 22 at the Esplanade Concert Hall, will also include performances by local opera singers Anna Koor and William Lim.

site_title: Price drop unlikely to derail longer-term property outlook
summary: Singapore's property market is expected to remain positive despite a potential 10-15% drop in residential prices over the next two years. Analysts believe a pullback in cooling measures is unlikely due to liquidity, with the government keeping the total debt servicing ratio in place. The office sector is also expected to hold up well, with rising wages and occupancy rates. Experts predict that the government may tweak the cooling measures, but no immediate intervention is expected, given the positive economic data and the US Federal Reserve's expected interest rate hike.

site_title: News of tie-up sends CEFC shares up
summary: CEFC International, a petrochemical and fuel oil trader, has partnered with Rizhao Port Group to build and operate oil storage facilities in Rizhao port, China. The joint venture will have an initial registered capital of 350 million yuan and cost approximately 700 million yuan. CEFC will subscribe to a 49% stake in the project for 171.5 million yuan, while Rizhao Port Oil Terminal will contribute the remaining 51% stake in land and cash. The project aims to increase CEFC's trade volume and margins, and may also generate revenue through leasing surplus capacity to third parties.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: United Overseas Bank's non-performing loans surged in Q2 due to deteriorating payments by high-end property buyers. Despite a potential 10-15% drop in residential prices, the long-term outlook remains positive. Local manufacturers' business optimism declined, while services firms turned more upbeat. The Singapore stock market rose 1.3% in July, driven by three banks. China's economy is expected to grow 7.5% this year, but vulnerabilities have risen, and the IMF urges urgent reforms.

site_title: MPA launches Safety@Sea S'pore campaign
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) launched the Safety@Sea Singapore campaign to increase awareness of safe practices and inculcate a safety-first culture at sea. The campaign aims to safeguard against complacency and raise safety standards, following 13 major incidents in 2011, eight in 2012, and six in 2013 in Singapore waters. The MPA will work with the maritime community to improve safety, enhance communication, and recognize companies that display exemplary safety practices. A National Maritime Safety at Sea Council will also be established to spearhead the drive for safety at sea.

images.alt_text: THE Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) yesterday launched the Safety@Sea Singapore campaign to increase awareness of safe practices and inculcate a safety-first culture at sea - PHOTO: NEWS.GOV.SG

site_title: M'sia Airlines touching down for a delisting
summary: Malaysia Airlines (MAS) is expected to be taken private by Khazanah Nasional, the majority owner, in a bid to revive the ailing carrier. The plan, set to be submitted to Prime Minister Najib Razak next week, involves an overhaul of the airline's management, route streamlining, and fleet resizing. MAS will not file for bankruptcy, but a rebranding exercise may be considered later. Khazanah will need to pay RM1.2 billion to buy out remaining shareholders, with a strategic equity partner potentially involved to bolster the airline's standing. A relisting is expected by 2018.

site_title: Publishing made easy with pre-orders
summary: Guy Vincent, 27, co-founded Publishizer, a platform for self-publishing, after realizing the difficulties of publishing a book. The platform allows authors to post a detailed proposal and receive pre-orders, which fund the publishing costs. Publishizer takes 5% of the funds raised, and authors maintain 100% rights and royalties. Since its launch, the platform has raised almost S$150,000 for 20 books, with one successful campaign raising S$28,865. Publishizer provides valuable guidance on self-publishing logistics, including order fulfillment, and plans to expand into the US market.

site_title: Gauging demand for music acts
summary: StartMyGig, a crowdfunding platform, aims to gauge demand for overseas music acts and suitable ticket prices in Singapore. Founded by Adrian Mah and Varian Lim, the platform allows fans to pledge for tickets, and once the campaign meets demand, concert promoters are alerted to bring in the act. StartMyGig takes a small percentage of confirmed ticket sales and measures demand using factors beyond digital sales, such as past performances and audience fatigue. The platform is set to launch with a large music event or festival, aiming to make the concert industry more efficient and provide opportunities for under-served segments of the market.

site_title: Not all A380s on order will be built, says Airbus
summary: Airbus has acknowledged that not all A380s on order will be built, citing financial health concerns from customers. The company has pulled a purchase accord with a Japanese airline, Skymark Airlines, and is monitoring the situation of other airlines with A380 orders, including Virgin Atlantic and Qantas. Airbus chief executive Tom Enders reassured investors that the company can place built planes with another customer and expects to deliver around 30 A380s next year, securing its break-even point on the program.

site_title: Seeking a happy ending
summary: A play titled "Gitanjali" is based on Rabindranath Tagore's poetry collection, set in India. The story revolves around Savitri, the owner of a traditional dance school, who seeks a successor. Her son Ebi wants to leave India, while her pet student Raka plans to move to Canada. In an effort to keep Ebi in India, Savitri puts out an ad for an arranged marriage. A young Indian woman named Sharda responds and travels to India for the marriage. The play explores the clash between tradition and personal desires, as the characters strive for a happy ending.

site_title: Roxy-Pacific reports 17% jump in Q2 earnings
summary: Roxy-Pacific Holdings reported a 17% year-on-year increase in Q2 earnings to S$22.70 million, driven by a 49% surge in revenue from its property development segment. Revenue from its property development segment rose 59% to S$102.64 million, largely due to recognition of higher revenue from new projects. The group's hotel ownership and property investment segment accounted for 11% of revenue, with average occupancy rates and room rates dipping slightly. Roxy has declared a 0.616 Singapore cent per share interim dividend and is set to acquire a land and hotel building in Kyoto City, Japan, for S$27.4 million.

site_title: Dengue cure: S'pore researchers move to next phase
summary: Researchers from SingHealth and Duke-NUS have completed a study on Celgosivir, a potential antiviral drug for dengue, after a 2012-2013 clinical trial involving 50 patients. The study found the medicine was well-tolerated, and the researchers are now moving to the next phase with US firm 60° Pharmaceuticals. The new study will explore increased dosages and combination treatments, with plans to recruit 50-100 patients in 2015. The deal, valued at S$1.6 million, also includes exclusive licensing of use patents and clinical trial data, with 60° Pharmaceuticals agreeing not to charge developing countries royalties.

site_title: Asia travel boom fuels airport-building growth
summary: Asia is experiencing a travel boom, fueling the growth of airports in the region. With the middle class expanding, airlines are setting up budget carriers and flying new routes, but many airports are struggling to cope, leading to plans for hundreds of new airports and upgrades to existing ones. The Asia-Pacific region saw a 6.0% annual growth in international tourist arrivals to 248 million last year, prompting governments to invest billions in airport infrastructure. The construction of new airports and upgrades is expected to cost over $100 billion in the next 10 years.

images.alt_text: Making way: Plans are underway for a full replacement of the Ninoy Aquino International in Manila, which is notorious for overcrowding and backward facilities. - PHOTO: BLOOMBERG

site_title: Skymark's wings clipped as Airbus deal turns sour
summary: Skymark Airlines Inc faces a crisis after Airbus cancelled its order for six A380 jets, citing a weaker yen and competition. Skymark had paid 26.5 billion yen in deposits, risking potential losses. Analysts predict damages could balloon, with penalties as high as 70 billion yen. Skymark's shares have lost almost a quarter of their value in two days. President Shinichi Nishikubo remains committed to buying A380s, but the airline's finances are under scrutiny.

site_title: Company Briefs
summary: Soilbuild Construction Group reported an 11% drop in Q2 net profit to S$5.2 million, despite steady revenue. Mandarin Oriental International saw a 20% drop in net profit to US$45.6 million due to Thai unrest affecting its hotels. Dairy Farm International Holdings reported a 2% increase in net profit to US$234 million, driven by a 5% increase in sales.

site_title: India's Bengaluru posts record home sales
summary: Home sales in Bengaluru, India's IT hub, reached a record 17.77 million square feet in the June quarter, up 10% from the previous quarter. Demand is driven by the off-shoring business, with Grade-A office sales expected to increase 3% to 22.9 million sq ft this year. Home prices rose 4% to 5,239 rupees (S$108) per square foot, with most sales in the middle segment. This is the first increase in office demand in three years and the strongest in Bengaluru.

site_title: Trial over Malaysian plane crash not likely at ICC: Dutch minister
summary: The Netherlands is unlikely to refer the investigation into the downing of Malaysia Airlines flight MH17 to the International Criminal Court (ICC), with Justice Minister Ivo Opstelten stating countries involved are likely to prosecute those responsible. The Dutch-led investigation has received significant evidence, and the Netherlands has universal jurisdiction for war crimes. Pro-Russian separatists are believed to have used a surface-to-air missile to shoot down the plane, killing all 298 passengers and crew. The ICC may be involved if countries are unable or unwilling to prosecute.

site_title: Instagram's new app to debut in S'pore, NZ, South Africa
summary: Instagram has launched a new app, Bolt, in Singapore, New Zealand, and South Africa, allowing users to instantly share content with loved ones. Bolt is a standalone app that captures and shares photos or videos with one tap, and its content is deleted after it's viewed. The app is seen as a more efficient alternative to Snapchat, but its long-term growth remains to be seen. With no monetization plans for now, Instagram is focusing on building user experience first, similar to its 2010 launch.

site_title: Singapore should plan for population of 10m
summary: Singapore should plan for a population of 10 million in the long term, according to architect-planner Liu Thai Ker, to ensure the country's sustainability. Liu, who oversaw Singapore's rapid development from 1969 to 1992, argues that planning for the longer term will provide a better estimate of land needed. A population of 10 million is projected to be reached by 2090, with the possibility of reaching it by 2200 if growth rate is based on lower projections. Liu emphasizes the need for Singapore to adjust to this growth, citing the country's ability to manage increasing land density through education and technology.

site_title: Bad home loans flow through to UOB NPLs
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) reported a 11.2% increase in non-performing loans (NPLs) to S$2.31 billion in the second quarter, driven by weak payments from high-end property buyers. The NPL ratio remains stable at 1.2%, but the bank expects the situation to worsen due to a sluggish residential market. UOB cited isolated cases involving a few borrowers and cash flow challenges in Thailand and Indonesia. Industry observers, including Nicholas Mak, believe the government's cooling measures will continue to impact the market.

site_title: Why accounting standards are getting more complex
summary: The International Accounting Standards Board (IASB) chairman, Hans Hoogervorst, argues that increasingly complex financial reporting standards reflect the economic reality, not a desire for complexity. He suggests that complexity can be made more manageable by cutting out unnecessary disclosures and allowing accountants to use their judgment to report complex transactions. Hoogervorst also acknowledges that some complexity is unavoidable, but believes that a clear and concise presentation of financial statements is possible. The IASB is working to simplify standards and reduce unnecessary disclosures, but convergence with US accounting standards may not be achievable.

site_title: Experiencing poetry in action
summary: A contemporary play, "Meghaduta", based on a 1,500-year-old Indian poem, tells the story of a yaksa's attempt to send a love message to his wife via a cloud. The play features seven graduating students from the Intercultural Theatre Institute, exploring their experiences and emotions. The production brings to life the yaksa's vivid descriptions of the cloud's journey, transforming the ancient tale into a relatable and engaging modern story.

site_title: MH370 survey ships making progress
summary: Australian authorities report progress in the search for Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370, with two survey ships mapping the ocean floor in the southern Indian Ocean. The ships, Zhu Kezhen and Fugro Equator, have covered over 68,000 square kilometers, with a third vessel set to join in August. The deepwater search is expected to begin in September, following the completion of a bathymetric survey. The search, led by Australia, aims to identify possible hazards and determine the plane's final resting place.

site_title: Q2 growth bounces back at a healthy 4%
summary: US economic growth accelerated to a 4% annual rate in the second quarter, surpassing the potential growth trend of 2-2.5%. This rebounded from a 2.1% decline in the first quarter, which was mostly weather-related. Consumer spending and business inventories drove the growth, while Americans saved more in the second quarter. The economy's performance is expected to bolster views for stronger growth in the next six months.

site_title: Art comes alive in interactive experience
summary: The Singapore Art Museum's exhibition "Sensorium 360: Contemporary Art and the Sensed World" explores the nine senses that enable humans to experience life, featuring 11 Asian artists from Singapore and Asia. The show uses interactive installations to engage the audience, exploring concepts such as the relationship between smell and hearing, visually-impaired perspectives, and the psychological effects of boundaries. Curators emphasize the importance of experiencing the artworks firsthand, rather than over-explaining their meanings. The exhibition runs until October 22, with free admission for Singaporeans and PRs.

site_title: Business loans down for first time since Nov 2012
summary: Singapore-dollar business loans declined 0.3% to S$367 billion in June, marking the first decline since November 2012. Trade finance and lending to the manufacturing sector were weaker, with loans to manufacturers falling 2.3% to S$31.1 billion. The moderation in business loans is expected to persist due to strong external headwinds and domestic restructuring pressure. However, consumer loans showed stronger growth, with credit card loans up 2% to S$9.85 billion, and overall Sing-dollar bank lending up 12.3% year-on-year.

site_title: Jazz giants to kick off new music series
summary: Three jazz legends, Arturo Sandoval, Herbie Hancock, and Pat Metheny, will perform at the Esplanade in Singapore as part of the new Mosaic Music Series. The series aims to showcase exceptional musicians and foster connections between audiences and artists. The shows will kick off with Sandoval on August 27, Hancock on September 9, and Metheny on October 27. The series also includes a listening party event, For The Record, to examine Hancock's influence on the genre. The Esplanade plans to continue presenting unique programs and collaborations, including workshops and masterclasses, to support local and international musicians.

site_title: CAO reports 32% jump in Q2 profit to US$17.7m
summary: China Aviation Oil (CAO) reported a 32.44% year-over-year increase in Q2 net profit to US$17.74 million, driven by higher contributions from associates. Revenue rose 4.35% to US$3.93 billion, while operating profit declined 46% to US$4.76 million. The company attributed the decline to lower trading gains from jet fuel and higher storage costs. CAO plans to focus on its core jet supply and trading business while expanding into aviation marketing and diversifying into other oil products.

site_title: Transparency wins funds
summary: A new crowdfunding platform, Geofundit, aims to increase transparency and efficiency in fundraising for non-profit organizations (NPOs) through online campaigns. Launched by 27-year-old Subhas Avadiar, the platform allows donors to track how their funds are used, building trust and encouraging donations. NPOs can run campaigns more efficiently, reducing time, effort, and costs. Geofundit has already seen success with a campaign raising over S$150,000 for an animal welfare charity. The platform plans to expand globally, targeting Asia and other regions, with a unique solution that differentiates it from traditional fundraising methods.

site_title: Baker Q2 earnings dive; order intake healthy
summary: Baker Technology, an offshore and marine equipment and services firm, reported a 92% drop in net profit for the second quarter to S$1 million, down from S$11.3 million last year. Group turnover fell 20% to S$17.8 million due to lower revenue recognition and higher operating expenditure. Despite this, order intake remained healthy, with a net order book of US$61 million, and the company expects orders to be completed within the next 12-18 months.

site_title: Terratech flat after strong start
summary: Terratech Group, a premium marble producer, listed on the Catalist board with its stock closing at 23.5 Singapore cents, 2.2% above its IPO price of 23 cents. The company, a unit of Tritech Group, plans to use the IPO proceeds to expand production capacity and processing facilities. Terratech expects Chinese marble consumption to grow at a 17.6% CAGR between 2010 and 2015, driven by government development trends. The company's CEO aims to venture into calcium carbonate powder production and strategic acquisitions.

site_title: Million-dollar US home loans surging ahead
summary: US banks are issuing mortgages of up to $10 million to wealthy borrowers, with over 15,000 such loans made in the second quarter, according to CoreLogic. In contrast, first-time homebuyers face stricter lending standards, with loan volume declining amid higher credit standards. Interest rates are also driving demand, with borrowers opting for lower rates and adjustable-rate mortgages. Lenders are building long-term relationships with wealthy borrowers to offset declining home lending, offering exclusive deals and flexible repayment terms.

site_title: Far East Group seeks M&A deals
summary: Far East Group, a provider of refrigeration and cooling systems, plans to expand its business in China and Southeast Asia through merger and acquisition opportunities. The company, which has already acquired Eden Refrigeration Manufacturing in China, aims to tap into the growing demand for cooling solutions in urban areas. Far East Group plans to increase its distribution network in China and Southeast Asia, including partnerships with existing distributors and potential acquisitions. The company's shares closed at S$0.192 cents, up one cent from the previous day.

site_title: Fed nods to firmer prices; expresses concern about labour weakness
summary: The Federal Reserve reaffirmed it was in no rush to raise interest rates, citing an improving US economy and a declining jobless rate. The central bank upgraded its assessment of the economy, but expressed concern about labor market slack. The Fed cut its monthly asset purchases to $25 billion, signaling a potential end to its stimulus program this fall. Interest rate futures suggested a greater probability of an initial rate hike early next year, but the Fed reiterated it would keep rates near zero for a "considerable time."

site_title: More perks for firms to give staff flexi-travel options
summary: Singapore's Land Transport Authority (LTA) has launched initiatives to encourage staff to travel on public transport during off-peak periods and opt for alternative modes like cycling and walking. Companies with over 200 employees near MRT stations will receive a Travel Smart Grant of up to S$160,000 to support flexi-travel arrangements. Three new initiatives include travel pattern analysis, employee incentives, and cash rewards for employees who travel during off-peak hours.

site_title: No-commission life insurance up ahead
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) will require life insurers to sell protection up to S$400,000 under a government-mandated direct-purchase scheme starting next year. The scheme, which includes term life insurance and whole life insurance with TPD cover, aims to balance stakeholders' interests while providing consumers with basic protection. The maximum sum assured will be set at S$400,000, with a sub-limit of S$200,000 for whole life products, to protect against consumers buying beyond their means. The move is part of the Financial Advisory Industry Review initiative to cut out agent commissions.

site_title: Around Town
summary: The Boys in the Band, a critically acclaimed play about gay men in 1968 New York City, premieres in Singapore at the Alliance Francaise Theatre from August 7 to 16. The play, written by Mart Crowley, explores themes of friendship, monogamy, and social issues, featuring an all-male, multi-national cast. The event is part of Tim Garner Productions' series of LGBTQ-themed plays, aiming to promote diversity, equality, and inclusion in Singapore.

site_title: SNEF chief Stephen Lee steps down after 26 years
summary: Singapore National Employers Federation (SNEF) president Stephen Lee is stepping down after 26 years, effective September 1. Lee, 67, will be replaced by Robert Yap, 62, CEO and chairman of YCH Group. Lee oversaw the federation's growth from 900 members to over 3,000 with a combined workforce of 700,000. He played a key role in strengthening the employers' partnership with the government and labor movement, leading wage reforms and navigating the SARS outbreak. Lee will remain involved in SNEF discussions and the National Wages Council.

site_title: Industrial space oversupply seen worsening
summary: Industrial space in Singapore is expected to worsen its oversupply issue due to a mismatch between demand and supply, mainly caused by regulatory restrictions on industrial space use. Current rules require at least 60% of the total floor area to be dedicated to core industrial activities, but many modern industrialists are shifting to service-based activities, falling into a "grey area" not covered by the rules. This mismatch is expected to lead to higher vacancies, with rents in the multi-user factory segment easing by 3% for the rest of the year, while the independent high-specification segment and business park segment are expected to see stable rents.

site_title: Focus now on fund-raising options for Wing Hang deal
summary: OCBC secured 97.5% of Wing Hang Bank shares, allowing it to fully acquire the Hong Kong lender. The S$6.2 billion deal will be funded through a mix of existing cash, new debt, and equity, with OCBC raising S$4.4 billion in equity to meet regulatory capital requirements. The acquisition will result in a two percentage point dilution of OCBC's earnings per share. Analysts view the deal as an "exceptional feat," but warn of potential painful restructuring and goodwill writedowns if Wing Hang does not deliver.

site_title: Owner of record-setting tanker seeks refinancing
summary: A record-setting Jones Act tanker, the American Phoenix, is seeking refinancing as its owner, Alterna Capital Partners, looks to profit from the vessel's valuation increase due to record rates for US-flagged ships. The tanker, valued at over $150 million, was previously leased at $100,000 per day and is now considered for leasing, equity, or debt financing. Industry executives suggest the move may be part of Alterna's private equity investment cycle, rather than a response to market conditions, which could soften rates in the next year.

site_title: Boeing raises forecast for global pilots demand
summary: Boeing has raised its forecast for global pilots demand to 533,000 over the next 20 years, citing rising aircraft deliveries and buoyant demand from the Asia-Pacific region. This translates to a need for 27,000 new pilots annually. The region is expected to account for 41% of the total, with Europe and North America following with 94,000 and 88,000 pilots, respectively. Boeing also projects a need for 584,000 technicians over the same period, with the Asia-Pacific region requiring 62,000.

site_title: China probes Microsoft's 'monopoly' actions
summary: China is investigating Microsoft for allegedly operating a monopoly in its market, focusing on its Windows OS and Office suite. The investigation, led by the State Administration for Industry and Commerce (SAIC), centers on allegations of bundling products and failing to disclose information about the software, causing compatibility issues. This move comes amid increased scrutiny of foreign firms doing business in China, with similar investigations launched in the pharmaceutical and baby milk powder industries.

site_title: Tuan Sing Q2 profit drops 24%, revenue down 31%
summary: Tuan Sing Holdings reported a 24% decline in Q2 net profit to S$11.6 million and a 31% drop in revenue to S$81.6 million, due to slower recognition of residential sales. The group's property division still accounted for 52% of total revenue and 70% of total profit. Despite this, Tuan Sing is optimistic about achieving better operational performance in FY14, with a total order book of S$749.5 million for development properties in Singapore.

site_title: St James' Place posts record funds
summary: UK wealth manager St James' Place posted record funds under management (FuM) of £47.6 billion in the first half of the year, a 19% increase. New client inflows and retained existing funds contributed to the growth, driven by affluent clients seeking its services. Operating profit rose 12% to £260.7 million, resulting in a 40% increase in the interim dividend. The company's stock has risen 8.5% this year, outperforming the FTSE 100.

site_title: Londoners cashing out, selling houses in city
summary: Londoners are selling their homes in the city, with many opting for suburban and country homes due to expected rising mortgage rates and new lending rules. The city's housing market has cooled, with prices stagnating for the first time since December 2012. The average price gap between London and the rest of England is £265,000, the widest on record. This has led to a surge in demand for suburban properties, with Londoners purchasing 75% more homes outside the capital than last year. Experts predict further price declines in the city, with the luxury market also showing signs of slowing.

images.alt_text: Moving on: London house prices stagnated last month compared with the prior month, the first time there's been no growth since December 2012. - PHOTO: BLOOMBERG

site_title: Equities should surpass bonds in H2
summary: Global equity markets are expected to surpass bonds in the second half of 2014, despite the year's patchy performance so far. The US economy's growth rebound in Q2 has boosted investor sentiment, and corporations are putting large cash holdings to work through M&A activity at near-record pace. However, geo-political uncertainties, particularly in Ukraine, and China's economic restructuring pose headwinds. Markets are likely to remain volatile, but economic fundamentals are expected to improve, driving better corporate earnings and ultimately benefiting equities.

site_title: Risks linked to corporate travel on the rise
summary: Corporate travel is experiencing a surge in international business travel, with spending expected to rise 7% this year to $1.18 trillion. However, this growth comes with increased safety and security concerns, with travel managers facing complex threats such as terrorism, Ebola outbreaks, and civil unrest. Industry experts warn that companies have a growing responsibility to protect their travelers, with potential legal and ethical implications. The industry is urging travel managers to implement robust safety policies and training for both experienced and novice travelers, and to maintain close communication with travelers during crises.

site_title: Carriers to seek 'neutral' info on airspace use
summary: Global airlines are pushing for "neutral information" on airspace use to ensure secure flights after the Malaysian airliner crash over Ukraine. The International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) is to discuss improved access to objective criteria with airline heads and air traffic control networks. Airlines need accurate information to decide whether to fly, but countries may not provide it. ICAO's role is limited, and any changes to its authority could test historic peace agreements. The agency could help inform country regulators, but governments may be hesitant to share sensitive military intelligence.

site_title: Global Premium Hotels Q2 profit down 22.2%
summary: Global Premium Hotels Limited reported a 22.2% year-over-year decline in Q2 net profit to S$3.81 million, due to factors such as the closure of Fragrance Hotel - Elegance and lower revenue from other hotels. The company's average occupancy rate decreased to 85.7% and average revenue per available room slipped to S$92.80. Despite a partial offset from Parc Sovereign Hotel - Tyrwhitt's maiden revenue contribution, earnings per share fell to 0.36 Singapore cent. The company expects better performance in the next six months with the full operation of the new hotel and completion of asset enhancement works.

site_title: Foreign buyers fuel concern in Miami luxury condo boom
summary: Miami's luxury condo boom is slowing due to an investor glut, slowing sales, and plans for thousands of new units. Foreign buyers, particularly from Latin America, Europe, and Canada, have fueled the market, but analysts warn of a possible oversupply and subsequent price drops. Existing condo sales fell 3.8% in June, and developers are requiring large deposits to finance construction. The investor glut may prompt some buyers to pull their money out of the market, potentially starting a selloff.

images.alt_text: Hot market: High-end condos in Miami. Florida led the US for foreign buyers in the first quarter, attracting 23% of US$92.2 billion of nationwide sales, - PHOTO: BLOOMBERG

site_title: Not easy to follow HK, S'pore property moves
summary: Hong Kong and Singapore have successfully cooled down their housing markets through government-imposed measures such as mortgage caps, taxes on property flippers, and levies on foreign buyers. Unlike other global cities like London and New York, these cities have control over their economies and residents' behavior due to their island geographies, public housing, and government policy-making power. Singapore and Hong Kong's unique circumstances allow them to implement decisive policy measures, whereas other cities face challenges in implementing similar controls.

site_title: Company Briefs
summary: Rotary Engineering disposed of its Shanghai unit for 22.2 million yuan (S$4.46 million) in cash, which won't affect its earnings per share and net tangible assets for the current fiscal year. SSC posted a 7.5% drop in net profit to US$1.8 million in Q1, due to a 20.1% decline in revenue, but expects its ship-owning business to improve with upcoming vessel acquisitions. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed.

site_title: Stay cautious on China, bullish on Japan: Eastspring
summary: Fund manager Nicholas Ferres from Eastspring Investments advises investors to stay cautious on China due to high debt and low free cash flow, despite its rallying stock prices. In contrast, he's bullish on Japan, citing rising profitability and free cash flows, as well as decreasing debt. Ferres also identifies Russia as an opportunity, citing its low valuations, low debt, and large foreign reserves buffer. He allocates 1% of his fund to Russia and emerging Europe, expecting the bearishness to be overdone.

site_title: Iraq seeks court order to seize oil worth US$100m in Texas
summary: Iraq's Oil Ministry seeks a court order to seize approximately $100 million of oil in Galveston, Texas, claiming it was illegally pumped from Kurdish wells. The oil, valued at over 1 million barrels, was exported through a Turkish pipeline and has undergone multiple changes in destination while at sea. If seized, it could signal recognition of Kurdistan's autonomy and potentially fuel the region's fight for independence.

site_title: Qantas continuing flights over Iraq
summary: Qantas will continue to fly over Iraqi airspace despite concerns about jihadist missile attacks. The airline's chief pilot stated that flying at altitudes above 38,000 feet makes it "far exceeding" the US Federal Aviation Administration's safety recommendation. Qantas will monitor the situation closely and adjust routes if necessary to ensure passenger safety. This decision contrasts with Emirates, which has halted flights over Iraq following the MH17 crash, and Etihad Airways, which has continued to fly over the region.

site_title: Govt injects S$100m to boost energy R&D
summary: The National Research Foundation (NRF) has announced a S$100 million investment to fund two energy R&D initiatives in Singapore, focusing on making buildings and data centers more energy-efficient. The initiatives will be implemented and managed by the Building & Construction Authority (BCA) and will comprise existing and new test facilities. The goal is to improve energy efficiency and reduce the country's carbon footprint.

site_title: Starhill Reit's Q2 DPU up despite lower overseas revenue
summary: Starhill Global Reit reported a 5% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.25 Singapore cents for its Q2, despite lower overseas revenue and a 1.4% decline in total revenue to S$48.4 million. Net property income rose 0.2% to S$39.2 million, driven by rental reversions in Singapore. However, revenue from China and Japan fell due to economic contraction and increased competition. The Reit's outlook for its Chengdu business remains bleak, with continued high-end luxury retail challenges in China.

site_title: Iskandar regulator plays down fears of property glut
summary: The Iskandar Regional Development Authority (IRDA) has downplayed concerns of a property glut in Iskandar Malaysia, citing jobs to be created over the next few years to ensure demand for thousands of homes. IRDA CEO Ismail Ibrahim noted that improved public transport, including a proposed rail link between Singapore and Johor Bahru, would be essential for advancing the economic zone. Despite concerns over high-end property supply and potential disruptions from massive reclamation projects, IRDA believes that the development of catalyst projects, such as the $27 billion Petroleum Integrated Complex, will create jobs and stimulate demand for housing.

site_title: Airbus profit rises on more commercial plane deliveries
summary: Airbus reported a 10% increase in first-half earnings to €1.77 billion, driven by more commercial plane deliveries. The company aims for a "moderate return on sales growth" this year, with net commercial orders exceeding deliveries. Airbus plans to deliver its first A350 wide-body model to Qatar Airlines by year-end and expects new orders to top its goal of 630 planes for the year. The company's restructuring plans in defense and space are also on track.

site_title: Preparing for the end of QE3
summary: The US Federal Reserve concluded its monthly meeting, signaling the end of its third quantitative easing (QE3) program by October. Despite this, interest rates are expected to remain low for some time. Market analysts, such as Pimco, believe the world is in a "new neutral" mode, with low interest rates and global growth. However, some experts, including Goldman Sachs, warn of geopolitical risks and potential market corrections, suggesting that the Fed's predictions may not hold. If inflation rises and the economy continues to grow, interest rates may rise sooner than expected, affecting asset prices and borrowing costs.

site_title: Poland may pay more for LNG terminal
summary: Poland's LNG terminal construction is on track despite potential cost increases. The consortium building the terminal is in talks to increase its payment from 2.4 billion zlotys to around 3 billion zlotys, citing changes in Polish law that will extend the project timeline and incur higher costs. Despite this, there is no risk to the project's completion, and both parties aim to finish the terminal on time and with the highest quality. The terminal, which will supply half of Poland's current annual gas usage, is expected to be completed by the end of 2015 and will be supplied by Qatar.

site_title: Deutsche Bank hires Allianz's Dilworth to head asset unit
summary: Deutsche Bank has hired James Dilworth, 57, as head of active asset management, overseeing almost half a trillion euros in actively managed investments. Dilworth, former CEO of Allianz Global Investors Europe, will lead the unit's operations in Germany and report to Michele Faissola. He succeeds Wolfgang Matis, who retired for personal reasons, and will oversee 400 employees.

site_title: OCBC has 97.5% of Wing Hang in the bag
summary: OCBC Bank secured 97.5% of Wing Hang Bank shares, allowing it to acquire the remaining shares and delist the Hong Kong bank. The acquisition is part of OCBC's Greater China strategy, giving it control of 88 branches in the region. The deal is expected to be accretive to OCBC's earnings per share and return on equity by 2017. OCBC plans to integrate Wing Hang's operations and businesses, offering a wider range of services to customers in the region.

site_title: Soilbuild Reit's Q2 DPU beats forecast
summary: Soilbuild Reit posted a Q2 distribution per unit (DPU) of 1.5 Singapore cents, beating the forecast of 1.481 cents. The real estate investment trust's annualised DPU is 6 cents, with an annualised distribution yield of 7.5%. The company's portfolio occupancy is 98.5%, and 85% of lease expiries due this year have been renewed or pre-committed. Net property income was S$14.04 million, beating the forecast by 3.4%. The revised JTC subletting policy is expected to impact only 10% of Soilbuild Reit's portfolio in the medium term.

site_title: Japfa to offer shares at an indicative price of 75-87 cents
summary: Japfa Limited, a Singapore-based producer of multiple protein foods, has lodged its preliminary prospectus for an initial public offering (IPO) of up to 285.2 million shares at an indicative price of 75-87 Singapore cents. The company, which boasts of brands such as 'So Good' and 'Greenfields', claims to be a market leader in protein foods and has operations in emerging Asian markets. Japfa expects to generate US$390 million in capital expenditures, which it plans to fund through the IPO and internal cash.

site_title: STATS ChipPAC's new technology sees strong demand
summary: STATS ChipPAC's new encapsulated Wafer Level Chip Scale Project (eWLCSP) technology has seen strong demand, with customers adopting it to improve quality, reduce costs, and increase ease of conversion for compact electronics. The eWLCSP solution, featuring a thin polymer case, provides mechanical robustness and resistance to damage. This addresses concerns over bare die packaging and inspection costs. The technology is expected to benefit STATS ChipPAC's customers and potentially lead to increased sales. The company's share price has jumped in recent months, fueling speculation of a possible takeover.

site_title: Consumer confidence highest since Oct '07
summary: US consumer confidence reached its highest level in nearly seven years, rising to 90.9 in July, according to the Conference Board. Strong job growth, fewer firings, and resilient equity markets are driving the increase. The Conference Board's gauge of present conditions rose to 88.3, and consumer expectations for the next six months increased to 92.7, the highest since February 2011. The unemployment rate dropped to 6.1%, and more employment opportunities are expected in the coming months, likely to influence Federal Reserve policy.

site_title: Heads or tails? Either way, you might beat a stock picker
summary: A recent S&P Dow Jones Indices study found that actively managed stock mutual funds have performed worse than expected, suggesting that luck rather than skill may be the primary reason for their success. The study's results were comparable to flipping a coin, with only 0.07% of funds consistently outperforming their peers over five years. This supports the conclusion that passively managed index funds are a better choice for most investors, as they eliminate the need to pick individual stocks or fund managers based on past performance.

site_title: Civmec unveils three-pronged expansion approach to growth
summary: Australian construction and engineering services provider Civmec is expanding its operations with a three-pronged approach. The firm plans to set up an office in Singapore in the next few months, which will serve as a hub to expand to the rest of the world. Civmec aims to integrate its eight vertical pillars and create more efficient processes. Despite the decline of the Australian mining industry, the firm sees opportunities in the sector and expects to derive more revenue from oil and gas in the future. The company has also developed an in-house IT system called Civtrac to drive efficiencies and provide its clients with real-time tracking of projects.

site_title: KepLand invests US$70m in New York property
summary: Keppel Land invests US$70 million in a New York residential development with a retail component, managed by Alpha Investment Partners, a subsidiary of Keppel Land. The property is located on the Upper East Side in Manhattan. This is Keppel Land's first US investment, and it aims to tap into the local market's growth potential. The investment is expected to have minimal impact on Keppel Land's financials.

site_title: HK expected to stay ahead as Asian precious metals hub
summary: Hong Kong is expected to maintain its position as an Asian precious metals hub despite competition from Shanghai and Singapore. Brink's Co, a US-based company, is opening a new vault in the city, doubling its gold and silver handling capacity. China's gold demand fell 19% in the first half of the year, and the country's demand is increasing at a slower pace due to currency weakness. The new vault will primarily be used by international financial institutions and institutional investors for storing precious metals.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: China tourist arrivals show no rebound, impacting local tourism earnings. Emerging economies' growth rate is expected to slow to 5% over the next five years. The EU has imposed sanctions on Russia, while Singapore attracts non-profit organizations. Raffles Medical Group increased net profit 8.5% in the second quarter. Completed condos' prices continue to fall, and Argentina defaults may trigger $29 billion in bondholder claims. US tech firms face risks of losing business due to NSA spying, and international business travel poses safety and security concerns.

site_title: Emerging economies to grow at 5% over next 5 years: IMF
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) predicts that emerging economies in Asia and elsewhere will experience a slowdown in growth to 5% over the next 5 years, down from 7% in the run-up to the 2008 global financial crisis. This slowdown could have a 2% drop in global output and spillover effects on recovery in advanced economies. The IMF warns that if monetary tightening is caused by market concerns over financial stability, emerging markets could suffer prolonged damage.

site_title: Interest in funds returning
summary: Wealthy investors are increasingly turning to fund investments, driven by a growing awareness of the importance of a portfolio approach to investments. According to Chandrima Das, Bank of Singapore's managing director, fund investments among high net worth individuals have risen, with long-only funds accounting for over 7% of clients' portfolios, up from 2% a few years ago. However, past experiences with funds have "tainted" investors' perceptions, with many suffering losses during market downturns. Das advocates a core/satellite approach to investments, where a core portfolio with a strategic asset allocation is complemented by tactical bets or trading ideas.

site_title: ISDN ropes in co-investors for Indonesian hydropower unit
summary: ISDN Holdings has roped in See Hup Seng as a co-investor in its Indonesian mini-hydropower projects, with See Hup Seng investing US$8 million for a 25% stake. This partnership aims to tap into Indonesia's vast renewable energy potential, with the goal of increasing renewable energy to 15% of total energy production by 2025. Canadian investor Robert Alexander Stone also acquired 20% of Aenergy Holdings Company, investing US$6.4 million. The partnerships aim to diversify and fortify ISDN's shareholder base and forge synergistic partnerships.

site_title: RMG begins work on Holland V project
summary: Raffles Medical Group (RMG) reported an 8.5% increase in net profit to S$15.61 million for Q2, driven by a higher patient load from its expanding clinic network. Revenue rose 6.6% to S$92.6 million, while operating profit increased 6.3% to S$18.73 million. Construction on its Holland V project has begun, with expected rental projections of 4-5% per annum. The company also submitted plans for its Raffles Hospital extension and declared an interim dividend of 1.5 Singapore cents per share.

site_title: EU takes aim at Russia financing, advanced tech
summary: The European Union has imposed its widest-ranging sanctions yet on Russia, curbing its access to bank financing and advanced technology in response to President Vladimir Putin's backing of the rebellion in eastern Ukraine. The EU has barred Russian state-owned banks from selling shares or bonds in Europe, restricted the export of equipment to modernize the oil industry, and banned new contracts to sell arms to Russia. The US is also drawing up fresh sanctions, with Secretary of State John Kerry warning that "economic costs are starting to bite" for Russia, but the EU stopped short of full-scale commercial warfare to avoid damaging its own economy.

site_title: Reinventing the (airplane) wheel
summary: A joint venture between Honeywell and Safran is developing an electric taxi system, EGTS, for airplanes. The system, which installs motors on the main landing gear, allows planes to taxi using their own electrical power instead of the main engines. This could save airlines millions in fuel costs, reduce engine maintenance, and lower emissions. The system has already seen interest from several airlines, including Air France and easyJet, and is expected to be installed on new planes and retrofitted on existing ones starting in 2016.

site_title: Canned bookings, poor sales pummel MAS
summary: Malaysia Airline System is facing a surge in passenger cancellations following the downing of MH17, with some travel agents reporting cancellations exceeding 20% since the incident. The airline's financial difficulties are compounded by its estimated annual loss of RM4.13 billion, with some analysts predicting a loss of over RM1 billion in 2014. The airline has attempted to lure passengers with lower fares, but experts say this may not be enough to reverse the trend, with passengers "very afraid" of flying with the airline again.

site_title: Chinese tourist arrivals slump; quick rebound not expected
summary: Chinese tourist arrivals to Singapore have plummeted by 27.4% in the first half of the year, with visitor numbers from China falling 14% and overall arrivals down 1.7%. The decline is attributed to the aftermath of the MH370 disappearance, the Thai crisis, and recent airline crashes. New China tourism laws have also deterred travelers. Industry players predict a slow recovery, with sales from the summer holidays still down 10% from last year. However, some travel agencies report a slight increase in bookings for customised tours including Malaysia, offering a glimmer of hope for a potential rebound.

site_title: Analysts not upbeat about SIA's first-quarter results
summary: Singapore Airlines is expected to report a muted performance in its first-quarter results due to downward pressure on yields. Analysts predict revenue will remain flat, while losses at SIA Cargo are expected to continue. Load factor decreased by 0.3 percentage points to 77.7% due to a 0.4% year-on-year increase in passenger carriage. The airline's joint venture with Tata is expected to contribute little in the near term, but may provide a long-term foothold in India's aviation market.

site_title: Sulphur emission enigma
summary: The International Maritime Organization's (IMO) 0.1% sulphur limit for ship emissions in North America and northern Europe will take effect in January 2015. While the shipping industry is generally ready, enforcement uniformity is a concern, particularly in northern Europe where countries have different views on technical issues. The International Chamber of Shipping (ICS) has expressed concerns about the potential for market distortion and is urging governments to implement the regulations uniformly to ensure compliance. The ICS has written to the Paris Memorandum of Understanding on Port State Control (PSC) to address these concerns.

site_title: Gold prices down on solid US jobs data
summary: Gold prices fell by 0.4% to US$1,301.49 per ounce after two weeks of declines, while silver retreated 0.6% to US$20.6240 per ounce. Platinum prices, however, rose 0.4% to US$1,484.50 per ounce. The decline was attributed to the US jobs data showing a low number of jobless claims, which boosted global equities and the US dollar. The situation in Russia and Gaza also weighed on gold prices, but analysts expect a measure of stability in the early part of the week.

site_title: Citi in Asia-Pac commercial banking push
summary: Citigroup plans to hire up to 100 bankers in Asia-Pacific commercial banking, a 10% boost for its unit, to offer smaller corporate clients a wider range of products. The strategy focuses on cross-border business, with a target of winning more wallet share from commercial banking clients. Citi aims to expand services to firms with annual sales between $10 million and $500 million, targeting suppliers to major Asian firms and start-ups. Banking revenue from small and medium-sized companies in emerging markets is expected to grow 20% per year, reaching $350 billion by 2015.

site_title: Plane downing may be war crime, says UN
summary: The UN has stated that the downing of Malaysia Airlines Flight MH17 may constitute a war crime due to its location in insurgent-held eastern Ukraine during a civil war. UN High Commissioner for Human Rights Navi Pillay condemned the incident, calling for a thorough and independent investigation. The Dutch-led investigation has been hindered by intensifying fighting in the area, and the Red Cross has classified Ukraine as in a state of civil war, making parties liable for war crimes.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: A slew of companies in Singapore are set to raise funds through initial public offerings (IPOs) as investor sentiment improves. The Land Transport Authority has announced it will match any toll increase on the Causeway if Malaysia follows suit. Macau's gaming revenue declined in June for the first time in five years, while the UN has deemed the downing of Malaysia Airlines flight MH17 as potentially a war crime. Manhattan Resources plans to expand into mining, and Singapore firms are lagging in tapping into the benefits of the Shanghai Free Trade Zone.

site_title: Pending home sales take unexpected dip in June
summary: The US pending home sales index declined 1.1% in June, falling short of forecasts, as limited credit availability and slow wage growth hindered prospective buyers. This marks a reversal from the 6% increase in May. Economists attribute the drop to credit constraints and stagnant wages, which may slow the housing recovery. The industry will need continued employment gains and a larger supply of homes to accelerate growth, while rising home prices may encourage more sellers to list their properties.

site_title: Australia's NAB sells £625m of property bad loans in UK
summary: National Australia Bank (NAB) sold £625m of non-performing commercial property loans in the UK to Cerberus Global Investors, reducing its gross loan balance by 20% to £2.38 billion. The sale will result in a small gain above net book value, releasing £127m of capital. The move aims to optimize return on equity and reduce exposure to UK commercial property loans, which have been weighed down by mounting bad debts. The sale also reduces gross impaired loans in the UK by 48% and allows for increased provision coverage on remaining assets.

site_title: Macau's gaming fortunes down in June
summary: Macau's gaming revenue declined 3.7% in June, marking the first monthly drop in five years, due to factors such as the World Cup and lack of new major attractions. Total gross gaming revenue fell to 27 billion patacas (S$4.2 billion). Analysts attribute the decline to tough year-on-year comparisons, a shift towards mass-market gamblers, and a crackdown on debit card usage. New integrated resorts are set to open in mid-2015, but investors and operators acknowledge 2014 will be a "tough year" for business.

site_title: Manhattan Resources expands into mining
summary: Manhattan Resources, a coal shipping firm, is expanding into mining. The company has made several mining-related announcements, including acquiring Singxin Resources, a mining firm in Xinjiang, for S$1 billion. Manhattan will use the mining expertise of its sister company Bayan Resources, a coal producer, to develop three mines in Xinjiang. The firm expects minimal capital expenditure and will focus on open-cut surface mining and selling chromite ores and serpentine, a versatile mineral used in steel-making. Manhattan aims to diversify into new revenue streams and embark on a new growth phase, with plans to conduct research and development into carbon emissions technology.
