Etihad's 24% stake in Jet will enable the airline to compete with regional rivals.

site_title: Home and office project at Canary Wharf gets approval
summary: Canary Wharf Group has secured local-government approval for the Wood Wharf project, which will feature 3,610 homes, office space, shops, and a hotel in London's Canary Wharf business district. The project, valued at £90.4 million, is the company's largest development in its pipeline, with 4.9 million sq ft of office space. The revised plan includes a minimum of 1,700 homes and was approved by the Tower Hamlets council. The project will be built adjacent to the existing Canary Wharf business district.

site_title: UN aviation body said to be mulling over bigger role
summary: The International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) is considering expanding its role to issue safety advisories after Malaysia Airlines flight MH17 was shot down in eastern Ukraine, killing 298 people. Representatives are weighing the potential for ICAO to issue warnings over zones of conflict, but there's no guarantee of change. The agency's current role is limited to advising member states, and any expansion would require agreement from member nations and consideration of liability. Small incremental adjustments may be made, but a major overhaul is unlikely.

site_title: Ezion sells two businesses to AusGroup for S$55m
summary: Ezion Holdings has agreed to sell its marine base and vessel chartering business to AusGroup for S$55 million, with AusGroup issuing 92.16 million shares at 44.49 Singapore cents apiece. The deal allows Ezion to focus on its service rigs business and AusGroup to expand into Australia's marine services. Ezion's stake in AusGroup will rise to 17.83% after the deal. The transaction is seen as a boost for AusGroup's revival plan, with its shares rising 1.12%. However, analysts question the deal's synergies and value, citing a "high valuation" of the assets being sold.

site_title: Eyes on China XLX performance on HK bourse
summary: China XLX Fertiliser Ltd will cease trading on the Singapore bourse at the end of July 24 and will only be quoted on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange, where it has a primary listing. The company's controlling shareholder, Liu Xingxu, has only managed to accumulate an additional 1.5% of shares, resulting in Pioneer Top Holdings owning 66.4% of the company. The stock's performance in Hong Kong is expected to be similar to that of two previous companies, China Animal Healthcare and Sound Global, which experienced significant price increases after delisting.

site_title: Sharp rise in private home purchases in Q2
summary: The number of private home purchases in Singapore increased by 37.1% in Q2, with 3,369 units transacted. The resale market saw a 41% rise, with 1,328 units sold, ending three consecutive quarters of decline. This surge may indicate that authorities are reconsidering property cooling measures, despite previous decisions to maintain them.

site_title: Keppel Land lifts Q2 profit despite falling sales
summary: Keppel Land reported a 12.2% rise in net profit to S$107.2 million for Q2, driven by its fund-management business and profit from Chinese projects. Revenue dropped 7.8% to S$304.6 million due to lower home sales in China and Singapore. The company's Alpha Investments and Keppel Reit contributed to the profit growth.

site_title: Keppel T&T's Q2 profit down 12.8%, revenue up 27%
summary: Keppel T&T reported a 12.8% decline in Q2 net profit to S$14.3 million, despite a 27% increase in revenue to S$51.3 million. Higher interest expenses and lower share of results from associated companies contributed to the decline. Revenue from data centre and logistics divisions drove the growth, with logistics revenue up 26.4% and data centre revenue up 19.7%. Earnings per share fell to 2.6 cents, down from 3 cents last year.

site_title: Malaysia, Australia still seeking missing MH370
summary: Malaysia and Australia continue searching for missing MH370, four months after the Malaysian airliner disappeared. The search efforts involve two crash investigations, with Australia sending 45 officials to Ukraine and Malaysia sending 133 people. Australia's Angus Houston has been sent to Ukraine to oversee the recovery of remains of Flight 17 victims, while the search for MH370 remains ongoing, with no new developments reported. The Australian government emphasizes the priority of finding MH370, alongside Malaysia and other countries.

site_title: Xpress in share placement deal to raise S$9.48 million
summary: Xpress Holdings, a Singaporean printing company, has entered into a share placement deal to raise S$9.48 million. The move comes after creditors started legal action over debts of S$2.4 million. The company has appointed a financial consultant and is in discussions with creditors to formulate a settlement. Fifty-five percent of the net proceeds will be used to repay creditors, with the remaining 45% for general working capital. The share placement is subject to in-principle listing approval from the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: Jokowi aiming for 7% growth for Indonesia
summary: President-elect Joko Widodo of Indonesia aims for a 7% annual economic growth rate, the highest pace since the 1990s Asian financial crisis. Widodo, 53, has pledged to address infrastructure and manufacturing shortcomings, invest in human capital, and curb fuel subsidies to boost growth. He secured 53.15% of votes in the July 9 election, beating 46.85% for Prabowo Subianto. Widodo's coalition has 37% of parliament seats, and he plans to start discussions on a Cabinet lineup and seek details on the budget position. Analysts believe his victory is likely to strengthen Indonesia's role in international forums.

site_title: Sheng Siong Q2 profit up 30.3%
summary: Sheng Siong Group Ltd reported a 30.3% rise in net profit for the fiscal second quarter ended June 30, driven by higher profit margin and stable selling prices despite strong competition. The company's gross profit rose 14.3% to S$42.32 million, and a 1.5 cent per share interim dividend has been declared. Despite a slight downward bias in selling prices, input prices improved due to savings from the Mandai Distribution Centre, resulting in a 24.7% gross margin. The company's shares ended trading half a cent lower at 66 cents.

site_title: Q1 profit at SATS slides to S$43.3m
summary: SATS, a gateway services and food solutions provider, reported a net profit of S$43.3 million for Q1 2014, down 6.3% year-over-year. Revenue remained flat at S$435.2 million. Gateway revenue grew 2% due to increased flights and airfreight, but food revenue declined 0.9% due to the weaker Japanese yen. The company expects moderate growth at Changi Airport and will invest in new technologies and facilities to boost productivity.

site_title: US home-rental industry is reshaping itself
summary: The US home-rental industry is undergoing a significant reshaping, with small landlords exiting the market and corporate owners selling houses in bulk. Following a 26% surge in prices since 2012, companies like Blackstone, Colony, and American Homes 4 Rent are consolidating their operations, focusing on efficient management and minimizing costs. Larger firms are using scale to reduce turnover, lease renewal rates, and expenses. As institutional funds internalize property management, they face challenges in maintaining thousands of homes, highlighting the importance of effective tenant management.

site_title: Petrol hikes push June consumer prices up 0.3%
summary: US consumer prices rose 0.3% in June, the smallest increase since February, as petrol costs jumped 3.3% and food costs increased 0.1%. The core measure, excluding volatile food and fuel costs, rose 0.1%, less than forecast. The increase is seen as temporary, bolstering Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's view that recent price hikes were reversing. If prices remain in check, Fed policymakers can keep interest rates low well into next year, according to economists.

site_title: Verizon slims down, delighting developers
summary: Verizon Communications has sold over $1 billion in buildings across the US, with the majority in New York, as the company downsizes due to rapid technological changes. The sold properties, including fortress-like brick high-rises, have been converted into residential condominiums, luxury homes, and office spaces, with some retaining Verizon facilities. The sales have proven beneficial for developers in an airtight market, and Verizon has pocketed the proceeds without returning them to customers as lower rates.

site_title: Pacific Andes bonds snapped up
summary: Pacific Andes Resources Development sold its inaugural Sing-dollar bond issue, receiving orders exceeding S$2 billion for its three-year, S$200 million issue priced at 8.50% down from 8.75%. Private bank clients accounted for the majority of the deal, similar to other recent deals by Halcyon Agri Corporation and Hyflux. The hot local bond market is driven by liquidity and relative undersupply, with 71 issues worth S$13.4 billion issued year-to-date, exceeding the same period last year.

site_title: Changi passenger traffic dips in June
summary: Changi Airport passenger traffic declined 0.3% year-on-year to 4.65 million in June, after a 1.4% increase in the first half of the year. This marks a deceleration in growth, with April and May seeing 3.4% and 2% increases, respectively. Commercial aircraft movements dropped 0.5% to 28,130 flights, while airfreight handled decreased 0.2% to 154,700 tonnes.

site_title: A*Star, partners unveil 4 joint semicon labs
summary: A*Star's Institute of Microelectronics (IME) has launched four joint semiconductor labs with 10 industry partners, committing S$200 million to facilitate "earlier, faster and cheaper" commercialization of semiconductor technologies. The labs focus on lithography, wafer level packaging, metrology, and assembly, aiming to capture new growth opportunities for Singapore and the region. The partnership reflects the country's commitment to the semiconductor industry, which has driven economic growth, with its value-added increasing nine times since 1993 to S$10.9 billion last year.

site_title: Analysts not expecting surprises from local banks
summary: Analysts expect Singapore's local banks, DBS, OCBC, and UOB, to report stable core earnings in the second quarter, driven by loan growth of 2-3% and non-Singapore operations. However, net interest margins (NIMs) may face pressure due to increased competition for deposits. The banks' China exposures and Asean businesses will also be scrutinized. UOB's Thailand operations may be impacted by ongoing political turmoil, while OCBC's insurance unit could provide a surprise. Overall, the banks' asset quality is expected to remain healthy, with non-performing loans (NPLs) likely to increase gradually.

site_title: Paris ready to cancel warship sale to Russia
summary: French President Francois Hollande announced he's prepared to cancel the sale of a second Mistral helicopter carrier ship to Russia if the EU expands sanctions. The ship, due in 2016, hasn't been paid for, allowing for possible withholding of the sale. However, sanctions can't be retroactive and won't apply to the first ship, already paid for and due for delivery in October. This decision comes amid Russia's ongoing conflict and EU efforts to impose additional measures on the country.

site_title: New acquisitions, better rentals boost A-Reit Q1 results
summary: ASCENDAS Reit (A-Reit) reported a 2.5% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 3.64 Singapore cents for its Q1 results, driven by new acquisitions and positive rental reversion. Gross revenue rose 8.1% to S$163.2 million, while net property income increased 7.7% to S$116.3 million. The Reit expects positive rental reversion this financial year at a mid- to high single-digit rate, despite a 1.4% decline in same-store portfolio occupancy.

site_title: Sales of super sports cars down to a trickle
summary: Sales of super sports cars in Singapore have plummeted by 90% since tax hikes and loan curbs took effect last year, with only 14 Ferrari units registered between January and June, down from 64 units in the same period last year. Similar declines have been seen at McLaren, with four units registered in the first six months compared to 17 a year ago. The high prices and increased taxes are deterring buyers, with some customers even deferring registration of their cars.

site_title: South Korea police find body of 'Sewol' owner
summary: South Korean police have found the body of Yoo Byung-eun, the owner of the Sewol ferry that sank in April, killing 294 people. The body was identified through DNA testing after being discovered in a field six weeks ago. The cause of death is unknown, with police awaiting toxicology and forensic analysis results. Yoo had been on the run since a summons was issued after the sinking, and a reward was offered for his capture. He was wanted for questioning on possible charges of embezzlement and criminal negligence related to lax safety standards and regulatory violations.

site_title: Aviation safety gaps need to be plugged
summary: Malaysia Airlines Flight MH17 was shot down over eastern Ukraine, killing 298 people, after it flew through airspace where multiple aircraft had been shot down by pro-Russia separatists. Despite warnings from the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) and US Federal Aviation Administration, airlines continued to use the route, with some carriers flying just minutes apart. The incident highlights gaps in airspace risk assessments, prompting calls for governments and ICAO to review and develop new protocols to prevent similar tragedies. Airlines have since rerouted flights, adding to operational costs and travel time.

site_title: Cosco Corp units score US$300m in contracts
summary: Cosco Corp units have secured US$300 million in contracts, including the building of an accommodation barge and seven bulk carriers. The company's shipyard subsidiaries, Cosco (Zhoushan) Shipyard Co Ltd and Cosco (Dalian) Shipyard Co Ltd, won these deals from European and Asian companies. Meanwhile, a subsidiary, Cosco (Nantong) Shipyard Co Ltd, has completed 96% of construction work on a vessel building project, but the contract will be terminated due to the company voluntary arrangement (CVA) proceedings of the client, ATP Oil & Gas (UK).

site_title: FCT's Q3 DPU rises 6% on higher rentals
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) reported a 6% rise in distribution per unit (DPU) to 3.022 Singapore cents in the third quarter, driven by higher retail rentals and occupancies. The trust's portfolio occupancy grew to 98.5% and rental reversions increased by 7.8%. FCT's CEO, Chew Tuan Chiong, expects the retail market to remain stable, with sustainable occupancy and rental rates.

site_title: French port welcomes Russians
summary: French port Saint-Nazaire welcomes 400 Russian sailors temporarily stationed there for training on two warships built by France, despite European concerns and opposition from the US. The port's economy, struggling with high unemployment, sees the deal as a triumph, with 7,000-8,000 people relying on the shipyard for a living. The training is part of a $1.6 billion deal signed in 2011, and the first ship, Vladivostok, is scheduled for delivery in November.

site_title: Suntec Reit's Q2 DPU up despite equity dilution
summary: Suntec Reit reported a 2.266 Singapore cents distribution per unit (DPU) for Q2 2014, a slight increase from the previous year, despite an 11.3% rise in distributable income to S$56.6 million. The trust's equity dilution from a private placement in March 2014 was largely offset by a 19.8% increase in distributable income from operations. The Reit's net property income rose 64.9% to S$46.1 million, driven by the opening of the Suntec Singapore Convention & Exhibition Centre.

site_title: Private pension plans 'no walk in the park': DPM
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam stated that private pension plans for Central Provident Fund (CPF) members are still an option for the future, despite the government's focus on enhancing the CPF scheme. However, he cautioned that such plans may not be risk-free, as riskier plans have not always resulted in higher returns. The government has not ruled out allowing CPF members to use their monies for private pension plans, but emphasized the need for careful consideration.

site_title: Myths and realities of hedge funds
summary: Despite the lack of a standard definition, hedge funds offer a range of investment strategies and tools, including shorting and leverage, which grant managers flexibility but also pose investor risk. The dynamic nature of hedge funds provides a competitive advantage over more constrained investment vehicles, but can lead to confusion and risk for investors. To effectively evaluate an investment in hedge funds, investors must understand the strategy and associated risks, considering trade-offs in their portfolio.

site_title: Crowdtivate unveils first 12 crowdfunding projects
summary: Crowdtivate, a new crowdfunding platform launched by StarHub, unveiled its first 12 projects, selected from over 400 entries. The projects, including a smart watch hybrid and a wearable "smart panic button," aim to raise funds for production and manufacturing. Crowdtivate operates on a rewards-based model, with contributors receiving customized units or other rewards. The platform is designed to cater to specific Asian needs, with partnerships with Indonesian operators and organizations providing mentorship and consulting.

site_title: Swissco gets nod for Scott & English deal
summary: Swissco Holdings received approval from shareholders for its acquisition of privately owned Scott & English Energy for approximately S$285 million. The deal combines Swissco's expertise with Scott & English Energy's sourcing capabilities and industry connections, aiming to achieve operational synergies and a stable income stream. Swissco shareholders waived their rights to receive a general offer for shares not owned by Kim Seng Holdings, and a share consolidation was passed, allowing the company to trade on a consolidated basis starting July 23. The acquisition will result in the issuance of 452.4 million new shares.

site_title: Company Briefs
summary: INTRACO issues profit warning due to low trading margins, expecting a loss for the half year ended June 30. Sino Construction signs a conditional sale-and-purchase agreement to acquire a 52% stake in Jems Exploration Pty Ltd for US$20 million. China Powerplus' delisting offer becomes unconditional with 91.58% valid acceptances. GLP signs a new 15,000 sq m lease agreement with a leading Chinese retailer.

site_title: War-risk insurance market caught out
summary: Malaysia Airlines' two crashes in less than five months have sent shockwaves through the aviation insurance market, with estimated claims totaling US$600 million for war-risk insurance policies. The airline's US$2.25 billion overall liability policy lacks a standard clause limiting search-and-rescue costs, potentially leaving insurers liable for tens of millions of dollars. The absence of this clause is unusual, and its omission is unclear. The Malaysian and Australian governments are discussing sharing costs for the Flight 370 investigation and seeking insurance reimbursement.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: Joko Widodo, the Jakarta governor, won Indonesia's presidential poll. Sales of super sports cars decreased by 90% due to tax hikes and loan curbs. Equities are favored over other asset classes. Real estate developers expressed pessimism about the market. In Malaysia, car sales increased 9.2% in June, despite high household debt. The China food scandal is spreading, affecting firms like Starbucks and Burger King. A body of the Sewol ferry owner was found in South Korea. The Mercedes-Benz E-Class remains a popular model in Singapore.

site_title: More factors to consider in business travel
summary: A commercial airline was shot down near the Ukraine border, killing 298 people, raising concerns for employers about duty of care for business travelers. Employers have a legal and ethical obligation to ensure a safe working environment, including evaluating security conditions in destination countries. The incident may prompt travel departments to reassess their carriers' routes, particularly over war zones, areas of civil conflict, or regions of crisis. Airlines may be forced to reroute flights to avoid these areas, raising questions about the practicality of such changes.

site_title: Pteris part of larger plans, says CIMC
summary: China International Marine Containers (CIMC) plans to expand its airport logistics systems business through a reverse takeover deal with Singapore-listed Pteris Global. The deal, if approved, will see CIMC gain a controlling interest in Pteris. CIMC will acquire Tianda Group, the world's largest supplier of passenger boarding bridges, for S$137.6 million. CIMC believes Pteris' potential and sees synergies between the companies, with the goal of leveraging Tianda's brand and customer relationships to boost sales. The deal could potentially create a significant value if the companies were to merge.

site_title: Rising geopolitical risks may not dent asset prices
summary: Market players believe rising geopolitical risks won't dent asset prices, citing market confidence and steady macroeconomic backdrop. Fund managers, including Fidelity's Charles Payne and Citi's Mark Schofield, see opportunities in large-cap stocks, particularly in the oil and pharmaceutical sectors. They forecast 9-10% earnings per share growth in 2014 and 2015, with dividend yields seen as attractive if global growth remains slow. Despite geopolitical risks, market volatility is likely to drive asset prices higher.

site_title: Higher rental rates boost MIT's Q1 DPU
summary: MAPLETREE Industrial Trust (MIT) reported a 3.3% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.51 Singapore cents for its Q1 2014, driven by higher rental rates and a 6.3% increase in distributable income to S$42.8 million. Gross revenue rose 4.4% to S$78.4 million, while net property income climbed 8% to S$56.7 million. The Reit's average portfolio occupancy fell to 90.7% due to tenant relocation. MIT expects industrial market rents to remain stable or ease over the next six months.

site_title: Higher vehicle levies bad for both nations
summary: Malaysia plans to impose a levy on foreign-registered vehicles entering Johor state, with proposed fees ranging from RM20 to RM50 (S$7.80 to S$40), sparking concerns it's a retaliatory measure against Singapore. The move could deter Singaporeans from visiting Iskandar Malaysia, a development zone with improved facilities. The lack of public transport links between Singapore and Malaysia is also highlighted, with a Rapid Transit System link expected in 2018. This could exacerbate congestion at land checkpoints, emphasizing the need for better options.

site_title: World's 'largest indoor arena' opens in Manila
summary: The Philippine Arena, billed as the world's largest indoor stadium, opened in Manila with a seating capacity of 55,000. The US$175 million venue was inaugurated by President Benigno Aquino, who praised the Filipino people for achieving great heights. The arena is owned by the Iglesia ni Cristo (Church of Christ) sect and will host concerts, sports events, and gatherings for its members. The venue is seen as a major showcase for the Philippines, demonstrating its capabilities in hosting large-scale events.

site_title: Hard to beat the market all the time
summary: A new study by S&P Dow Jones Indices found that only two out of 2,862 mutual funds achieved top-quartile performance for five successive years, with 99.93% of funds failing the test. The study suggests that past performance does not guarantee future returns, and that a small number of active investors can achieve remarkable streaks, but consistently outperforming is rare. The findings support the case for index-fund investing, but also show that active managers can beat the market in certain cases.

site_title: MLT's Q1 DPU up on improved results
summary: MAPLETREE Logistics Trust (MLT) reported improved Q1 results, with available DPU rising 5.6% to 1.90 Singapore cents, driven by a 6% increase in distributable amount to S$46.6 million. Net property income rose 5.6% to S$69 million, boosted by a 7.4% increase in gross revenue to S$81 million, despite a 19% rise in property expenses.

site_title: Irrational markets ignore global trouble spots
summary: Global markets have largely ignored geopolitical tensions in Russia, Iran, Iraq, and Israel, despite the risks to growth, investment, and jobs. Economists warn that business uncertainty surrounding these issues could deter investment, while the US stock market remains overvalued. Analysts identify Russia and China as undervalued markets due to economic and market concerns. The US Federal Reserve's quantitative easing program has contributed to the rise in global markets, but uncertainty persists over its end. Sanctions against Russia are expected to escalate, while the Iran nuclear talks have been extended, but concerns remain about the country's nuclear capabilities.

site_title: Financiers look to the fields for their latest offering
summary: A group of investors, including Credit Suisse's Thomas Gimbel and the LeFrak real estate empire, are buying up US farms through a real estate investment trust (Reit) called American Farmland Co. The company, founded by D Dixon Boardman, has spent $131 million on 16 farms and over 4,450 hectares of tillable land. Hedge funds have invested $14 billion in farmland, and American Farmland aims to expand into a publicly traded company, offering ordinary investors a piece of the agricultural asset class.

site_title: Thai state carrier picked to undergo reform
summary: Thailand's military junta has selected Thai state carrier Thai Airways to undergo reform, with a focus on boosting services and then cost-cutting. The airline has struggled with four quarters of losses due to declining ticket sales and high operating costs. Air Chief Marshal Prajin, with little business experience, will chair a meeting on July 24 to consider a restructuring plan. The junta aims to separate politics from business and demonstrate its ability to manage the economy, but critics question Prajin's qualifications for the task.

site_title: Spackman thrills on debut while First Sponsor falls
summary: Spackman Entertainment Group, a Korean film production company, made a successful trading debut on the Catalist board, with its stock price rising 86.5% to 46.5 Singapore cents. In contrast, real estate firm First Sponsor Group fell below its IPO price, closing at S$1.44, down 3.67% from its opening price of S$1.47. The IPOs raised S$10.8 million and S$59.7 million, respectively. Spackman's Q2 2014 results are set to be released by September 13.

site_title: Being ready when things go wrong
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) conducted the Blue Dolphin 2014 exercise to test the readiness of agencies to respond to passenger vessel incidents in Singapore waters. The exercise simulated the evacuation of 700 passengers and crew members from a cruise ship, with over 1,000 staff from 21 agencies and companies participating. The scenario involved a fire in the engine room, and the exercise aimed to assess the preparedness and response to mass evacuation and transfer of persons at sea. The exercise highlights the need for exercises like this to ensure better survivability in the event of a disaster, and underscores the importance of contingency planning and international cooperation to minimize the risk of catastrophe.

site_title: London home prices fall in July for 2nd month
summary: London home prices fell 0.4% in July, marking the second consecutive month of decline, according to Rightmove plc. This decline was attributed to an increase in homes for sale, which softened the market for sellers. The average asking price in the UK capital fell to £587,174 (S$1.25 million), and across England and Wales, prices declined 0.8% for the first time since December.

site_title: Beleaguered MAS to present turnaround plan
summary: Malaysia Airlines (MAS) will present a turnaround plan to the government fund that controls it, Khazanah Nasional, amid the carrier's financial struggles following two recent disasters. The plan may include taking the company private or allowing it to go bankrupt, with the option of renegotiating union contracts. MAS has been plagued by losses and reputation damage, with the government estimating it only has enough funds to last a year. Analysts predict drastic measures, including selling new shares, to keep the airline afloat, and a decision on the plan is expected next month.

site_title: Jokowi wins presidential poll
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo has won the country's presidential poll with a vote tally of 53.15% of the total national vote. His rival, former special forces general Prabowo Subianto, has accepted defeat despite initial claims of "massive and systemic fraud." Prabowo's hopes of being a spoiler during Jokowi's first term are uncertain, with his seven-party coalition breaking apart. Jokowi's victory marks a move away from political dynasties, and he faces the challenge of healing a divided nation, which has experienced ethnic and religious tensions during the campaign.

site_title: Accordia Golf Trust units from S$0.97 each
summary: Accordia Golf Trust, a business trust owning golf courses in Japan, has launched its initial public offering (IPO) in Singapore to raise up to S$782 million. The trust is offering 782,025,000 new units at S$0.97-S$1 per unit, with 41,163,000 units available to Singapore public offering. The trust plans to distribute up to 9.1% of its distributable income annually, offering an attractive yield for investors. The IPO is the biggest on the Singapore Exchange this year, with a market capitalization of up to S$1.1 billion.

site_title: Asia airlines strive for return to mediocrity
summary: Airlines in South-east Asia, including Malaysia Airlines and Thai Airways, are striving for a return to mediocrity due to tragedy and political upheaval. The state shareholders of the two carriers are backing reform, but the region's oversupplied market and intense competition from low-cost carriers like AirAsia pose significant challenges. Restructuring options include delisting, asset sales, and equity partnerships, but cutting the bloated workforce is also crucial. Despite some airlines' success, forecasts indicate that many carriers, including Malaysia Airlines, will struggle to achieve profitability. A capital injection may be necessary for some airlines.

site_title: Key features of the new HQ
summary: Commonwealth Capital's food businesses will construct a new headquarters in Singapore, overseen by Commonwealth Food Services Pte Ltd. The building will feature a new auditorium and training venues for employees. This project aims to enhance the learning and on-the-job experience of trainees. The exact details of the construction and timeline are not mentioned in the article.

site_title: Vard nets 140m kroner in Q2 turnaround
summary: Singapore-listed Vard Holdings posted a net profit of 140 million kroner in Q2, reversing a net loss of 20 million kroner in the same period last year. Revenue fell 1.4% to 2.942 billion kroner, but the company delivered seven vessels and secured five new contracts, taking its order intake to 2.7 billion kroner. The company's cash and cash equivalents reached 1.8 billion kroner, and its order book stood at 21.6 billion kroner.

site_title: Focus on high-rise in Australia's housing boom
summary: Australia's housing market is experiencing a renaissance, driven by a shift towards high-rise apartments due to rising land costs, an ageing population, and foreign investment. The value of home building reached a four-year high in the first quarter, with 48,964 new homes started in the first quarter, up 22% from last year. However, construction of these high-rise apartments is a long process, taking up to three years to get approved, and may not be completed until 2019. This shift may temper the immediate benefits of the housing boom and keep interest rates low.

site_title: Scrutiny may go beyond 'retail' foreign banks
summary: Singapore's move to regulate and supervise "too big to fail" banks may not just target foreign lenders with a retail presence, but also their systemic importance and exposure to short-term funding. The country aims to ensure these banks hold enough liquid assets to cover short-term market shocks. Foreign banks, which hold 65% of all banking assets in Singapore, face scrutiny due to their large interbank funding and interconnectedness with other financial centers. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has set out requirements for these banks to subsidiarise and hold more capital, but some analysts argue that the measures may not be enough to target systemic vulnerabilities.

site_title: KepInfra Trust expects asset performance to stay stable
summary: KepInfra Trust reported a 13.4% decline in net profit to S$3.34 million for the second quarter, while revenue dropped 2% to S$16.43 million. Distribution per unit remained stable at 3.13 cents. The trustee-manager expects underlying asset performance to remain stable due to long-term concession agreements with Singapore statutory bodies. Net profit for the first half slipped 3.1% to S$6.84 million, while cash generated from operations increased 17.2% to S$26.94 million.

site_title: FrasersCom's Q3 DPU stays at 2.19 cts
summary: Frasers Commercial Trust (FCOT) reported a flat distribution per unit (DPU) of 2.19 Singapore cents for the third quarter, despite a 0.7% decline in net property income (NPI) due to lower Australian dollar and repair expenses. Singapore properties saw a 4.9% NPI growth, driven by improved performance in China Square Central. Occupancy rates remained strong at 98% across the portfolio. The Reit manager plans to focus on maintaining occupancy rates and managing expiring leases.

site_title: Halcyon Agri's 5-year bonds subscribed by 16 times
summary: Halcyon Agri Corp issued a $125 million 5-year bond that was subscribed 16 times, with orders exceeding $2 billion. The bonds were priced at 6.5%, down from initial guidance of 6.75%. Strong demand from private bank clients led to the lower price. The bond features a 2% step-up margin, increasing the coupon to 8.5% after the third year. This is Halcyon's first bond issuance and diversifies the Singapore dollar bond market, which has seen deals from real estate and marine sectors.

site_title: Q1 tourist arrivals stay flat on low China volumes
summary: Singapore's tourist arrivals remained flat in Q1 at 3.9 million, driven down by a 14% drop in Chinese visitors due to tourism laws implemented in October. Visitor arrivals from Indonesia rose 6%, while those from South Korea and Vietnam increased by 17% and 13% respectively. Tourism receipts edged up 5% to S$6 billion, with business and sightseeing segments contributing to the growth. Hotel room revenue rose 12% to S$0.8 billion, with luxury hotels posting the biggest gains in average room rate and revenue per available room.

site_title: Regulator plans new rules to shield investors
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has proposed new regulations to boost investor protection, particularly for investments linked to land banks, gold, and other physical assets. The regulations aim to shield retail investors from scams, including a recent land-banking bond scam. The MAS plans to classify land-banking investments as collectively managed investment schemes (CIS) and regulate gold buyback arrangements. Retail investors will also be required to be rated based on the complexity and risk of their investment products. Additionally, the MAS proposes to allow non-institutional investors to opt for accredited investor status, providing flexibility for investors to decide on the level of regulatory protection.

site_title: Iata and ICAO told to take lead in new protocols
summary: Dubai-based Emirates president Tim Clark calls for an international meeting of carriers to respond to the downing of a Malaysian airliner, citing regional instability and the need for new protocols. Clark suggests Iata and the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) take a lead in addressing the issue, potentially involving national regulators in giving airlines guidance on safe flying routes. Clark emphasizes the need for a unified response to prevent airlines from being targeted in regional conflicts, following the downing of MH17.

site_title: Shipping containers may provide affordable housing
summary: Architects in Washington, DC, are experimenting with repurposing shipping containers as affordable housing. The first of 18 containers will be stacked in a basement to create an experiment in creating eye-catching, affordable housing. The project, led by Matthew Grace and Sean Joiner, aims to determine if hundreds of thousands of discarded sea containers can help create more affordable housing. The containers will be used to build floating apartments on a barge in the Potomac River and a homeless village in Georgetown.

site_title: Company Briefs
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust has signed a memorandum of understanding to acquire Mapletree Zhengzhou Logistics Park in Henan, China, for 205.6 million renminbi. Hyflux plans to issue S$175 million worth of perpetual capital securities with an interest rate of 4.8%. Tee Land's net profit for Q4 2014 rose to S$5.6 million, driven by a share of associates results. mDR Limited has a three-year distribution agreement with Ooredoo Myanmar to distribute SIM cards and telecommunication services in Mandalay, Myanmar.

site_title: SMRT, SBS to be fined S$1.65m
summary: SMRT and SBS Transit will be fined S$1.65 million for service disruptions on the North-South and East-West Lines, and North-East Line, respectively. The penalties will be donated to the Public Transport Fund to help needy families with transport fares. The incidents occurred due to SMRT's failure to comply with procedures and processes, while an SBST incident was caused by a passenger's action. The LTA reported a decline in train service withdrawals across the network, with the number of withdrawals on the North-South and East-West Lines dropping to 1.3 per 100,000 train-km travelled.

site_title: Rebuilding MAS for the long haul
summary: Malaysia Airlines (MAS) faces a turning point in 2014 after two plane disasters and 537 lives lost. The airline, which was on shaky financial footing, is being pushed to renew itself. Khazanah Nasional aims to develop a revival plan within 6-12 months, following the loss of MH370 and amid financial struggles and compensation payouts. Despite a challenging year, MAS sees an opportunity for renewal, with the airline's 20,000 employees counting on it.

site_title: Kingsmen bags S$25.2m KidZania contract
summary: Kingsmen Creatives has secured a S$25.2 million contract to fit out KidZania Singapore, a children's indoor edu-tainment centre at Sentosa's Palawan Beach. The contract includes construction and maintenance of the attraction, expected to be completed by 2015. KidZania will feature a miniature city with 90 "pretend" businesses, teaching children about professions, financial literacy, and teamwork. Kingsmen's shares rose half a cent to close trading at S$0.92 following the announcement.

site_title: M1's Q2 profit up 12.1%
summary: M1's Q2 profit rose 12.1% to S$43.9 million, driven by a 13.3% decrease in cost of sales. Operating revenue slipped 2% to S$239.7 million, but service revenue inched up 0.8% to S$209 million. The telco's fibre customer base grew to 94,000, and mobile revenue increased 3.4% to S$167.9 million. M1 expects "moderate growth" in net profit after tax for 2014 and declared a cash interim dividend of seven Singapore cents per share.

site_title: Sembcorp Marine wins S$600m deal from French O&G company
summary: Sembcorp Marine has secured a S$600 million contract from French oil and gas company Saipem to convert two very large crude carriers into floating storage production offloading units for the Kaombo Project in offshore Angola. The project, valued at S$600 million, will take approximately 32 months to complete. This latest contract brings Sembcorp Marine's total new orders secured this year to S$2.53 billion, with no material impact expected on its earnings for the year ending Dec 31, 2014.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has proposed regulations for investments linked to physical assets such as land banks and gold. Geopolitical risks have increased, but markets are unlikely to fall. Q1 tourist arrivals to Singapore remained flat due to lower volumes from China. M1's Q2 profit increased by 12.1% and SMRT and SBS Transit will be fined for service disruptions. OCBC Bank is searching for a new event organiser for its OCBC Cycle event. Meanwhile, US companies are raising wages, and the head of Emirates airlines calls for an international meeting to address regional conflicts.

site_title: Downing of jet exposes defects of precautions
summary: A Malaysia Airlines Boeing 777-200 was shot down over eastern Ukraine, killing scores of passengers. The downing occurred despite airspace restrictions implemented by Russia and Ukraine in response to the conflict, which included closing airspace up to 32,000 feet along the planned route. The decision to restrict airspace rather than close it completely raises questions about the effectiveness of precautions taken to protect commercial aviation. The incident highlights the need for more stringent measures to ensure passenger safety.

site_title: Artist completes Singapore cityscape drawing
summary: British artist Stephen Wiltshire completed a detailed drawing of Singapore's cityscape in a public exhibition, commissioned by Singapore Press Holdings to mark its 30th anniversary. Wiltshire, 40, took a helicopter ride to get an aerial view and drew the cityscape from memory over four days, with the finished artwork measuring four meters by one meter. The piece, titled "See the Big Picture," will be presented to President Tony Tan as a gift to the nation to mark Singapore's 50th anniversary next year.

site_title: Marble producer launches IPO
summary: Terratech Group Limited, a Singapore-based marble producer, has launched an initial public offering (IPO) of 108.7 million shares at S$0.23 per share on the Catalist board of the Singapore Exchange, raising an estimated S$25 million. The company operates the Kelantan Marble Quarry in Malaysia, with an estimated 20.29 million cu m of resources and plans to expand production capacity and extract 230,000 cu m of dimension stone blocks by 2018, driven by China's expected 17.6% annual growth in marble consumption.

site_title: Boeing absent from crash scene
summary: Boeing has declined to send representatives to the crash site of Malaysian Airlines Flight 17, which was downed by a missile in eastern Ukraine. The company's absence is unusual due to the wartime situation. Instead, a team of investigators, including representatives from the US, UK, and Netherlands, are working with the Ukrainian government to study the incident. The team is focusing on airspace restrictions and the flight's history, and has not been allowed to access the crash site due to armed separatists.

site_title: Bodies placed in refrigerated rail wagons: workers
summary: Dozens of bodies from the Malaysian Airlines crash site in eastern Ukraine were placed in refrigerated rail wagons, sparking Western concern. The bodies were loaded into wagons at a station 15 km from the crash site and will be sent to an undisclosed location. The move has been criticized by the Dutch foreign minister, who described it as "dragging bodies around." The OSCE monitors accompanied armed rebels in checking the wagons, and the issue of what to do with the remains is still unresolved.

site_title: Best missile defence? Avoid war zones
summary: Airliners can only avoid missile attacks by staying out of conflict zones, as commercial jets lack suitable technology to defeat shoulder-fired missiles like the Buk system. Despite a US$239 million investment in upgrading commercial craft, fighter jets can evade high-altitude missiles with radar and rapid turns, but airliners cannot. Airlines are adding extra safety margins to routes over Ukraine and avoiding conflict zones, with regulators and trade groups saying they assess and mitigate risk through technology evaluation and route adjustments.

site_title: Chappati maker rolls out the dough
summary: A Singapore-based start-up, Zimplistic, has reportedly sold over 8,300 units of its automated chappati-making machine, the Rotimatic, in just one week, generating US$5 million in revenue. The device, priced at US$599 during pre-order, is set to retail for US$999 later this year. The company, co-founded by a husband-and-wife team, claims the Rotimatic is the first of its kind and aims to make the popular Indian staple accessible to anyone. The machine is set to be delivered early next year, with plans for expansion into India and other markets.

site_title: BRICS beating path to multi-polar financing
summary: The BRICS group of nations, consisting of Brazil, Russia, India, China, and South Africa, has launched a US$50 billion New Development Bank and a matching reserve fund, challenging US financial dominance and the US dollar-backed International Monetary Fund (IMF) and World Bank. The institutions aim to create a more multi-polar world financially, with an equal say for each member. The move is seen as a response to the IMF's "Washington Consensus" and the US dollar's use as a tool of foreign policy, with the goal of cutting dependence on the West and reducing the US's "exorbitant privilege" as owner of the world's reserve currency.

site_title: Angry Birds keeps Rovio's nest warm while it diversifies
summary: Finnish video game company Rovio Entertainment, the creator of Angry Birds, remains focused on its flagship game despite diversifying into new areas. The puzzle game has been downloaded over 2 billion times, and Rovio has launched other titles, such as Bad Piggies, to test new directions. The company plans to continue expanding the Angry Birds brand through new games, such as Angry Birds Stella, and licensing products like lunch boxes and toys. Rovio aims to learn from Disney's success in owning and growing multiple franchises, but for now, Angry Birds remains its core product.

site_title: Abu Dhabi bank's Q2 profit soars
summary: Abu Dhabi Islamic Bank (ADIB) posted a 22.5% jump in second-quarter net profit to 454.8 million dirhams, beating analysts' estimates. The bank cited a 13.9% increase in net revenue and improved asset quality as key drivers of the profit growth. ADIB's core business income boosted revenues, with loans extended by 15.4% year-on-year and deposits growing 18.2% over the same period. The lender's CEO attributed the record quarterly performance to the sustainable strength of its core banking businesses, despite legacy issues from the previous sovereign-related debt crisis.

site_title: Commercial cards have huge growth potential, especially in SME sector
summary: Singaporean banks see significant growth in commercial card usage, particularly among small and medium enterprises (SMEs). Despite low actual usage rates, banks expect double-digit growth in the take-up of commercial cards, with potential for corporate expenditure on these cards reaching US$200 billion. Banks such as Citibank, DBS, and UOB have introduced new commercial card offerings, including travel benefits and cost-saving rewards programs, to cater to SMEs' needs. Financial institutions remain optimistic about increasing usage of commercial cards among SMEs.

site_title: Cloud security a big concern for firms
summary: Cloud security remains a major concern for firms, with many chief information officers (CIOs) questioning the security of public cloud applications and data. A recent study by Forrester Research predicts the public cloud market will reach $191 billion by 2020, but security remains a top concern. Companies need to implement cloud platforms that co-exist with in-house legacy systems, and flexible procurement models to facilitate multi-year transition plans. Experts, such as Dimension Data CEO Bill Padfield, emphasize the need for organizations to develop skill sets, build governance models, and chart plans to bridge foundational gaps in cloud adoption.

site_title: Now bend it like an Asian
summary: Asian football teams can increase their chances of winning the World Cup by investing in youth development, creating a solid talent pipeline, and fostering a culture that loves and supports soccer. Countries like China, South Korea, Japan, and Australia have the potential to compete with European and South American teams, but it will require a long-term commitment and significant resources. The key to success lies in replicating the business ethos of Asian companies, such as Alibaba, which emphasizes clear goals, dedication, and collaborative efforts. It will take time, perseverance, and discipline for Asian teams to meet the exacting standards of play and eventually win the World Cup, with some predicting it could happen in 10 years or longer.

site_title: Cost of liabilities could reach US$1 billion
summary: The victims' families and countries of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 are likely to seek millions of dollars in reparations after the plane crash in Ukraine, with estimated payouts ranging from $50 million to $1 billion. Under the Montreal Convention, Malaysia Airlines is responsible for $150,000 per passenger, but countries will also demand successive payouts for economic and non-economic costs. The US, for example, may demand higher payouts, while China may offer lower amounts. The total cost of liabilities could reach $1 billion, with the carrier's reinsurer, Allianz, ultimately required to pay unless investigators determine responsibility for the missile attack.

site_title: STI clings to 52-week high as geopolitical worries hit markets
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index reached a new 52-week high of 3,310.53, despite a 3.64-point net rise, as geopolitical worries fueled market volatility. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 dropped due to news of the Malaysia Airlines crash and ongoing tensions in Ukraine and Gaza. United Overseas Bank and Jaya Holdings were among the notable movers, with UOB bouncing back and Jaya's shares falling. Non-oil domestic exports contracted 4.6% year-on-year, and analysts attributed the decline to overly optimistic expectations of global recovery.

site_title: O&M opens #ogilvychange practice in Singapore
summary: Ogilvy & Mather (O&M) has opened its #ogilvychange practice in Singapore, becoming the third city where the practice is available, after London and Prague. The practice utilizes cognitive psychology, social psychology, and behavioural economics to influence behavior and purchase decisions. Partnering with local universities, the practice aims to educate and experiment with new ways to "nudge" people into making better decisions. O&M Asia Pacific's Sonal Narain will oversee the practice, alongside co-founders Rory Sutherland and Jez Groom. The move aims to challenge traditional marketing models and provide more effective marketing strategies.

site_title: Serving up multiple brands
summary: Japan Foods, the group behind Japan-themed restaurants, is adapting to manpower shortages and rising rental costs by implementing cost-cutting measures. The company has introduced iPad ordering systems, expanded its central kitchen, and bought noodle machines to reduce expenses. This approach has helped reduce material costs from 21.7% in 2012 to 18.4% in 2014. The group has also successfully diversified its brands and leased spaces in shopping malls, increasing its negotiation power and reducing conversion costs. With a strong Singapore dollar and increased brand appeal, Japan Foods is poised for further expansion and growth.

site_title: IoT's success will hinge on data centres
summary: The Internet of Things (IoT) is poised to revolutionize daily life and work, with the Asia-Pacific market expected to reach $100 billion by 2020. As IoT devices generate vast amounts of data, powerful computers and big data analytics will be needed to process and analyze this data. Data security will be a primary concern, and organizations will need to develop tailored data centre strategies to manage and store IoT data, ensuring flexibility, scalability, security, availability, and connectivity.

site_title: PastaMania bulks up to be big food group
summary: Singapore-based Commonwealth Capital Pte Ltd, the owner of PastaMania, plans to integrate its warehouse, logistics, and manufacturing operations into a new S$70 million building by end-2015. The company aims to create an end-to-end business model, expanding its food business to include retail concepts, manufacturing, and logistics services. The new headquarters will house 300 production staff and 100 non-production employees, featuring advanced automation systems and a research and development laboratory. The company projects revenue of S$100 million for 2014 and aims to list on overseas exchanges to expand its international presence.

site_title: Going beyond just 'keeping the lights on'
summary: A global survey by Avanade found that 40% of IT staff spend time managing legacy systems, hindering innovation. Business leaders believe they can make better decisions without IT, with 86% saying they can make decisions without involving the department. However, 86% of businesses are open to IT staff taking a more business-oriented role, and 69% plan to expand IT's role to become a business adviser. To address this, IT departments should partner with external service providers and position themselves as sources of new business tools.

site_title: Ascott Reit's post-rights Q2 DPU falls to 2.19 cts
summary: Ascott Reit's second-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) fell 11% to 2.19 Singapore cents due to a dilution from a one-for-five rights issue. Despite this, the Reit's DPU for the first half of the year is 3.94 Singapore cents, and it expects contributions from new properties to boost its full-year performance. The Reit's revenue and gross profit rose 14% and 14% respectively, driven by contributions from new properties and existing ones. However, the Reit's Singapore market revenue fell 10%, while its Australian market revenue declined 8%.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: Singapore banks' expansion into regional markets may be overrated, given the experience of multinational banks following the 2008 crisis. Meanwhile, Malaysia Airlines is struggling after two plane disasters, and Japan Foods is expanding its food conglomerate. C&W is ramping up growth in its Asia-Pacific business, while Crestar Education Group is setting up a 6 million yuan pre-school in China. Reclamation works may hinder PTP's berth expansion, and India's position on a global trade deal is putting it in jeopardy.

site_title: WE Holdings sells unit for S$8.4m
summary: WE Holdings sold its main components distribution business to Jubilee Industries Holdings for US$8.4 million, a 26% premium over its net tangible asset value. The sale excludes Ubi property units and excludes revenue from the electronics components distribution business, which generated US$52 million in revenue. WE Holdings will now focus on its commodities business, awaiting final approval for a Myanmar cement business purchase and starting iron ore trading.

site_title: C&W to ramp up growth of its Asia-Pac business
summary: Cushman & Wakefield (C&W) plans to expand its Asia-Pacific business, following a 50% increase in regional headcount to 3,600 over the last four years. The commercial real estate services firm aims to double its Asia-Pacific revenue in the next four to five years, driven by growing demand from occupier clients expanding into the region. C&W will continue to evaluate potential targets and new markets, with a focus on creating depth in its existing offices and acquiring quality talent. The Asia-Pacific region is expected to continue its growth, driven by a growing middle class and economies such as China, India, and Indonesia.

site_title: Amundi triples Asian electronic forex trading volume in 2 years
summary: Amundi Asset Management has tripled its electronic foreign-exchange trading volume in Asia over the past two years, conducting 70% of its currency transactions electronically. The company oversees $1 trillion in global trading, citing efficiency and transparency as the main advantages of electronic trading. Amid investigations into potential market manipulation, Amundi prioritizes client interests and avoids trading at fixed times to maintain competition. This move comes as foreign-exchange traders face their biggest-ever loss due to volatility and decreased trading volumes.

site_title: Here's how to create an effective authority grid
summary: A company's authority grid is a document outlining the decision-making authorities for various matters, such as long-term strategic plans and capital expenditures. This grid, typically a matrix, lists approval authorities (CEO, chairman, committees, and full board) in one column and matters for approval in another. The grid can include nuances like "endorse," "concur," and "recommend" to clarify approval processes. Companies should regularly review and update the grid with the board's final approval, and make it accessible to senior managers and board members to ensure efficient decision-making and avoid conflict.

site_title: Buying activity plunges
summary: Buying activity on the Singapore Exchange decreased, with 12 companies making purchases worth S$1.9 million, down from S$4.4 million in the previous week. Selling activity among directors remained low, with five companies disposing of shares worth S$4.2 million. Notable director trades included ABR Holdings' managing director Ang Yee Lim purchasing 127,000 shares, and chairman Chen Qiuhai of Yamada Green Resources buying 200,000 shares. Other companies with significant director trades included Roxy-Pacific Holdings, Yanlord Land, and IFS Capital. Overall, the buying activity plunged, while selling activity remained low, suggesting that investor confidence remains cautious.

site_title: Airlines redraw flight paths to steer clear of Ukraine
summary: Airlines in the Asia-Pacific region have re-routed flight paths to avoid Ukrainian airspace following the downing of Malaysia Airlines Flight MH17, which killed 298 people. The change in flight paths could result in flight delays and additional fuel costs, with Thai Airways expecting delays of up to half an hour. Analysts predict that the tragedy may lead to lower tourist arrivals from Europe to South-east Asia, with some carriers suspending flights to certain destinations due to safety concerns.

site_title: S'pore banks' regional expansion overrated?
summary: Singapore banks' regional expansion may not be as lucrative as initially thought, given the experience of multinational banks from the 2008 financial crisis. Despite stepping into the gaps left by European banks, their regional expansion may not yield substantial returns. A saturated local market and economic uncertainty due to US tariffs and trade tensions also pose challenges. As a result, Singapore lenders may need to reassess their regional expansion strategies to ensure their long-term success.

site_title: Slicker city
summary: The new Honda City is a small family sedan with surprisingly good performance, despite its unappealing design. The fourth-generation City features a new platform, Earth Dreams CVT transmission, and electric power steering, which combine for a responsive and fun driving experience. The 1.5-liter naturally aspirated engine produces 120 horsepower, and the CVT allows for direct acceleration and smoother shifts. The car also boasts a range of safety features, including Vehicle Stability Assist and motion-adaptive EPS. With a starting price of $109,999, the City offers impressive performance and economy, making it a great value for its price.

site_title: Quietly safe, easy-going Thai cuisine
summary: Soi 60, a modern Thai restaurant in Singapore, offers tame and civilized Thai cuisine, reminiscent of a walk in the Botanic Gardens. Chef Martin Goetz's recipes, inspired by his Australian roots, showcase the complexity of Thai flavors without extreme boldness. Highlights include a luxurious miang kham starter, a well-balanced papaya salad, and a tender beef short rib dish. However, dishes like tom yum soup and mango sticky rice fall short. Overall, Soi 60 is a safe, yet pleasant, dining experience, but lacks the jolt of authentic Thai flavors. Rating: 6/10.

site_title: China Fishery ratings unchanged by Copeinca bond amendments
summary: China Fishery Group's current BB- rating with a negative outlook remains unchanged after its US$250 million 9% Copeinca senior notes due 2017 amendment. The proposed amendments allow Copeinca to guarantee up to US$1.2 billion of China Fishery's debts, paving the way for consolidation of its Peru operations. Fitch Ratings expects no material developments to lead to a ratings upgrade due to high debt to earnings ratios and volatile fleet performances. The rating agency also notes that the proposed amendments will not change key business terms like interest rates or maturity dates.

site_title: Focus on compliance hurting performance
summary: A new study by Heidrick & Struggles' Asia-Pacific Corporate Governance Report 2014 found that a heavy focus on compliance may be hindering the performance of boards in Singapore and the region. The report, which surveyed 170 publicly listed companies and over 165 board members, highlighted that high-performing boards prioritize capabilities such as people, leadership, vision, and innovation. Singapore boards, in particular, were found to have the fewest meetings and lack improvement in gender mix, with only 6.3% female representation. The report concluded that a common culture and strong bond among directors are key to effective boards.

site_title: Jacks of all trades, masters of none?
summary: Large global banks are struggling to maintain a universal banking model in Asia due to rising cost pressures and regulations. Despite this, many still believe in the model's merits, citing access to the region's growing wealth. However, the model's viability is being challenged by increasing negative synergies between investment and retail banking, and the need for banks to operate as subsidiaries rather than branches. As a result, some banks, such as Standard Chartered and HSBC, have exited or scaled back certain businesses in Asia, while others, like Citigroup, remain committed to the model, citing the need for global banking partners to cater to emerging affluent consumers.

site_title: Roll call
summary: News outlets in Singapore have conducted a taste test of lobster rolls at nine different restaurants, with Pince and Pints and The Market Grill standing out for their generous portions and high-quality lobster meat. The Cajun Kings offered the best value for money, while The Dancing Crab and Platypus Lobster Shack provided affordable options. Other restaurants, such as Luke's Oyster Bar and Chop House and The Pelican, fell short due to inconsistent quality and overcooking. The cheapest option, Boston Seafood Shack, was criticized for using a mix of lobster and crayfish.

site_title: Show & sell
summary: British expatriate Millie Heath has transformed her two-storey shophouse in Singapore into a unique home, showcasing her clients the lighting in situ while also making it her own. She has mixed pieces from boutique stores, bigger retailers, and overseas purchases, creating a lively and cosy space. Heath, who works for British lighting brand Vaughan, displays some of their pieces in the home to give clients an idea of how the lamps look in situ. The home features a mix of decorative lighting, colourful cushions, and personal touches, reflecting Heath's love for creating something different.

site_title: Accused changes tune, says he played role in church affairs
summary: City Harvest Church member John Lam has admitted to being involved in every major decision of the church, contradicting his lawyer's earlier statement. Lam faced questioning over his involvement with companies like Xtron Productions, which managed Sun Ho's career and the church's evangelical effort. Prosecutors produced documents showing CHC's control over these companies, challenging Lam's claim of independence. Lam also admitted to being involved in transactions totaling S$50.6 million, which he claimed were for the church's benefit. The trial continues on August 4.

site_title: Flower power
summary: Japanese landscape architect Jun-ichi Inada is creating a 3D orchid display at the Singapore Garden Festival, featuring 18,000 orchid plants in a 5m by 10m high tower. Inada views plants as "interpreters of the day's weather" and believes that landscaping is about balance, proportion, sustainability, and creating a sense of drama. He aims to bring nature to the urban environment and has worked on various projects, including the redevelopment of Singapore's Botanic Gardens and the National Orchid Garden. Inada's design philosophy emphasizes the importance of individual needs and qualitative achievements in urban planning.

site_title: Shanghai bourse's int'l board shelved
summary: The Shanghai Stock Exchange's international board, which would allow foreign companies to list on the mainland, has been put on hold due to China's focus on reforming its IPO and listing regime for domestic shares. Reforms aim to liberalize the domestic listing regime and increase market openness, with potential benefits including a boost to the A-share market and the introduction of listed real estate investment trusts. China has already lifted a 14-month moratorium on initial public offerings and has seen 52 IPOs raise 35 billion yuan in the first half of the year, with projections for 100 more IPOs in the second half.

site_title: Google may turn NY pay phones into Wi-Fi spots
summary: Google is considering a plan to convert New York City's pay phones into Wi-Fi spots, providing free wireless Internet access to residents. The proposal, which is part of Google's efforts to increase digital access, would see new designs installed in pay phones, offering Wi-Fi, phone services, and advertising. Bids for the project are due, with companies including Cisco Systems, IBM, and Samsung participating in the proposal. The project aims to provide access to over 7,300 pay phones in the city's densely trafficked corridors, with revenue generated by advertising on their side panels.

site_title: World leaders call for probe into crash of airliner
summary: World leaders demand an international investigation into the downing of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17, which killed 298 people, amid blame-shifting between Ukraine and Russia. US officials suspect Ukrainian separatists backed by Moscow fired a surface-to-air missile. The US calls for an immediate ceasefire, while pro-Russian separatists claim they will ensure safe access for international experts. The tragedy stokes tensions between Russia and the West, with the Netherlands declaring a day of national mourning for its 154 dead.

site_title: MAS reels from body blow
summary: Malaysia Airlines (MAS) has suffered its second major air disaster in just five months after its Flight MH17 was shot down in Ukrainian airspace, killing all 298 people on board. The incident has led the government to demand the airline produce a turnaround plan within a week, with industry sources suggesting a "reset plan" is needed. The airline's financial woes have worsened, with shares losing 17% since March, and a new board and management team may be considered to help the carrier recover. The incident has sparked a tug of war between Russia and Ukraine, with concerns over the black box recording device.

site_title: No preferential treatment for Chinese banks
summary: Foreign banks in Singapore's Shanghai Free Trade Zone (SFTZ) must align their systems with the People's Bank of China (PBOC) to obtain trade account approvals. Unlike Chinese banks, foreign banks have not yet received approval due to system incompatibility. This requirement was likely the reason for Chinese banks' earlier approval for their Shanghai FTZ trade accounts. The approval process highlights the importance of system compatibility for foreign banks operating in the SFTZ.

site_title: Business briefing
summary: Spackman Entertainment Group's initial public offering (IPO) placement shares were fully subscribed with 69,440,000 shares sold at 26 Singapore cents. The shares are expected to start trading on the Catalist Board of the Singapore Exchange on Tuesday. In related news, SATS reported a 2.5% increase in flights handled, a 1.6% growth in unit services, and a 4.9% increase in cargo throughput in the April-June fiscal first quarter.

site_title: TCM's luxe and modern take
summary: TCM practitioner Mark Chern has opened a new world of treatment options at Como Shambala Urban Escape, offering a luxe and modern take on traditional Chinese medicine. Chern, who trained in Taiwan and China, provides holistic treatments such as acupuncture, cupping, and visceral manipulation to address hormonal imbalance issues, pain, and stress. His "Balanced Body Approach" aims to realign the body and promote overall well-being, making TCM more accessible and appealing to those who previously viewed it as a less-than-inviting environment.

site_title: Company Briefs
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore has approved Alibaba's acquisition of a stake in SingPost. CapitaMalls Asia will be delisted from the Singapore and Hong Kong exchanges on July 22. TEE International secured $57 million worth of engineering contracts in Singapore. Meanwhile, NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed.

site_title: OCBC warned of painful Wing Hang restructuring
summary: OCBC Bank is warned by Macquarie to reconsider its proposed acquisition of Wing Hang Bank due to potential risks of significant goodwill impairment and material pressure on its capital ratio. The acquisition is seen as a replay of DBS's acquisition of Dao Heng Bank, which resulted in a significant write-off and impairment of goodwill. Macquarie notes that Wing Hang will remain sub-scale in Hong Kong and revenue synergies will be harder to reap than cost savings, making the deal expensive for OCBC.

site_title: Chew again grills Lam on 'false' evidence
summary: Former City Harvest Church board member Chew Eng Han continues to challenge current board member John Lam's testimony during his cross-examination, questioning the accuracy of Lam's assertions about key investment decisions. Chew claims Lam's evidence is "totally false" on several occasions, specifically regarding the church's $21.5 million investment in Xtron Productions bonds. Lam admits to having no access to emails or documentation at the time of his initial CAD statement, but claims his state of mind has changed after reviewing new evidence. The hearing continues with the prosecution's cross-examination of Lam.

site_title: Tiered data plans, fibre broadband revenue closely watched
summary: Singapore's telco sector is closely watching tiered data plan adoption, with the proportion expected to reach 70% by year-end. Analysts expect the rate of conversion to be crucial, as StarHub's new 4G speed charge may discourage postpaid subscribers from switching. The iPhone 6 release in September may also drive migration to tiered plans. Meanwhile, fibre broadband revenue is expected to dip further, with new players entering the market. Despite a potential fourth telco, industry watchers remain optimistic, with Maybank Kim Eng Research maintaining its "overweight" rating on the telco sector.

site_title: Lobster on a roll
summary: New England-style lobster rolls are trending in Singapore, with three-hour queues reported at Pince and Pints, a lobster-only eatery. The luxury snack, consisting of cold mayonnaise-coated lobster meat chunks in a butter-griddled hot dog bun, was initially not popular but has gained widespread acceptance. Chefs attribute the trend to the perception of lobster as a premium product and the convenience of having them already shelled in a roll format. Lower lobster prices due to increased demand have also made it accessible to the masses.

site_title: Asia-Pac airlines close weaker
summary: Asian-Pacific airlines closed slightly lower on July 17, 2014, following the downing of Malaysia Airlines flight MH17 in eastern Ukraine. Malaysia Airlines' stock fell 2.5 sen to 20 sen, while Singapore Airlines, Cathay Pacific, and Japan Airlines also declined. However, Qantas Airways bucked the trend, gaining one Australian cent to close at A$1.25. The decline was attributed to concerns over the Ukraine conflict and the Israeli ground offensive in Gaza, which added to market volatility.

site_title: Google taps mobile; Q2 revenue up
summary: Google posted its 18th consecutive quarter of 20%+ revenue growth, with Q2 revenue rising 22% to $15.96 billion, beating analyst estimates. The company's core search, YouTube, and product-listing ads drove three times more mobile traffic for merchants compared to last year. Analysts believe Google is well-positioned to benefit from the shift to mobile and wearables, with some raising their price targets by up to $75 to $745. The stock has risen 26% in the past year and is expected to benefit from the "Internet of things" and Android's popularity.

site_title: Cheong Choong Kong to retire as OCBC Bank chairman
summary: OCBC Bank's chairman, Cheong Choong Kong, will retire on August 31 after 11 years, succeeded by Malaysian Ooi Sang Kuang. Ooi, a former deputy governor of Bank Negara Malaysia, will provide continuity as a director. During his tenure, OCBC Bank implemented strategic initiatives, strengthened its balance sheet, and achieved significant growth, becoming one of the world's best-capitalized banks. Ooi, who joined OCBC's board in 2012, has a wealth of financial experience and is seen as a stable choice to lead the bank.

site_title: Semi-permanent beauty
summary: Semi-permanent beauty treatments, such as eyebrow embroidery and hair removal, are gaining popularity among time-strapped women. Chains like Erabelle and Browhaus have seen significant increases in revenue, with some customers opting for permanent treatments like Intense Pulsed Light (IPL) hair removal. While these treatments offer convenience and natural-looking results, there is a higher risk involved due to the long-term effects and varying hygiene and safety levels. Experts recommend researching and choosing reputable salons and brands to minimize the risk of undesirable results.

site_title: BSI Bank ready to samba under new Brazilian owner
summary: BSI Bank, a 140-year-old Swiss bank, has been acquired by Brazilian investment bank BTG Pactual for 1.5 billion Swiss francs (S$2.07 billion). The deal marks a significant milestone for BSI, which will now "make a huge leap forward" as a midfield private bank player, according to its CEO Hanspeter Brunner. The acquisition is expected to bring new energy to the bank under its new Brazilian owner.

site_title: Strong China-Singapore links go beyond trade: PM
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized that the bilateral relationship with China extends beyond trade, citing the 2.3 million Chinese visitors to Singapore annually and joint projects such as the Suzhou Industrial Park. He also highlighted the free trade agreement between the two countries, which has promoted liberalized trade since its entry into force in 2009. Lee expressed confidence in continued cooperation and noted that China is not yet ready to join the Trans-Pacific Partnership negotiations, but may consider it in the future.

site_title: Co-work operations
summary: Two new co-working spaces in Singapore cater to women and artists, respectively. Woolf Works, a women-only space, offers 1,400 sq ft of office and communal areas, including a library and meeting room, at rates starting from S$500 for five permanent desks. Art Social Haus, an art-centric space, provides 1,000 sq ft of workspace with communal facilities and a focus on community and networking. The Tool Room, a co-working space, features ergonomic workstations, a bar, and a napping loft, with membership rates starting from S$650. The Cub, an incubator space, offers a large oval meeting table to budding entrepreneurs who pitch their business ideas to venture capitalist Joel Sng.

site_title: Asia business travel outlook remains cloudy
summary: The Asia business travel outlook remains uncertain due to a slowing Chinese economy, despite a 6.5% year-on-year growth in global premium travel in May. The Far East posted a 2.5% growth, while other markets like the North Atlantic and Middle East experienced double-digit growth. The International Air Transport Association (Iata) attributes the growth to stronger global business activity, but notes that trade indicators are mixed and export orders have fluctuated.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports fell for a second month, hindering hopes of a trade recovery. Microsoft is set to cut up to 18,000 jobs as it transforms into a cloud-computing software company. Indonesian presidential election candidate Joko Widodo is increasingly likely to win, while BSI Bank, a Swiss bank, is set to be sold to Brazilian owners. Retail investors in Singapore remain confident about market prospects, and new listings on SGX have fueled hope for the market operator. US sanctions have been imposed on Russia, and airline chiefs are optimistic about industry revenues.

site_title: CDLHT tops year-to-date gains by stapled trusts
summary: CDL Hospitality Trusts (CDLHT) has topped year-to-date gains among stapled trusts in Singapore, with an 11.8% total return. The trust's portfolio includes 12 hotels and two resorts valued at over S$2 billion. CDLHT's price return has averaged 4.8% and its total return has averaged 8.3% for the year to date. The top three-performing trusts include CDLHT, Far East Hospitality Trust, and Ascendas Hospitality Trust, with an average indicative dividend yield of 7.2%.

site_title: ADB trims S-E Asia growth forecast for this year to 4.7%
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has trimmed its growth forecast for South-East Asia to 4.7% for 2014, down from 5% previously, citing country-specific factors in Indonesia, Thailand, and Vietnam. However, growth in emerging economies is still forecast to reach 6.2% in 2014 and 6.4% in 2015. China's growth is expected to moderate but still reach 7.5% in 2014 and 7.4% in 2015, while India's growth forecast is maintained at 5.5% in 2014 and upgraded to 6.3% in 2015. Japan's growth is forecast at 1.5% in 2014, up from 1.3% previously.

site_title: Cultural Matching Fund draws S$10m
