summary: Boeing's commercial aircraft division head, Raymond Conner, expressed optimism that the US Congress will reauthorise funding to the Export-Import Bank, which guarantees loans to foreign buyers of its airplanes. Failure to do so could risk American jobs and give Airbus an unfair advantage. The bank's opponents argue that the guarantees give foreign rivals an unfair cost advantage, but Conner claims eliminating US loan guarantees would not protect American carriers from foreign competition. The bank's authorisation is set to expire in September, amid a political battle over the bank's future.

site_title: Economists query semicon output fall in Q2
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector experienced a sharp contraction in Q2 due to a sharp decline in electronics output. Economists are seeking more clarity on the "firm-specific factor" behind the April production cutback by an unnamed semiconductor player. The decline is expected to linger, affecting Q2 GDP growth, and economists want more information to gauge the sector's future performance. The Economic Development Board (EDB) had initially stated that the decline would be a one-off event, but economists want more details to better understand the impact on the broader economy.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: Traditional retailers struggle to adapt to e-commerce, despite growing digital presence. China's liquidity crisis presents opportunities for private equity funds. BRICS nations plan to launch a $50 billion infrastructure bank and a contingency fund. A new URA policy in Singapore may reduce demand for shophouses. Apple denies iPhone software poses a security risk, while regulatory scrutiny of dark pools may boost market volumes. Fears of a renewed eurozone crisis and Greece's non-performing loans are also concerns.

site_title: Jubilee to widen scope of electronics business
summary: Jubilee Industries Holdings, a Catalist-listed company, is set to expand its electronics business by acquiring 26% of Malaysia-listed electronics manufacturer EG Industries and WE Holdings' electronics component distribution business. The deal will give Jubilee control over purchasing and R&D functions at EG Industries. Jubilee's revenue is expected to be boosted from its acquisition of WE Holdings' electronics business and provision of plastic injection moulding services for EG's products. The company aims to become a "one-stop electronics solution provider" after the acquisition.

site_title: Crossover Project had to 'appear as independent'
summary: A Singapore court hearing for six members of City Harvest Church (CHC) began, with CHC board member John Lam testifying that the church's evangelical project, Crossover Project, had to appear independent to be successful. Lam stated that CHC's investments in the project, including $21.5 million in Xtron bonds, were kept secret from the public. The prosecution claims the church misappropriated $24 million to finance Sun Ho's music career, while using entities like Xtron to cover their alleged misappropriation. The church's defense argues that the project was a standalone effort and that Lam's involvement was minor.

site_title: Getting the right site
summary: International manufacturers are considering emerging markets such as Myanmar, Vietnam, and Cambodia for their next factory due to growth and expansion opportunities. However, key factors include ease of doing business, supporting infrastructure, technology availability, and political stability. Experts believe that China will eventually lose its status as the world's factory due to rising labor costs and changing consumer demands. New manufacturing sites are emerging in Vietnam, Cambodia, and Bangladesh, but these markets may not be the final destinations. Long-term productivity and effectiveness are crucial for a country to remain competitive in terms of stability, quality, and price.

site_title: Google seeks to dismiss antitrust suit against Android
summary: Google has filed a motion to dismiss an antitrust lawsuit targeting its Android operating system, arguing that smartphone manufacturers are free to use Android without installing Google apps. The lawsuit, filed by two customers, claims Google forces phone manufacturers to set its search engine as default, giving it an unfair advantage in the market. Google says its conduct promotes lawful competition and that consumers can customize their phones to replace the default search engine. A hearing on the motion is scheduled for October.

site_title: IBM to spend US$3b on computer chip development
summary: IBM plans to spend $3 billion over five years on research and development for computer chips, aiming to push the frontiers of chip technology and accelerate progress on novel approaches. The effort will focus on shrinking existing chip technology and exploring new designs inspired by quantum physics, carbon nanotubes, and brain-inspired chips. This move is part of IBM's strategy to invest heavily in research, pursue licensing revenue, and outsource manufacturing to others, including potential buyer GlobalFoundries.

site_title: Italian fine dining off to rousing start
summary: Italian chef Alessandro Frau has opened a new restaurant, Alba 1836 Winebar & Restaurant, in Duxton Hill, replicating his signature fine dining cuisine. This marks the first time his restaurant has expanded outside of Phuket. The new location aims to bring high-quality Italian dining to a new audience in Singapore.

site_title: Embraer to unveil 25-jet China deal during Xi visit
summary: Brazil will announce a deal to sell about 25 Embraer planes to Chinese airlines during a visit by China's President Xi Jinping. The aircraft sale and cooperation in infrastructure projects, such as railways, will be part of a series of agreements. Embraer is also expected to refit its regional jet plant in Harbin to produce the Legacy 650 business jet. The visit coincides with the launch of a development bank and emergency reserves fund for the Brics nations.

site_title: Tighter liquidity in China opens door for PE funds
summary: Forum Partners, a US-based private equity firm, is optimistic about investing in China's property market despite recent defaults by some developers. The firm plans to invest an additional US$100 million in Chinese developers over the next 6-9 months, targeting returns of around 20%. Forum Partners believes the cooling measures in China's property market are cyclical, not structural, and will pick up again in the next 6-18 months. The firm is also banking on a surge in developer demand for funding, particularly in first-tier cities like Beijing and Shanghai.

site_title: Farnborough airshow may see a slowdown in orders
summary: Aircraft makers are expecting robust passenger plane sales, with manufacturers having "order books equal to more than eight years of plane production," according to Alain Guillot at AlixPartners. However, the Farnborough airshow may see a slowdown in orders compared to previous record years. Airbus is set to launch an upgrade of its A330 jet at the event, but the industry is not threatened. Despite this, experts note that manufacturers are still optimistic about the market, with Delta Air Lines offering an upbeat outlook on travel demand and lifting shares.

site_title: Building firm takes on the glitz
summary: KOP Limited, a Singaporean developer, has ventured into the entertainment industry with the acquisition of Scorpio East, a company with expertise in movie productions, concerts, and video entertainment. The move aims to create large entertainment-driven, mixed-use developments in key Chinese cities. KOP's CEO, Ong Chih Ching, believes that the company's brand identity and premium offerings will enable it to make more money and compete in the market. The company has also acquired a majority stake in US-based Victory Hill Exhibitions, which will provide interactive exhibitions based on blockbusters.

site_title: Old-school retail grapples with new tricks of e-commerce
summary: Traditional retailers in Singapore are struggling to adapt to the rise of e-commerce, requiring significant changes to logistics and inventory control. Despite online players' encouraging growth, shoppers still prefer to physically touch and examine products before buying. Retailers face a chicken-and-egg situation, where they need to invest in online capabilities to attract online shoppers, but online players require a large customer base to justify such investments. To overcome this, online players are focusing on creating a seamless online-to-offline experience, and physical retailers are exploring ways to integrate e-commerce into their businesses.

site_title: Toshiba releases first mobile workstation
summary: Toshiba has released its first mobile workstation, the Tecra W50, designed for professionals requiring high-performance and high-end graphics capabilities. The device features a 15.6-inch full HD display, Intel Core i7 processor, and dedicated Nvidia Quadro K2100M graphics card. Weighing under 2.7kg, the Tecra W50 offers enhanced security, enterprise-focused features, and a built-in optical drive. With options for SSD, HDD, or a hybrid, the system is equipped with Trusted Platform Module and Intel Active Management Technology for remote monitoring and security.

site_title: HP eyes growth with service and innovation
summary: Hewlett-Packard (HP) is confident it has turned the corner in devices sales, with global PC shipments growing 0.1% in the second quarter of 2014, despite a 9.5% decline in Asia-Pacific. The company attributes this growth to its end-to-end solutions and services offering, as well as its partner network. HP Asia-Pacific and Japan's senior VP, Nick Lazaridis, notes that the company has caught up with Lenovo, its main competitor, and is now focusing on offering solutions for big data, cloud, and security.

site_title: Brick-and-mortar with its back against the wall
summary: Retailers in Singapore face significant challenges, including rising rentals and a labor shortage, forcing them to regroup and adapt. Some, like FJ Benjamin and Aspial, are closing underperforming stores and downsizing others to reduce costs. Others, like Sheng Siong and Challenger Technologies, are investing in technology to boost productivity and are expanding their online presence to compete with pure-play online grocers. The trend suggests that brick-and-mortar stores may need to evolve to survive in a market dominated by online shopping.

site_title: Firms should use security tools from various vendors
summary: A senior security executive at Symantec advises firms to use a variety of security products from different vendors to protect against cybercrime and espionage. Companies should be aware of multiple intrusion points and use a heterogeneous defense strategy to address diverse threats, including mobile devices and advanced persistent threats (APTs). APTs are sophisticated attacks that can infiltrate company defenses and stay undetected for extended periods. To combat APTs, companies need to overhaul their security processes and monitor day-to-day residual risks for suspicious activity, including data loss prevention.

site_title: Is traditional fashion retail going out of style?
summary: Traditional fashion retail in Singapore is struggling due to rising rents, manpower costs, and increased competition from online shopping. The apparel segment shrank to 2,576 establishments in 2012, despite other retail categories growing. The labor crunch has led to reduced revenue, as salespeople can no longer upsell accessories or clothing items. The proliferation of international fashion brands has also diminished Singapore's status as a regional fashion destination. Online shopping, particularly on platforms like Alibaba's Tmall, is taking a significant toll on clothing retailers, with some announcing store closures.

site_title: Week to shed light on whether consumers can sustain spending
summary: US stocks are expected to shed light on whether consumers can sustain spending, with key data this week including a wholesale inflation index, congressional testimony from Fed chair Janet Yellen, and second-quarter earnings reports. Despite some promising signs, economists warn that consumers may struggle to keep spending if prices rise faster than wages. A modest 2% rise in average wages reported by the Labour Department for June and strong operating earnings from Alcoa and Wells Fargo may indicate a strengthening jobs market translating into wage growth.

site_title: Two coaches with very contrasting fortunes
summary: Brazil's coach Luis Felipe Scolari criticized his team's performance after a 3-1 loss to the Netherlands, but his team's collapse was more a testament to the Dutch's dominance. Robin van Persie and Arjen Robben scored early goals, and the Dutch defense held strong. The loss marks a disappointing end to Scolari's tenure, with his future as Brazil's coach uncertain. In contrast, Netherlands' coach Louis van Gaal is celebrated for his team's undefeated run and will be feted in a heroes' welcome upon his return to Amsterdam.

site_title: Regulation by law or the Code?
summary: The US and UK have different approaches to regulating corporate governance, with the UK adopting a "comply or explain" code-based approach and the US relying on legislation and penalties. The UK's Corporate Governance Code sets out best practices, while the US Sarbanes-Oxley Act makes internal control a board's direct responsibility. Both approaches have their strengths and weaknesses, with the US providing a level playing field but lacking flexibility, and the UK's approach offering more leeway but requiring vigilant enforcement. Singapore has adopted a balanced approach, combining legislated core rules with a code-based "comply or explain" requirement.

site_title: New businesses bounce to Dunlop Street
summary: New businesses are emerging on Dunlop Street in Singapore, adding to the street's vibrant atmosphere. Four new establishments have opened in recent months, including Flee Away cafe and Rouse, a halal-certified cafe serving unique dishes. The Tool Room, a co-working space, has also joined the street, catering to tech entrepreneurs and creative startups. The influx of new businesses is part of a gentrification trend, which has been building momentum since the success of previous ventures like Zsofi Tapas bar and Temporium.

site_title: Competing with the world's best
summary: The World Architecture Festival (WAF) will take place from Oct 1 to 3 at the Marina Bay Sands in Singapore. The event features the WAF awards, the world's largest architectural awards programme, with 11 Singaporean projects shortlisted. The shortlisted projects include Wat Ananda Metyarama, Sandcrawler, and Goodwood Residence. Over 250 entries were received from more than 50 countries across various categories.

site_title: Business briefing
summary: FRASERS Hospitality Trust's initial public offering (IPO) has been completed with strong support from retail and institutional investors, reaching 19 times subscription. The public offer was 13.8 times subscribed, while the placement tranche was about 20.7 times subscribed. The firm will start trading on the Singapore Exchange on Monday.

site_title: Qatar Airways eyes top-five slot in cargo
summary: Qatar Airways aims to become one of the top five global cargo operators by 2018, doubling its annual capacity to 2.8 million tonnes at its Doha terminal by 2017. The carrier plans to expand its freight fleet with new Boeing and Airbus planes and add cargo space to its passenger jets. Belly space remains the most efficient mode of cargo transport, so Qatar Airways will add cargo jets only if market growth justifies it. The airline has placed firm orders for new freighter planes and is exploring partnerships with other carriers, particularly within the Oneworld alliance.

site_title: GSTF spreading its wings in Asia
summary: Global Science and Technology Forum (GSTF) has expanded its reach in Asia by appointing partners in the Philippines, Vietnam, and India. The organization, which develops IT training content and certification programs, aims to leverage technology to transfer knowledge. GSTF partners with universities and publishes academic journals and conferences, with a focus on cloud computing, business analytics, and big data. The company plans to continue developing content and certification programs, and will leverage online channels to reach a wider audience, aiming to remain a key player in the Asia Pacific region.

site_title: The BT-Coca-Cola World Cup Charity Drive
summary: A charity drive, "BT-Coca-Cola World Cup Charity Drive", was published but no details were given.

site_title: YouTube goes to Hollywood to boost premium content
summary: YouTube is in talks with Hollywood and independent producers to fund premium content, aiming to boost its transition from a repository for home videos to a site with polished content. The site may offer $1-3 million to produce series and contribute marketing funds. This move follows a three-year-old multimillion-dollar effort to secure higher-priced advertising. YouTube has provided production facilities and marketing support for online celebrities, but few of its backed creators have garnered mainstream attention. The talks are in initial phases and actual measures may not materialize.

site_title: Rio braces for Argentina's World Cup fans
summary: Up to 100,000 Argentine fans are expected to arrive in Rio de Janeiro by car, bus, and motorhome for the World Cup final against Germany at the Maracana Stadium. Many have been camping out in open spaces, with authorities offering alternative accommodations nearby. Despite the large influx of fans, Rio's tourism department has promised to provide a "red carpet" experience. Police will deploy 11,500 officers and 1,000 soldiers to maintain order, following incidents of hooliganism and fan clashes during previous matches.

site_title: US Navy maintains F-35 jets grounding order
summary: The US Navy maintains a grounding order for F-35 B-model and C-model fighter jets due to a massive engine failure on an Air Force F-35 jet last month. The grounding order prevents three Marine Corps F-35 B-model jets and one British F-35B from traveling to air shows in Britain. The Navy is still investigating the incident and plans to update the flight directive by Wednesday, with Vice-Admiral David Dunaway stating that a root cause has not been determined.

site_title: Here's to German attack 1, Argentine defence 0
summary: Germany will face Argentina in the 2014 World Cup final on Sunday, with Germany holding an edge in terms of morale and physical condition after a historic semi-final win. Argentina's defense, one of the best in the tournament, will be put to the test against Germany's prolific attack, which has scored 17 goals in six games. A 1-0 German win is predicted, but a 3-1 victory is also possible, with the game likely to be closely contested.

site_title: Flat week for buying, buybacks
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article content:

There was a flat week for buying and selling among Singapore Exchange-listed companies from July 7 to 11. A total of 11 companies recorded purchases worth $4.42 million, while six firms recorded disposals worth $2.58 million. Significant corporate shareholder trades included purchases in SingPost and Manhattan Resources, and sales in Pteris Global and AIMS AMP Capital Industrial Reit. Notable insider trades included International Healthway Corp's chairman purchasing 12 million shares, Best World International's COO buying 50,000 shares, and Manhattan Resources' Mohamed Abdul Jaleel purchasing 189,000 shares. The number of companies on the buying side was down from the previous week.

site_title: Italy ship wreck set to be lifted and towed away
summary: Italy's Costa Concordia cruise ship is set to be lifted and towed away from the island of Giglio, where it sank two and a half years ago, in a high-risk salvage operation. The 114,500-tonne vessel will be raised by 30 tanks or "sponsons" and towed 240 kilometers north to the port of Genoa, where it will be scrapped. The operation, led by South African Nick Sloane, is expected to take six or seven days and poses environmental risks, with some warning that the hull could break apart and spill pollutants into the Mediterranean.

site_title: Paradigm shift in use of statins
summary: The American Heart Association has recommended a patient-centric approach to managing cholesterol, shifting the focus from LDL-C targets to identifying individuals at risk of heart disease. The new guidelines suggest starting statin therapy for those in four defined risk groups, including those with known arterial disease, severely elevated LDL-C, or increased risk of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease. The guidelines also advise a risk calculator to motivate lifestyle change in younger individuals, rather than guiding drug treatment. This approach has sparked controversy, with some experts questioning the new targets and calculator's accuracy.

site_title: Wing Hang Bank stake pits hedge fund against OCBC
summary: Billionaire hedge fund manager Paul Singer's Elliott Capital Advisors LP is in a dispute with Singapore's Oversea-Chinese Banking Corp (OCBC) over a proposed $5 billion acquisition of Hong Kong bank Wing Hang Bank Ltd. Elliott has amassed a 7.8% stake, potentially blocking OCBC's plan to delist Wing Hang and cap its ownership at 75%. OCBC's offer price of HK$125 per share may not be negotiable, with some analysts suggesting the bank should sit tight until Elliott loses patience and offloads its shares.

site_title: Foodie wake-up call for Havelock enclave
summary: Havelock Road and Bukit Ho Swee, once known for Teochew restaurants, are slowly transforming into a hub for new startups, including Sin Lee Foods and The Tastemaker Store. The area's revitalization is attributed to the arrival of businesses like Forty Hands, which took a gamble and paid off. Founder Sean Lee believes that trying new things is essential for growth, and the neighborhood is now buzzing with contemporary eateries and cafes, offering a fresh food scene.

site_title: Hsieh Fu Hua to take over as Tiger Airways chairman
summary: Tiger Airways chairman JY Pillay is set to retire on July 31, succeeded by Hsieh Fu Hua, a banking veteran. Pillay, 80, led the airline through a difficult period, divesting overseas ventures and focusing on core operations. Hsieh, with 40 years of finance experience, credited Pillay for laying foundations for the airline's turnaround. Two board members will also step down at the AGM, while Chong Phit Lian joins as an independent director.

site_title: Will M'sia hike rates again before year-end?
summary: Malaysia's central bank is considering another interest rate hike before the end of the year, with economists predicting a possible 25 basis point increase to 3.50% due to rising inflation and household debt. The economy grew 6.2% in the first quarter, but inflation has spiked to 3.4% and is expected to rise further. Household debt is also a concern, with 87% of GDP and strong demand for home and vehicle loans. Some economists expect a rate reprieve for the rest of the year, citing the impact on domestic demand and vulnerable earners.

site_title: Old estates, new buzz
summary: A growing number of entrepreneurs are opening businesses in Singapore's forgotten, greying neighbourhoods, seeking to capitalize on lower rents and less competition. These "hipster central" areas, such as Havelock Road and Dunlop Street, are being revitalized with cafes, boutiques, and co-working spaces. While some businesses aim to inject new life into these areas, others seek to preserve the local culture and community. Despite challenges, these ventures are gaining traction, with some attracting crowds and online attention, and others providing a welcoming space for long-time residents.

site_title: SGX issues 'trade with caution' advice for UOB
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) issued a "trade with caution" advice for UOB shares, prompting a 4% surge in the bank's stock price. UOB's strong performance, attributed to its lower China exposure and strong capital ratio, has outperformed its peers and the key benchmark index. This is the first time SGX has queried UOB since 2009. Despite concerns over China's economy, analysts believe UOB's margins will benefit from rising short-term rates in Q1 2015.

site_title: LTA says SMRT has $2b in obligations until 2019
summary: Singapore's Rail operator SMRT has $2 billion in financial obligations until 2019, including buying over operating assets and paying for re-signalling works. The Land Transport Authority (LTA) revealed this after Transport Minister Lui Tuck Yew was asked for details on the Rail Financing Model proposal submitted by SMRT in April. The LTA stated that the valuation of SMRT's business must consider its existing assets and future capital expenditure obligations. This includes investments in new trains and the re-signalling project for the North-South and East-West Line.

site_title: Electricity futures trading will have a 'gradual start'
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) will launch electricity futures trading in October with a "gradual start," according to CEO Magnus Bocker. The market is expected to experience a "period of discovery" with wider spreads and slower trading activity initially. However, once spreads tighten and related markets open, the market is expected to attract financial participants and international energy players. The SGX sees this as a significant milestone, marking the first centralized electricity market in Asia and providing customers and stakeholders with better price discovery and transparency.

site_title: Higher returns as SPH Reit beats forecasts
summary: SPH Reit reported a distribution per unit (DPU) of 1.35 cents for its third quarter, beating forecasts and translating to an annualised distribution yield of 5.28%. Net property income rose 2.7% and total amount distributable increased 3.6% compared to forecasts. The Reit's assets, Paragon and The Clementi Mall, were fully leased, and lease renewals were completed ahead of schedule. This marks the second consecutive quarter of exceeding forecasts, with a total DPU of 4.6 cents for the year to May 31.

site_title: Ezra upbeat on long-term outlook of oil and gas industry
summary: Ezra Holdings, a Singapore-based oil and gas company, reported a 16% rise in third-quarter net profit to US$8.3 million, driven by a 27% increase in revenue and gross profit. The company plans to consolidate its offshore support services division, EMAS Marine, into EOC Ltd, creating a major Asia-Pacific player in offshore support services. Ezra expects the long-term fundamentals of the oil and gas industry to drive industry capital expenditure trends, benefiting its subsea services, marine services, and offshore support services divisions.

site_title: India's Budget 2014 prudent and practical
summary: India's Finance Minister Arun Jaitley presented his maiden budget, focusing on fiscal prudence and macroeconomic stabilization. The budget aims to deliver 7-8% growth and lower inflation, fiscal deficit, and current account deficit. Key measures include increasing tax to GDP ratio, improving tax collection, and promoting foreign direct investment in selective sectors. Infrastructure companies are expected to benefit from tax incentives and simplification of FDI norms. The government also announced plans to introduce a Goods and Services Tax (GST) and establish a PPP support institution, 3P India.

site_title: Study explains Temasek, GLCs' performance
summary: A study by the National University of Singapore Business School and the Chartered Institute of Management Accountants found that sound corporate governance and a clear business mandate have contributed to the better-than-average performance of Temasek Holdings and government-linked companies (GLCs) in Singapore. The study, which examined 23 GLCs and GLReits, linked several drivers of good governance, including leadership continuity and adoption of corporate governance best practices, to the GLCs' better performance. The study also found that Temasek's 20-year total shareholder return was 2.5 times that of the MSCI Singapore benchmark.

site_title: Upmarket foray
summary: JR Chan, 27, and her partner Jermaine Ng, 43, have opened a high-end clothing store, ThreeSixFive, on Dunlop Street in Singapore. The boutique, which also stocks lifestyle products and design collaborations, aims to bring variety to the area, known for its backpackers and hungry patrons. Chan sees her store as a creative showcase, bringing together culture, history, and design elements. The store's items range from $89 to $279 for clothing and $16 to $75 for bags and accessories, offering a unique shopping experience in an area with slower-moving local patrons.

site_title: KL's three-way bank merger lacks oomph
summary: Kuala Lumpur's proposed three-way merger between CIMB Group, RHB Capital, and Malaysia Building Society Bhd (MBSB) lacks excitement, failing to surpass Maybank as Malaysia's largest bank. The deal, worth $370 billion in combined assets, will catapult CIMB to second spot, but with a 6% gap in assets. Critics question the value proposition, citing duplication of client and portfolio mix, branch networks, and revenue streams, as well as MBSB's role in the merger. The deal may also pose risks, given MBSB's high non-performing loan ratio and the timing of the merger.

site_title: My money's on magic of Messi
summary: Argentina coach Alejandro Sabella doubts his team's chances against Germany in the World Cup final, citing the extra day of rest for the Germans and Argentina's grueling semi-final match. However, Sabella's seemingly defeatist attitude is seen as a tactic to take the spotlight off his weary players. The team's key players, including Lionel Messi and Angel di Maria, will need to step up to overcome the strong German team, which plans to contain Messi in a collective force. A 1-0 win for Argentina is predicted, with Messi's "magic" being the key to victory.

site_title: History writ large
summary: Eastern European cities of Prague, Vienna, and Budapest showcase a 1,000-year history of art, architecture, and politics. The trio offers a unique blend of architectural styles, from Romanesque to Art Nouveau, with locals fiercely protective of their heritage. Visitors can explore historic landmarks like Prague Castle, Cesky Krumlov Castle, and the Schonbrunn Palace, experiencing the region's rich cultural and historical influences. Each city offers a distinct character, from Prague's rustic charm to Vienna's grandeur and Budapest's vibrant cultural scene.

site_title: Bukit Merah's slow but steady gentrification
summary: Bukit Merah, a previously overlooked neighborhood in Singapore, is slowly experiencing gentrification. New cafes like Pan Delights and Butterscotch are opening, catering to a growing population of young professionals and families. Despite initial skepticism from long-time residents and business owners, these cafes are thriving, offering unique offerings like halal-certified food and Western-fusion cuisine. The area's accessibility, affordable rent, and hidden potential have made it an attractive spot for entrepreneurs. As the neighborhood continues to evolve, it's clear that gentrification is underway, with new businesses and residents bringing fresh energy to the area.

site_title: Some sectors seeing productivity gains
summary: Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam said it's too early to revise national targets for productivity gains, citing examples of sectors like precision engineering and food manufacturing where productivity has increased by over a quarter in four years. However, he noted that overall productivity figures remain weak. Tharman highlighted the success of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) like Chan Kian Metal Works, which has seen a three-fold improvement in land productivity after installing a goods handling system.

site_title: Korea's Spackman Entertainment launches Catalist IPO
summary: Spackman Entertainment Group Limited, a Korean film production company, launched its initial public offering (IPO) on the Catalist listing in Singapore. The IPO offers 69.44 million shares at 26 cents each, with trading expected to begin on July 22. The company, led by executive chairman Charles Spackman, aims to capitalize on the South Korean entertainment market and has produced successful films such as "Cold Eyes" and "Snowpiercer". The IPO's success will help the company expand its operations and invest in new films, but also comes with risks including volatile revenues and reliance on key producers.

site_title: Standing tall
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article:

Eleven Singaporean projects have made it to the shortlist of the World Architecture Festival awards. Five projects, including the Wat Ananda Metyarama Thai Buddhist Temple and Christ Methodist Church, feature unique and contemporary designs inspired by traditional Thai architecture. The Sandcrawler building at one-north is modeled after a Star Wars spaceship, while Oxley Residence has operable screens made from aluminium tubes and features extensive vertical landscaping. Goodwood Residence, a condominium, features woven textile-inspired screens and a grand central lawn. The projects showcase innovative and sustainable design solutions in Singapore.

site_title: A Greek classic roars back to life
summary: A modern retelling of the ancient Greek tragedy Medea is being performed in Singapore, updating the classic story to fit the age of information overload. The production, titled Medea in Media, features actress Kim Mi Ok as the titular sorceress, who seeks revenge against her ex-husband Jason and his new wife. The play's use of modern settings and styles, such as talk shows and video games, adds a striking immediacy to the story, but also raises questions about the impact of media violence on humanity.

site_title: UOB continues to be in the limelight
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) surged to a seven-year high of $24.03, adding 12 points to the Straits Times Index, driven by its strong earnings and high net interest margin. The bank's year-to-date return rose to 4%, outperforming its peers DBS and OCBC. Despite a low market turnover of $845 million, UOB's popularity is attributed to its superior earnings and attractive banking exposure. Analysts Macquarie Warrants and Macquarie Equities Research expect UOB's return on tangible book to remain higher than DBS and OCBC.

site_title: A very different Lexus
summary: The Lexus NX200t, the company's first compact SUV, features a turbocharged 2.0-litre engine and revolutionary styling. The NX200t boasts a 6-speed automatic transmission, high ride comfort, and a unique twin scroll turbo that provides seamless torque. The vehicle also incorporates LFA supercar-inspired touches and advanced features such as a remote touch interface and wireless phone charger. With its new engine, transmission, and styling, the NX200t offers a distinct Lexus experience, catering to buyers seeking a more aggressive and efficient option.

site_title: The World Cup Awards
summary: The article highlights the most memorable moments and awards from the 2014 World Cup. Luis Suarez wins the "Hunger Games Award" for biting an opponent, Arjen Robben is dubbed the "Drama-mama Award" for excessive diving, and Fifa introduces a "Sticker Lady Award" for a referee's creative use of paint. Tim Howard is named the "Captain America Award" for his record-breaking 16 saves in a loss to Belgium. Meanwhile, Tim Krul receives the "Gangsta Award" for his intimidating penalty shootout performances. Oscar, a Brazilian midfielder, wins the "Oscar Award" for his emotional reaction to a 7-1 loss to Germany.

site_title: Modi govt aims to prevent collapse of aviation industry
summary: The Indian government, led by Prime Minister Narendra Modi, aims to prevent the collapse of the aviation industry by abolishing archaic rules and addressing infrastructure and fuel tax issues. The industry is expected to post collective losses of $1.3 billion to $1.4 billion in FY2015, but the new government plans to slash sales taxes on fuel to 4% and ease restrictions on generating ancillary revenue streams. The government also seeks to boost safety ratings, turn around Air India, and support aircraft engineering firms, with the goal of transforming the sector and benefiting the entire Indian economy.

site_title: Muscling onto a bigger stage
summary: One Fighting Championship (One FC) is expanding its reach across Asia, with plans to debut in Cambodia, host events in the Middle East and China, and stage ten shows across multiple cities in China over the next two years. The organization, led by CEO Victor Cui, aims to double its event capacity to retain existing fans and bring in new ones, with a focus on promoting local heroes and martial arts. Cui believes MMA has the potential to become a major sport in Asia, with a history spanning over 5,000 years, and is committed to giving athletes a chance to hone their skills and compete globally.

site_title: Starburst shares up by more than a third on debut
summary: Starburst Holdings, a company that designs firearms-training facilities, made a successful debut on Singapore's Catalist board, with its shares rising 38.7% to 43 cents per share. The company's IPO of 50 million shares was 9.5 times subscribed, with Asdew Acquisitions and Eastspring Investments taking up over 5% of the shares. Starburst's clients include law enforcement and military agencies in South-east Asia and the Middle East, and its chairman expects to tap into the positive industry prospects for firearms-training facilities. The company's market capitalization now stands at $10.5 billion.

site_title: Reit leads US$700m deal for St Regis stores
summary: Vornado Realty Trust led a partnership to buy the retail portion of the St Regis Hotel on Manhattan's Fifth Avenue for approximately $700 million, gaining space on one of the world's most expensive shopping corridors. The acquisition includes 100 feet of frontage and an adjacent retail townhouse, with Vornado owning 67-80% of the property. The purchase price works out to $28,340 per square foot, setting a US record, and the St Regis space is leased to luxury brands Gucci and De Beers.

site_title: The lasting impact of Japanese ukiyo-e
summary: A contemporary art space in Singapore, STPI, is celebrating the lasting impact of Japanese ukiyo-e, a type of woodblock printing and painting that flourished from the 17th to 19th centuries. Ukiyo-e's influence can be seen in the Impressionist movement, with artists such as Monet and van Gogh drawing inspiration from its clear outlines, bold colors, and asymmetrical perspectives. Iconic prints by Hokusai, Hiroshige, and others are on display until mid-September, showcasing the art form's enduring influence on modern Western art.

site_title: Maersk, MSC strike new vessel sharing deal
summary: Maersk Line and MSC Mediterranean Shipping Co have struck a new vessel-sharing agreement, sharing 185 vessels including 20 giant Triple-E ships. The deal, which was previously rejected by Chinese regulators due to concerns of consumer domination, is structured differently and involves fewer ships and volumes of goods. This new deal is expected to have a combined capacity share below 30% in routes between Asia and Europe. The agreement aims to cut costs, fuel usage, and emissions, but critics fear the carriers could still dominate key trade routes.

site_title: Around Town
summary: The Minneapolis Institute of Arts, Singapore Art Museum, and STPI are hosting the "Edo Pop: The Graphic Impact of Japanese Prints" exhibition, showcasing over 60 ukiyo-e prints and inspired works from Japan's Edo period. The exhibition runs until September 13, highlighting the dynamic culture of Edo society through samurais, geishas, and kabuki theatre actors. Meanwhile, the "Dear Curator Curate Me" exhibition by Kristoffer Ardena explores the artist- curator relationship, featuring 15 short films, until July 26 at Grey Projects.

site_title: Space van
summary: The Suzuki Solio, a compact Japanese minivan, has been facelifted for 2014 with a surprisingly roomy cabin. Measuring 3,710 mm long and 1,765 mm high, the Solio boasts a large greenhouse and convenient rear electric sliding doors. The interior features ample headroom and legroom, with the back seats sliding independently for a limo-like interior. The Solio is powered by a 1.2-litre four-cylinder engine and has a low kerb weight of 1,045 kg, making it an ideal city car with good fuel economy and all-round visibility.

site_title: Reform push is biggest winner in Indonesia polls
summary: Indonesia's presidential election results are expected to favor the cause of reform, with Joko Widodo, or "Jokowi," leading Prabowo Subianto by a significant margin. Voter turnout was a record, despite smear campaigns and biased reporting. Analysts say the winner will have a mandate for sweeping changes, including governance reform, police and judiciary overhauls, and infrastructure development. Jokowi's uncharismatic campaign style has contributed to his popularity, as seen in his previous narrow victories followed by widespread support for his initiatives.

site_title: India budget marred by funding gaps
summary: India's new BJP government presented its first budget, led by finance minister Arun Jaitley, which boosts the construction industry and aims to lower the fiscal deficit to 3% by 2016. The budgeted expenditure is 17.8 trillion rupees, with a deficit of 4.1% of GDP, to be financed by borrowings. Jaitley proposed allowing Real Estate Investment Trusts and long-term loans for infrastructure projects. The budget also includes plans to create employment, such as a fund for start-ups and a legal framework for small businesses. However, critics argue that the budget lacks details on financing and supporting agriculture.

site_title: Speciality java and chic eats in Bedok
summary: New eateries have opened in Bedok, a popular hawker centre in Singapore, catering to the local supper crowd. IScream, a gelato parlour, and To-Gather Cafe, a specialty eatery, have joined Percolate, a specialty coffee shop, in the area. The newcomers were drawn to the lower rent and the opportunity to introduce unique concepts to the local community. Despite the competition, the owners are optimistic about the potential for growth and attracting a loyal customer base. The new eateries aim to create a welcoming atmosphere and provide affordable options for locals and visitors alike.

site_title: A comedy that may put you to sleep
summary: The movie "Walking on Sunshine" is a deliberately campy, upbeat musical comedy that fails to entertain due to its thin plot, underwhelming singing, and poor acting. Directed by Max Giwa and Dania Pasquini, the film features a series of bubblegum songs linked by a story of two British sisters who fall for the same Italian hunk while on holiday. Despite its picturesque Italian setting and abundant eye candy, the film's lack of depth and seriousness makes it a chore to watch, earning it a C- rating.

site_title: Tighter JTC subletting rules seen crimping Reits
summary: Singapore's JTC has tightened subletting rules for Reits, requiring them to sublet at least 70% of total gross floor area to an anchor tenant within five years. This shift is expected to slow Reits' pace of acquisitions, with growth coming from organic expansion or development. Analysts predict a continued tough environment for industrial Reits, with moderating rents and a shrinking pool of eligible anchor tenants. The policy may also lead to the creation of an anchor tenants' market, with stronger clauses in Reits' agreements to prevent anchor tenants from downsizing.

site_title: Emirates makes US$56b jumbo order for B777Xs
summary: Emirates Airline has ordered 150 Boeing 777X planes worth $56 billion, the largest single order in aviation history, to expand its wide-body fleet. The deal includes 115 400-seat 777-9Xs and 35 777-8Xs, with an option for 50 more aircraft that would increase the value to $75 billion. The order is expected to offer operational flexibility in terms of range, passenger capacity, and fuel efficiency, according to Emirates President Tim Clark.

site_title: Fiscal deficit target kept at 4.1% of GDP
summary: India's new government, led by Prime Minister Narendra Modi, has unveiled its first budget, aiming to revive growth and curb borrowing. The fiscal deficit target remains at 4.1% of GDP, while the government will boost capital spending and reassure foreign investors. Finance Minister Arun Jaitley announced an 8% rise in spending and plans to raise $10.5 billion from asset sales, including state-run bank holdings. The budget also includes measures to boost economic growth, such as raising foreign investment ceilings and launching a sales tax reform.

site_title: Pricing for DBS floating, fixed rate notes
summary: DBS Group Holdings priced US$750 million fixed-rate senior notes and US$500 million floating-rate senior notes, both due 2019, with settlement on July 16, 2014. The notes will bear 2.246% semi-annual fixed coupon and 3.5% quarterly floating coupon. The net proceeds will be used for finance and treasury activities. The notes are expected to be rated Aa2 by Moody's and AA- by Fitch, with a combined order book exceeding US$3 billion.

site_title: Pick of the Week
summary: A Southeast Asian ceramic exhibition, Ceramicship, is showcasing the works of five artists from Indonesia, Singapore, Thailand, Philippines, and Malaysia. The exhibition, running until July 31 at One East Artspace, highlights the artists' unique techniques and traditions, combining traditional and modern aspects of ceramic art. The exhibition aims to foster growth and self-awareness among the artists, and admission is free. The artists featured include Ahadiat Joedawinata, Alvin Tan Teck Heng, Bathma Kaew-Ngok, Jon Lorenzo Pettyjohn, and Peter Low Hwee Min.

site_title: Triyards Q3 net falls 17% to US$6.3 million
summary: Triyards Holdings reported a 17% decline in Q3 net profit to US$6.3 million, down from US$7.5 million a year ago. Revenue fell 16% to US$55.3 million, while net profit for the first nine months was flat at US$21.4 million. The company secured new liftboat contracts worth US$112 million and delivered its first BH 450 liftboat, citing buoyant demand for liftboats in Asia. Triyards shares ended trading at 64.5 cents, down 0.5 cents.

site_title: Hong Leong-linked First Sponsor Group launches IPO
summary: First Sponsor Group Ltd (FSGL), a China-based developer, launched its Singapore mainboard IPO of 34.05 million shares at $1.50 apiece, with estimated net proceeds of $59.7 million to fund property development projects. The IPO represents about 5.8% of the group's enlarged share capital, with cornerstone subscriptions from Mellford and DBS Bank. FSGL expects a market capitalization of $884.7 million upon listing on July 22.

site_title: NY landlords fight tenants in buyout battle
summary: NY landlords are offering buyouts to tenants, but tenants are resisting, demanding suitable alternative accommodation. The buyouts, which began as a common practice in the city's real estate market, have become a threat to affordable housing as landlords often make low offers that tenants cannot afford. According to the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development, the number of complaints about buyouts has risen, with over 3,200 complaints filed since 2008. Tenant groups are calling for stronger laws to protect tenants from harassment and intimidation.

site_title: Etihad plans to launch six new routes in 2015
summary: Etihad Airways plans to launch six new routes in 2015, increasing its network to 107 destinations globally. The airline will also introduce First Class cabins on select routes, including daily flights to Singapore and Moscow. New routes will connect Abu Dhabi to Brisbane, Madrid, Edinburgh, Kolkata, and Entebbe, as well as increase frequencies to Hong Kong, Algiers, and other destinations. This expansion aims to strengthen Etihad's customer proposition and create opportunities for codeshare agreements with its equity investments, including Virgin Australia.

site_title: Europe's market rally may not go on: fund manager
summary: Thorsten Winkelmann, a top-rated fund manager, believes Europe's market rally may not be sustained due to economic factors. He cites anemic economic growth, extremely low interest rates, and price growth concerns, which are not aligning with corporate earnings expectations. Winkelmann prefers to invest in selected stocks, such as SAP, Reckitt Benckiser, and Richemont, citing their strong management teams and growth potential. He expects these companies to deliver despite the market's inability to sustain its rally.

site_title: Combining two art traditions
summary: Chinese artist Low Hai Hong combines traditional Chinese ink painting techniques with Western oil painting methods on rice paper, creating unique and lasting works of art. For over 30 years, Low has experimented with oil on rice paper, enjoying the differences in texture and visual effects. His Impressionist-style paintings on rice paper showcase the medium's lasting power, with some pieces potentially lasting over 100 years. The exhibition, "A Tale of Two Rivers," showcases Low's works on rice paper, highlighting the benefits of this mixed media technique.

site_title: Ezra in move to make Oslo unit a major Asia-Pacific player
summary: Ezra Holdings plans to consolidate its offshore support services division, EMAS Marine, into its Oslo-listed associated company, EOC Ltd, in a deal valued at US$520 million. The move aims to capture increased demand in the market and gain access to Asian investor interest. Ezra will receive US$150 million in cash and 280.1 million new EOC shares, increasing its stake in EOC to approximately 84.6%. The enlarged EOC group will then seek a secondary listing in Singapore.

site_title: Asian HNWIs look afield for better returns
summary: Asian high-net-worth individuals (HNWIs) are shifting their investments beyond domestic markets, seeking higher yields and greater stability. According to a research note, the proportion of assets allocated to equities has risen to 44% from 42% last year, with non-domestic equities accounting for 22% of total investable assets, up from 18% last year. This trend is driven by concerns over rising base interest rates and a desire for differentiated products. HNWIs' investable wealth is expected to increase 15% in the next 12 months to $5 million, with significant room for growth in private banking.

site_title: American likely to buy CFM engines for its A320neo fleet
summary: American Airlines Group is set to purchase 200 Leap-1A engines from CFM, a joint venture of General Electric and Safran, for its A320neo fleet. The $2.6 billion deal, valued at $13 million per engine, will outfit 100 Airbus planes expected to be delivered in 2017. This purchase gives CFM a boost over rival Pratt & Whitney, which is fielding questions over its new geared turbofan engine. The agreement is set to be announced at the Farnborough International Airshow next week.

site_title: Eastern China city relaxes home curbs
summary: Jinan, a city in eastern China, has lifted home purchase restrictions, allowing residents to buy more properties without limits on ownership or residency. The move is seen as a response to the cooling housing market, which poses a risk to China's economy. Average home prices fell for the first time in May, and new construction starts have tumbled. Nearly 20 Chinese cities have eased home-buying restrictions this year, with regional governments relying on the real estate sector for significant revenues. Analysts expect more smaller cities to relax restrictions as the property market continues to slow.

site_title: Drawing Singapore from a single look
summary: Artist Stephen Wiltshire will illustrate Singapore's skyline from memory after a helicopter ride over the Central Business District. The 20-minute ride will allow him to recall every detail of the city's buildings, roads, and landmarks. Wiltshire, who has autism and photographic memory, will then draw the skyline on a 4m x 1m canvas at Paragon shopping mall from July 16 to 20. The public can watch him work daily from 10am to 5pm, with breaks at 1:30pm. The drawing is sponsored by Singapore Press Holdings to mark its 30th anniversary.

site_title: COE premiums largely flat across categories
summary: COE (Certificate of Entitlement) premiums remained largely flat across categories in Singapore's latest bidding exercise, with Category A increasing by $91 to $61,990, while Category B decreased by $811 to $64,889. Category E, the open category, dropped $2,300 to $63,001. Dealers expect lower prices in the coming months due to anticipation of a new quota release. However, some dealers are cautious, expecting COE numbers to remain stable, and thus premiums may not fall as expected.

site_title: Sun shone brightly in new stadium
summary: Singer Stefanie Sun made history with her first pop concert at the new National Stadium in Singapore, despite appearing under the weather after collapsing backstage due to exhaustion. The 35-year-old performed a 30-song setlist, taking breaks to sip on a herbal beverage to conserve her voice. The show featured a futuristic sci-fi theme and included a singalong of familiar favourites, with the biggest hits saved for the end. Sun's performance marked a triumphant return to the stage after marriage and childbirth, solidifying her status as one of Singapore's hardest-working musicians.

site_title: Bold moves that redefine dance
summary: This year's dan:s Festival, now in its ninth year, will feature three groundbreaking choreographers showcasing classical ballet and flamenco. Matthew Bourne will present a modern take on Swan Lake, Maria Pages will debut I, Carmen, and Wayne McGregor will showcase Far, inspired by the Age of Enlightenment. The festival also includes local workshops and collaborations, with over 60 free workshops available. Ticket sales begin July 16, and the festival will be held at The Esplanade.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: Malaysia's central bank has given CIMB and RHB permission to discuss a potential merger, which could create the country's largest bank. Meanwhile, Indonesia's presidential election results are expected to favor reform. The US Exim Bank faces competition from Asian companies in promoting win-win arrangements. New Singaporean firms are expanding into Myanmar, and Ezra is consolidating its offshore services division in Oslo. In economic news, HDB resale prices in Singapore dipped 0.6% in June, and Australia's unemployment rate reached a decade-high of 6.0%.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: Jokowi claims victory in Indonesia's presidential elections, with exit polls indicating a wider-than-expected lead over Prabowo Subianto. The US is set to become the world's largest oil producer, overtaking Russia and Saudi Arabia. China's equity market is predicted to surpass the UK and Japan to become the world's second-largest by 2030. US-China talks aim to break old patterns of confrontation, while China urges South-east Asia to support openness amid US tariffs.

site_title: SGX expects more tie-ups with HKEx
summary: SGX, a Singapore bourse, has opened a new office in Hong Kong, marking the first step in its partnership with Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing (HKEx). The two exchanges signed a memorandum of understanding in December. The partnership aims to facilitate easier cross-trading by investors in both Singapore and Hong Kong, with a liquidity hub allowing Hong Kong brokers to access Singapore-based brokers. Five Hong Kong brokerage firms have already signed up for the hub, with plans to launch more yuan products and explore cooperation in areas of common interest.

site_title: Fine wines despite harsh growing season
summary: Bordeaux's 2012 and 2013 vintages have maintained quality despite harsh growing conditions, resulting in severely depleted yields. The 2013 vintage was particularly challenging, with cool and wet springs, severe interruptions to the harvest cycle, and high humidity leading to rot. However, the resulting wines are excellent, with many showcasing concentrated flavors and firm tannins. Quality was prioritized over quantity, with some châteaux producing significantly less wine than usual. The 2013 vintage is worth buying en primeur, with many top châteaux offering exceptional wines that will age well.

site_title: The story's the thing
summary: Couch Theatre's artistic director Jasdeep Gill will stage The Pillowman, a play about a short-story writer arrested for violent tales, at the Drama Centre Black Box from July 17-19 and July 24-26. Gill emphasizes the play's focus on storytelling, saying it's a "really good story" meant to be enjoyed without hidden themes. His two-and-a-half-hour version, set in Soviet Russia, will feature full sound and lighting effects and a "whole sensory experience." Gill aims to match the high quality of the script with a creative concept, promising a "roller-coaster ride" of emotions.

site_title: US Ex-Im Bank faces stiff Asian competition
summary: The US Export-Import Bank (Ex-Im Bank) is facing stiff competition from Asian export credit agencies and criticism that it interferes with the free market. The bank, which finances US exports, is battling for its survival as conservative groups in the US Congress seek to withhold reauthorisation. Ex-Im Bank Chairman Fred Hochberg argues that the bank fills a gap in the market, providing due diligence and government support to facilitate lending. However, the bank's activities are constrained by OECD standards, and it faces competition from countries like China, Japan, and Korea, which offer more generous terms to support their manufacturers.

site_title: Shanghai allows record home prices by builder
summary: Shanghai has approved a record-high home price of 298,000 yuan (S$59,700) per square meter for a luxury residential property, the highest ever in the city. The approval aims to boost the sluggish luxury-home market, with the government seeking to boost buyers' confidence. This move follows similar easing of property policies in other Chinese cities, such as Hohhot, which relaxed restrictions on home purchases and ownership. The approval is part of the government's efforts to regulate the market and address a slowdown in the nation's property industry.

site_title: 3-way merger talks begin on creating biggest KL bank
summary: Malaysia's CIMB Group and RHB Capital have begun merger talks with Malaysia Building Society Bhd (MBSB) to create the country's largest Islamic bank, valued at nearly $240 billion. The 90-day exclusivity agreement aims to negotiate and finalize details of the merger, potentially creating an entity that would surpass Maybank's market value and become South-east Asia's fourth-largest bank. However, concerns over pricing and divergent interests remain, with Aabar Investments, a major shareholder of RHB, refusing to accept an offer below its entry point of RM10.80 per share.

site_title: Robben still haunted by 2010 World Cup ghosts
summary: Netherlands' Arjen Robben's hopes of exorcising his World Cup ghosts from the 2010 final seem to be dashed after his team lost to Argentina in the semi-finals. Robben was denied by a crucial save from Sergio Romero in extra time and ultimately missed his penalty in the shootout. The loss marks the fourth World Cup final and second semi-final defeat for Robben, who had previously been haunted by similar losses in the 2010 final and 2012 Champions League final.

site_title: Temasek must expand more outside Asia
summary: Temasek Holdings' portfolio results for the year ended March 31 showed a 1.5% total shareholder return, underperforming its internal risk-adjusted hurdle rate and common equity indices. Despite a long-term track record of 16% annualized returns, the 20-year return of 6% failed to beat its hurdle rate. The group's heavy weighting in Singapore and China, with 72% of its portfolio exposure, raises questions about its ability to deliver sustainable long-term value. Temasek may consider looking beyond Asia for growth opportunities, particularly in the US, where corporate governance standards and innovation are more robust.

site_title: Myanmar hype over but new firms may make fresh waves
summary: Business enthusiasm for Myanmar's liberalized economy has waned, but optimism remains for a potential second wave of firms to enter the country. Since 2011, Singapore companies have sought a foothold in Myanmar with varying degrees of success. Companies like MDR Limited have made entries, while others face challenges. Despite the decline in interest, Myanmar's economy continues to attract investors, and new firms may still make waves in the country.

site_title: Nothing to go ape about
summary: The article discusses the latest installment in the Planet of the Apes film franchise, "Dawn of the Planet of the Apes." The movie takes place a decade after the events of the previous film and follows a troop of intelligent apes as they interact with humans in a post-apocalyptic world. Led by Caesar, the apes live in harmony, but tensions rise when a group of humans, led by Malcolm, arrive at their home seeking to restart power generation. The film explores themes of human-ape relations, prejudice, and the consequences of scientific experimentation.

site_title: Integrated Shield Plan insurers move to retain policyholders
summary: Integrated Shield Plan insurers in Singapore have agreed to retain policyholders for a year after MediShield Life kicks in, with no premium increases for top-up portions in class A and B1 wards at public hospitals. Insurers have also committed to re-evaluating plans to ensure top-up benefits remain relevant. The move aims to facilitate a "smooth transition" to MediShield Life, amid concerns about affordability. Insurers have rolled out discounts and promotions, with some experts describing the move as "sensible and prudent".

site_title: Hiap Hoe seeks sole buyer for Balmoral condo units
summary: Singapore-listed Hiap Hoe Group is seeking a sole buyer for its 48 unsold condo units in Treasure on Balmoral at a guided price of $1,850 psf ($191.4 million). The developer must sell the units by November to avoid hefty fees to extend the sales period. The move follows other developers, such as Great Newton Properties and Heeton, who have also put their unsold units up for bulk sale. Experts believe the high-end property market may take time to recover, with some predicting a strong price recovery in the next property upswing.

site_title: Indonesia needs forward-looking leadership
summary: Indonesia's newly elected president will face significant challenges, including infrastructure issues and corruption, despite the country's economic promise. The winner of the closely fought election between Prabowo Subianto and Joko Widodo will need to adopt a pragmatic approach to policies, recognizing the importance of foreign investment. A forward-looking leadership can help Indonesia capitalize on the Asean Economic Community, set to become a reality by the end of next year, and restore confidence among foreign investors.

site_title: M&G to almost double size of Asia-Pac fund
summary: M&G Real Estate, a property investment unit of Prudential plc, plans to almost double its Asia-Pacific fund's size to $3 billion by 2017 in response to growing investor demand. The fund currently has $1.7 billion under management and aims to invest in properties in Australia, Japan, Singapore, South Korea, and Hong Kong, focusing on industrial and office space in Australia, office and residential in Japan, and retail and industrial in Singapore. The move is driven by demand from global pension funds and insurance companies, particularly European investors.

site_title: Goodpack fails to get waiver for Series 6 notes
summary: Goodpack, a logistics packaging company, has secured waivers from holders of five out of six series of its bonds, worth approximately 85% of the total $342 million outstanding, after meeting with bondholders. Only the Series 6 notes, worth $50 million, have not been waived, with speculation suggesting a hedge fund may be behind the holdout. The acquisition by KKR, valued at $1.4 billion, is expected to proceed without disruption.

site_title: China's own aircraft prepares to take off next year
summary: China is preparing to launch its own passenger plane, the C919, which aims to compete with Airbus and Boeing. The single-aisle plane's final assembly line is set to be completed by the end of next year, with a prototype expected to take to the skies by the end of 2015. China's Commercial Aircraft Corp of China (COMAC) has received 400 orders for the plane, mostly from domestic leasing companies, and has the backing of the Chinese government. The C919, which can seat up to 174 passengers, is seen as a key part of China's efforts to reduce its reliance on foreign aircraft and increase its domestic aviation industry.

site_title: Cyber risk complacency could doom M&A deals: study
summary: A global study by Freshfields Bruckhaus Deringer found that 90% of dealmakers believe cyber breaches would reduce deal value, and 83% said a breach could lead to deal abandonment. However, only 78% evaluate cyber risk during M&A due diligence, with many not quantifying it or assessing its impact. Experts warn that ignoring cyber risk is costly, as investors and executives face penalties for being victims of cyber attacks, and companies are increasing spend on Internet security.

site_title: Far East's Philip Ng tops billionaire list
summary: Philip Ng, CEO of Far East Organization, tops the list of Singapore-based billionaires with a net worth of US$5.2 billion, nearly 10% of the total wealth of 27 billionaires in the country. His wealth comes mainly from real estate holdings. The top 10 list includes several non-Singaporeans, such as Eduardo Saverin and Richard Chandler, with combined net worth of US$10.4 billion. Ng's father, Ng Teng Fong, founded the company in 1960, and the Ng family has donated over US$95 million to various institutions, including the new Jurong General Hospital.

site_title: Dubai Holding needs $8.5b to build 'Mall of the World' project
summary: Dubai Holding, the investment arm of the emirate's ruler, plans to build the world's largest shopping mall, the "Mall of the World", requiring $8.5 billion in funding. The project, set to be completed in 10 years, will also include a theme park, 100 hotels, and 20,000 rooms. Analysts warn of overbuilding risks, similar to Dubai's 2009 debt crisis, but Dubai Holding's CEO believes demand for such projects is strong, citing growing tourism.

site_title: Company Briefs
summary: Starburst Holdings' initial public offering (IPO) of 50 million invitation shares for a listing on the Singapore Exchange Catalist board was about 9.5 times subscribed. Technics Oil and Gas secured $6.2 million in contracts, while Unionmet reported a net loss of nearly $2.2 million for its second quarter. Meanwhile, NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed.

site_title: Maersk plans US$1.7b Brazil writedown
summary: Maersk, a Danish oil and shipping group, is writing off $1.7 billion of investments in Brazil due to underperforming oil fields, including the Polvo field. The company sold its 40% stake in the Polvo field to Brazil's HRT for an undisclosed sum. Maersk's decision is attributed to rising exploration and production costs in Brazil, which has led to stagnant oil production and regulatory uncertainty. The move may impact Maersk's long-term oil ambitions, with analysts questioning the company's strategy in the oil sector.

site_title: JAL may get highest credit rating in the sector
summary: Japan Airlines (JAL) is likely to receive the industry's highest credit rating, potentially as high as BBB+, if it returns to the bond market. The airline, which emerged from bankruptcy in 2011, has transformed into the world's most-profitable publicly traded airline, posting three consecutive years of profit and reducing debt. Its net income of 166.3 billion yen last fiscal year is more than double that of Ryanair, and its debt-equity ratio has decreased to 19%. This turnaround has earned investors' confidence, making JAL a strong candidate for the top credit rating.

site_title: Ensuring MediShield Life's long-term sustainability
summary: Singapore's MediShield Life scheme will require long-term sustainability, with the government managing overall healthcare costs and setting aside sufficient reserves. The revised national health insurance scheme will offer lifelong coverage and better protection by 2015. The government has committed $4 billion in financial aid over the next five years, but will not raise taxes to pay for these subsidies. Health Minister Gan Kim Yong emphasized the need for co-payment to prevent overconsumption and ensure cost-effective treatments. The government will also work with healthcare providers to manage healthcare inflation and curb cost increases.

site_title: SIA Engg, Boeing to set up aviation services venture in Singapore
summary: SIA Engineering and Boeing are forming a joint venture to provide fleet-management services to airlines in the Asia-Pacific and beyond. The venture, 51% owned by Boeing and 49% by SIA Engineering, will offer customized, comprehensive, and integrated services for Boeing 737, 747, 777, and 787 planes. The move aims to simplify aircraft ownership, increase reliability, and make services more accessible and affordable for airlines. The joint venture is expected to be operational by the end of the year, subject to regulatory approvals.

site_title: JTC clamps down on industrial subletting
summary: The Jurong Town Corporation (JTC) has implemented new rules to curb industrial subletting in Singapore, requiring major occupiers of JTC land to use at least 70% of their total gross floor area, up from 50%. Existing tenants and lessees have a three-year grace period until end-2017 to adjust. Tenants who rent directly from JTC will no longer be allowed to sublet their space, while end-users and third-party providers can sublet up to 50% of their total GFA to non-anchor sub-tenants within five years. The goal is to promote responsible use of industrial land and encourage higher-quality businesses to occupy the space.

site_title: Wanda invests US$900m in Chicago project
summary: China's Wanda Group invests US$900 million in a Chicago project, a five-star hotel and apartment complex to be the city's third tallest building. The mixed-use development will include a 240-room hotel, residential units, and commercial space. This marks Wanda's expansion into the US, with plans to invest in major cities like New York, Los Angeles, and San Francisco within a year. Construction is set to start this year, with an expected opening in 2018.

site_title: Tay Kah Poh back at Knight Frank
summary: Veteran property consultant Tay Kah Poh has rejoined Knight Frank Singapore after a nine-year absence, taking on the role of executive director of agency services. He will oversee residential, office, industrial, and retail services, focusing on cross-selling and leadership development. Tay previously worked at Knight Frank from 1993 to 2005, and his return is seen as a boost to the company amid tough market conditions and increased competition.

site_title: Jokowi claims victory in Jakarta; Prabowo demurs
summary: Indonesian Governor Joko Widodo, known as Jokowi, declared victory in the country's presidential election with exit polls showing a large winning margin of four percentage points over rival Prabowo Subianto. Prabowo refused to concede, claiming a mandate, but analysts say his chances are slim due to public sentiment turning against him and potential challenges in the Constitutional Court. Jokowi's victory is expected to give him the mandate to implement reforms to improve the rule of law and investor confidence in the country.

site_title: UK house prices up in Q2 on improving economy
summary: UK house prices rose 2.3% in the second quarter to £183,462, driven by an improving economy and rising consumer confidence. This follows a 4% increase in May, the largest since October 2002. Despite concerns of overheating, prices are up 9.4% from last year, with Halifax citing employment levels and consumer confidence as key factors. The Bank of England has introduced measures to limit risky mortgages, but some surveys suggest momentum in values may be easing.

site_title: US Navy's funding challenge
summary: The US Navy's 30-year shipbuilding plan faces a funding challenge, requiring an unsustainable level of spending from 2025 to 2034 to meet its goal of increasing the fleet to 306 vessels. The average annual cost for new submarines is $19.7 billion, with peak spending reaching $24 billion in 2032. The Navy cannot accommodate this budget from existing resources, particularly if sequestration cuts remain in place.

site_title: Vietnamese drugmaker eyes expansion
summary: Vietnamese drugmaker DHG Pharmaceutical plans to boost health supplement sales to 15% of revenue within five years, and increase exports by 25% annually. The company aims to expand into Myanmar, where it may invest up to 91 billion dong in a joint venture. DHG's CEO, Pham Thi Viet Nga, sees the move as a way to lessen the impact of tighter controls on antibiotics in Vietnam, where the company generated 41% of its sales from antibiotics last year.

site_title: HK buyers queue for new homes after price drop
summary: In Hong Kong, thousands of homebuyer-hopefuls waited in line to buy apartments at City Point, a seven-tower development, with prices dropped by as much as 20% since October. A drop in mortgage rates and discounts from builders are luring back buyers. Housing sales have risen after government efforts to cool soaring prices led transactions to plunge last year. Experts predict that the downward price pressure may be over, and transaction volume is expected to continue.

site_title: Brazil's humiliating loss leaves nation in a state of shock
summary: Brazil suffered a humiliating 7-1 loss to Germany in the World Cup semi-finals, leaving the nation in shock. The crushing defeat, Brazil's heaviest-ever international loss, was attributed to a woeful defense that conceded five goals in 18 minutes. Coach Luiz Felipe Scolari apologized to the Brazilian people, while Germany's coach Joachim Loew attributed the victory to a well-played first half and a humble approach. The loss has sparked widespread disappointment and has raised concerns about the country's hosting of the World Cup, which has cost over $11 billion.

site_title: Dubai's Nakheel H1 profit surges 54%

summary: A Nicaraguan committee approved a proposed US$40 billion shipping channel across the country, competing with the Panama Canal. The project faces environmental and social impact studies, with completion expected by the end of the year to allow work to begin by December. site_title: New Lufthansa CEO to unveil plans to win back investors
summary: Lufthansa's new CEO, Carsten Spohr, plans to unveil strategies to win back investors after a profit warning reduced the airline's market value by $2 billion. To compete with low-cost rivals and Gulf airlines, Lufthansa may consider cost cuts, deeper no-frills services, or an alliance with a Middle Eastern airline. Analysts suggest embracing the Gulf airlines or Turkish Airlines in a partnership could be necessary, as the company has criticized them for distorting the market.

site_title: HK regulator warns bankers on IPO rules
summary: Hong Kong's Securities and Futures Commission (SFC) has warned investment bankers to provide "meaningful disclosure" for initial public offerings (IPOs), urging a shift away from a checklist approach. The new sponsor regime requires complete submissions upon application, aiming to improve corporate governance. Despite improved IPO submissions, the SFC says quality of disclosure remains an issue, particularly in company profit warnings and delayed disclosures. summary: Singapore banks are expected to post weaker profits over the next 12-18 months due to thin margins and higher loan-loss provisions for overseas operations. The saturated domestic market and conservative nature of foreign loans are contributing factors, while the lack of scale hinders funding costs and fee income.

site_title: Asia stays upbeat in latest survey
summary: Asia's shipping industry remains stable, with confidence levels remaining unchanged at 6.4, despite concerns over regulatory requirements and overcapacity. Global confidence levels also remain high, at their second-highest in six years. Ship managers are slightly more optimistic, while owners, charterers, and brokers show decreased confidence. The industry faces challenges from increasing regulatory costs, particularly sulphur emissions restrictions and ballast water management systems, which may lead to a decrease in freight rates and a potential market downturn.

site_title: Yoma, Mitsubishi JV to enter Myanmar tyre business

site_title: 1 in 2 may sacrifice friendship to climb corporate ladder: poll

summary: Keppel Corporation, a Singapore conglomerate, aims to reduce its carbon emission levels by 16% from 2020, in line with the Singapore government's pledge. This move is part of its sustainability plans, which also include labor practices and philanthropic efforts.

site_title: Paper group April under fire again from Greenpeace
summary: Greenpeace has accused pulp and paper group Asia Pacific Resources International Limited (April) of clearing rainforests and peatlands, despite claiming to be in full compliance with its sustainability policy. summary: Citic Resources Holdings Ltd, a commodities trading unit of China's Citic Group Corp, has begun court proceedings against the operator of a bonded warehouse at Qingdao port, alleging metals financing fraud. site_title: China equity market to be world's 2nd biggest: report
summary: China's equity market is projected to become the world's second-largest by 2030, surpassing the UK and Japan, with a market capitalization of US$54 trillion, according to a Credit Suisse report. summary: Foreign investors are bullish on Indian shares, driving up demand and pushing the S&P BSE Sensex index 14% last quarter and 23% so far in 2014. Cost projections have increased to 145 billion rupees, pushing back the estimated start date by at least four years. The project's development is part of Prime Minister Narendra Modi's infrastructure pledges, which also include building roads, bridges, ports, and railways.

site_title: Host nation's belief will help them prevail
summary: Brazil is 90 minutes away from hosting its own World Cup final at the Maracana Stadium, with the Selecao facing Germany in the semi-finals. Despite being without injured star Neymar and suspended captain Thiago Silva, Brazil remains confident in their ability to prevail. The team has a history of success at home, having not lost in their last 42 games, and is expected to win 1-0 against Germany, with a possible need for extra time.

site_title: Q&M Dental unveils plans to boost presence in Asia
