summary: Q&M Dental Group, a Singapore-listed dental services company, has unveiled plans to boost its presence in Asia, particularly in China and Malaysia. The company has completed its 108 million yuan (S$21.7 million) acquisition of a 60% stake in Aoxin Stomatology Group in China's Liaoning province. Q&M aims to move upstream to be its own dental-product supplier and downstream into dental distribution. The company has also announced plans to expand in other Asian markets, including a non-binding letter of intent with Baihe Stomatology Hospital in Changchun, Jilin Province.

site_title: Tenaga stake in power plant annoys Mitsui
summary: Malaysia's 1MDB has proposed partnering national utility Tenaga Nasional in a 2,000MW coal-fired power plant project, sparking discontent from Japanese partner Mitsui Co. Mitsui owns 30% of the joint venture, while 1MDB controls 70%. The decision was made despite a contract awarded by the Energy Commission five months prior. This move could lead to Japan's bank potentially blocking funds to 1MDB, as Mitsui has significant influence over the Japanese financial sector.

site_title: Proposed DBS senior unsecured notes get expected AA- rating
summary: DBS Group Holdings has received expected ratings of AA-(exp) and Aa2 from Fitch Ratings and Moody's Investors Service for its proposed US dollar-denominated senior unsecured notes, respectively. The notes are rated at the same level as DBS's 'AA-' Long-Term Issuer Default Rating, reflecting the good credit profile of its banking subsidiary, DBS Bank Ltd. The ratings account for DBS's status as a financial holding company and the structural subordination of its senior unsecured debt. The ratings are subject to change if DBS's IDR changes.

site_title: Savills appoints MD for investment sales
summary: Savills appoints Steven Ming as Managing Director of Investment Sales and Residential Services, overseeing business space, residential sales, and international residential sales. Ming, who joined Savills a decade ago, has led the team in closing $6 billion in investment transactions and has experience in prime collective sales and residential bulk transactions. He aims to galvanize the capabilities of the business to take it to a new level and consolidate the market position. The appointment is seen as a recognition of Ming's market leadership in Singapore and the South-east Asian region.

site_title: Retailers free to choose non-Reit landlords
summary: Retailers in Singapore have the freedom to choose non-Reit landlords for their mall leases, according to industry watchers. However, their options may soon narrow as other landlords adopt Reit-like practices and more malls come under Reit control. This freedom weakens retailers' grievances about Reit-owned malls imposing steep rental increments and unfair terms.

site_title: Time for a stewardship code for Singapore
summary: Singapore is lacking a comprehensive stewardship code to encourage institutional investors to take a more active role in corporate governance, similar to the UK's 2010 Stewardship Code. The country's 2012 Code of Corporate Governance included a statement on shareholder engagement but was deemed ineffective. Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam emphasized the need for balance between government regulation, market-based disclosure, and investor responsibility. Singapore is not alone in recognizing the importance of stewardship codes, with several countries, including Japan, South Africa, and Malaysia, adopting similar codes.

site_title: MOM minister backs COI's findings on riot
summary: Minister for Manpower Tan Chuan-Jin stated that the underlying cause of the Little India riot was not "systemic dissatisfaction" with employment and living conditions among foreign workers in Singapore. A recent survey of foreign workers found that 9 in 10 are satisfied with their work and plan to continue working in Singapore. The Committee of Inquiry's findings and the survey results back each other, contradicting previous claims.

site_title: Property price cap eased for Beijing developers: report
summary: China's Poly Real Estate Group received regulatory approval to price a Beijing project at 100,000 yuan (S$20,000) per square meter, easing the property price cap. This move signals a relaxation of pricing policies for developers in the capital. The approval comes after the Beijing municipal housing commission granted Poly the approval on June 14. This easing of price caps could help curb property speculation and boost confidence in the market, but may also drive up home prices, a concern for the central government.

site_title: Aussie construction index at 7-month high
summary: Australia's construction index reached a 7-month high in June, with the sector expanding for the first time this year. The index climbed 5.1 points to 51.8, above the 50 threshold separating growth from contraction. Home building activity led the rebound, with the house building measure reaching 56.6 and new orders surging 5.6 points to 60.1. The volatile apartment sector, however, dropped 16.7 points to 49.2.

site_title: GDF buys Lend Lease's UK facilities mgt unit
summary: French gas and power group GDF Suez has acquired Lend Lease's UK facilities management business through its Cofely unit, providing a £2.5 billion revenue stream. The deal follows Cofely's previous acquisition of Balfour Beatty's facilities management business for £190 million. Cofely aims to become Europe's largest provider of energy services for buildings by acquiring smaller peers. German industrial services company Bilfinger also has £1.1 billion available for acquisitions until 2015, competing with Cofely in the industry.

site_title: Strata-titled space beside HDB Hub for sale at $65m
summary: A prime retail shop in Toa Payoh Central, Singapore, is up for sale by tender at an indicative price of $65 million, averaging $11,245 per sq ft. The 5,780 sq ft strata-titled shop has a remaining 57-year lease and is located next to the HDB Hub, a popular shopping destination. The sale is seen as a rare opportunity due to the area's high human traffic and prime location, with monthly rents for similar units reaching $50 psf. The tender closes on August 12, with analysts expecting keen interest and competition for the property.

site_title: Swiss property, equity markets still at risk
summary: Switzerland's property and equity markets remain at risk due to the low interest rate environment, according to a Swiss National Bank (SNB) board member. The SNB set ultra-low interest rates to lower the appeal of the Swiss franc, leading to strong price increases in real estate and equities. Fritz Zurbruegg warned that the low rates pose risks to Swiss financial stability, making it challenging for the SNB to raise rates without conflicting with its goal to cap the franc.

site_title: As digital comes of age, customer markets are being remade
summary: Digital technology has revolutionized various sectors, enabling companies to create new business models, unlock opportunities in new industry segments, and boost growth. The convergence of existing technologies and large volumes of data are having a transformative effect, with companies embracing digital technologies to reinvent themselves and expand into new markets. As digitally-enabled companies collaborate with once distinct industries, digitally contestable markets are being created, offering higher growth than traditional sectors. Large companies are now driving disruption, incorporating digital technologies, and innovating in surprising ways, leading to industry sector reform and remade customer markets.

site_title: Prudence the key to FCT's stability
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT), a Singaporean retail real estate investment trust (Reit), has demonstrated stability and resilience despite the global financial crisis. Its suburban malls strategy and low gearing, with a gearing level of 27.7%, have contributed to its success. The Reit has delivered higher gross revenue and net property income every year since its listing in 2006. Its asset enhancement initiatives and prudent equity fund-raising have also helped maintain a sound capital structure. FCT is cautious about acquisitions and tenant mix, and is evaluating expansion into new markets such as Indonesia and Thailand.

site_title: Airbus undecided over A330neo launch at Farnborough Airshow
summary: Airbus has not decided whether to launch its proposed A330neo jet at the Farnborough Airshow, but its strategy chief Marwan Lahoud is confident about plane orders at the event. The A330neo, a more efficient version of the 20-year-old A330 jet, has completed technical work and is expected to go ahead soon, subject to board approval. Airbus is optimistic about the overall outlook for aircraft deals at the Farnborough Airshow, with Lahoud expecting a "good business dynamic" and "pretty confident" orders.

site_title: Apple said to headhunt Tag Heuer exec for iWatch
summary: Apple has reportedly hired Tag Heuer executive Patrick Pruniaux, who is leaving the luxury watch brand to join Apple, ahead of the expected launch of the iWatch this autumn. The move is seen as a strategic move by Apple to expand its presence in the personal luxury goods market. Analysts and industry executives are divided on the potential impact of smartwatches on the luxury Swiss watch industry, with some believing they may disrupt the market, while others see them as a threat only at lower price points.

site_title: Under one roof
summary: Singapore's JTC has launched new industrial facilities that aim to benefit small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) by providing cost savings and productivity improvements. The concept of shared facilities allows SMEs to outsource non-core activities and processes, leveraging the expertise of specialized operators or providers. This can be particularly beneficial for start-ups and SMEs in the services industry, such as accountancy firms, and for industries like the semi-conductor sector. However, challenges need to be addressed, including data privacy issues and re-designing business models. To overcome these challenges, incentives such as productivity improvement credits and free rentals for a few months may be offered.

site_title: Linc Energy to build UCG plant in Poland
summary: Linc Energy, a MAINBOARD-listed oil and gas producer, will start underground coal gasification (UCG) operations in Poland, transforming Europe's energy landscape. The firm has obtained initial approval for its first project near Krakow, with plans to conduct gas production trials and verification of its proprietary UCG process. Linc Energy aims to confirm that UCG can be operated safely and environmentally, with potential to replace 10 billion cubic meters of gas per annum for over 80 years.

site_title: France steps up passenger screening at airports
summary: France has stepped up passenger screening at its airports, implementing new security measures in response to US demands for extra security for US-bound flights due to concerns over Islamist radicals plotting new attacks using hard-to-detect bombs. The measures, which impact Europe's two busiest hubs, Heathrow and Charles de Gaulle, will focus on footwear and electronic items such as mobile phones and computers. US officials cited "real-time intelligence" behind the request, which also comes amid concerns about hundreds of Islamist radicals returning from fighting in the Middle East.

site_title: Vard buys engineering firm STX Canada Marine for $13m
summary: Vard Holdings acquired STX Canada Marine for $13.16 million, expanding its engineering and design capacity in North America. The acquisition, funded by internal resources, will enhance Vard's naval architecture and marine engineering services worldwide. The company currently has an order book of 38 ship designs, with 20 for offshore support vessels, and does not expect the deal to impact earnings. The deal is in line with Vard's strategy to grow its business in North America.

site_title: UC and the humble, enhanced deskphone
summary: A good Unified Communications (UC) strategy remains crucial in enterprises despite the increasing adoption of mobility and Bring-Your-Own-Device (BYOD) strategies. Desktop phones, often overlooked, still play a significant role in enterprise communications, with 70% of employees using them for traditional communication tools. Alcatel-Lucent Enterprise notes that UC convergence of multiple communication tools onto a single platform will drive growth, with the UC-as-a-service market predicted to reach $7.6 billion globally by 2018. Desktop phones are expected to remain relevant, with advancements in technology offering improved features and security, and are projected to grow at an average rate of 9.6% between 2011 and 2018.

site_title: Concentration and focus
summary: Germany's World Cup team has created a highly secure and isolated environment at their Campo Bahia fortress, shielding their players from fans, locals, and media. The team's "Konzentration und Fokussierung" philosophy emphasizes concentration and focus, leading to their success in the tournament. However, this approach has raised eyebrows, with locals and tourists unable to access the heavily guarded compound, and a jarring contrast to the relaxed atmosphere in the nearby village.

site_title: US housing boom spurs Asia shipments
summary: US housing boom boosts imports of furniture and building materials from Asia, with a 6.3% increase in the first four months of the year, the largest since 2007. Asian manufacturers, such as Li & Fung, are benefiting from the rebound in the US economy, with total US imports of furniture and building materials from Asia rising to 971,678 standard containers. The US housing market's growth is driving demand for furnishing and building materials, with analysts attributing the surge to higher sales and stable borrowing costs.

site_title: Game on pleasing customers
summary: There is no article provided for summarization. The content appears to be a list of news articles from various sources, but none of them match the prompt for summarization.

site_title: Why stocks didn't rally more dramatically last Friday
summary: US stocks closed at record highs last Friday after a strong jobs report, with 288,000 new jobs added and the unemployment rate dropping to 6.1%. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 92 points to 17,086, breaking the 17,000 milestone. Despite the strong report, stocks didn't rally more dramatically due to concerns over valuations and the potential for the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates, which was triggered by a rise in the 2-year Treasury note. The Fed's chairman Janet Yellen may reconsider its rate hike plans, and some economists believe the stock market can continue to climb as long as rate increases are small and gradual.

site_title: Small box, big bucks
summary: Vodoke, a set-top box firm, is set to reach $1 billion in revenue by the end of 2015, with sales expected to grow 10 times this year compared to last year. The company, which has already seen revenue soar 30% year-on-year, is in talks with telcos in Australasia and Asia to expand its customer base. Vodoke's set-top box, which runs on Android, can run both pay-TV broadcasts and stream internet content through apps and its browser. The firm aims to turn television screens into display panels for ads when not in use, and plans to dominate the living room with its set-top box.

site_title: Getting kids creative
summary: Xobon Magazine publishes a section called "Make" where it showcases artwork, doodles, sketches, and crafts made by kids, along with their stories. This initiative aims to encourage creativity in children. The magazine highlights the various forms of creativity, including making a piece of artwork, a craft, or a story.

site_title: Indian cuisine gets avant-garde edge
summary: Indian chef Abhijit Saha, known as the "Gordon Ramsay of India," has opened his first all-Indian restaurant, Saha Signature Indian Restaurant & Bar, in Singapore. The restaurant offers a modern twist on traditional Indian cuisine with Western flourishes, featuring dishes such as frozen dahi vada powder and Goan scallops marinated in a pickling mix of ginger, garlic, and mustard. The meal is accompanied by a knowledgeable sommelier who guides diners through the culinary journey. While some dishes may be too avant-garde, others, such as the coconut ice cream and fluffy fermented rice pancakes, are well-received. The restaurant receives a 7.5-star rating for its innovative and delicious take on Indian cuisine.

site_title: HetNet to allow for better connectivity
summary: Singapore is pushing for a "smart nation" through the use of HetNet, a type of network allowing seamless switching between 2G, 3G, 4G, and WiFi networks. This technology will help connect government agencies and improve spectrum utilization efficiency. HetNet can be used indoors and outdoors, providing a better user experience, and offers cost savings to operators. The Infocomm Development Authority of Singapore is conducting trials for HetNet, and the technology is being backed by multi-industry muscle, including the WiFi Alliance and Wireless Broadband Alliance.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: Retail rents may hold steady or increase slightly despite new supply entering the market due to healthy demand and "sticky" rent prices. Frasers Centrepoint Trust's CEO emphasizes caution and prudence in managing suburban retail properties. Meanwhile, companies like Vodoke and UOB are investing in new technologies, such as contactless payments and HetNet, to enhance connectivity and commerce. Bank Negara is expected to raise interest rates to combat inflation, and China is urging Southeast Asia to maintain openness despite US tariffs.

site_title: Asian firms more likely to embrace public cloud: survey
summary: Asian firms are more likely to adopt the public cloud, with 31% of businesses in the region making "significant investments" in it, compared to 25% globally. The cloud is the top spending priority in technology for companies in Asia, driven by the desire to be more agile and handle spikes in demand from visitors. IT departments in the region are using the cloud for backend needs, such as storage and computing on demand, and companies trust their systems to third-party vendors, with cost being the third-ranked reason for adoption.

site_title: Soul and humanness
summary: German carpenter Till-Oliver Kautz suggests that "good hand-made furniture" is a key factor in creating great conversation pieces in a home, making mass-produced furniture harder to compete.

site_title: Buying stays flat, selling among directors rises
summary: Buying activity was flat for the second consecutive week, with 15 companies purchasing shares worth $4.9 million. Selling activity increased, with 6 companies disposing of shares worth $6.3 million. Buyback activity declined, with 7 firms repurchasing shares worth $7.7 million. Insider purchases were recorded in Singapore Airlines, Xyec Holdings, and Dynamic Colours Limited, while insider sales were reported in Haw Par Corporation, Chew's Group, and Communication Design International. The trading was spread across several sectors, with notable buybacks in Singapore Airlines and Xyec Holdings.

site_title: Asean airports seen gaining from China tourism
summary: ASEAN airports are well-positioned to capture China's long-term growth in outbound travel, with rising incomes and less-restrictive travel rules expected to drive growth. Barclays forecasts 5.8% global air traffic volume increase in 2014, with 21% growth in outbound Chinese travel. Airports of Thailand is singled out as a global infrastructure asset best-placed to benefit from this trend, trading at 18.1 times 2015 PE.

site_title: Starting them young
summary: A Japanese firm, Life is Tech, offers an IT program for junior high and high school students in Japan, teaching them to design apps, game design, and animation skills. The program has taught over 3,000 students across several cities and aims to bring it to Singapore. The program uses Objective-C and GameSalad to teach programming and game development skills. Over 30 students have gone on to develop and publish apps sold on Apple's App store, and two students have started their own programming companies. The next IT camp is scheduled for December, costing $599.

site_title: Transcu plans capital reduction to write off losses
summary: TRANSCU Group plans to undertake a $734.38 million capital reduction exercise to write off accumulated losses of $744.4 million, aiming to rationalize its balance sheet. The firm intends to reduce its share capital to $2, seeking shareholder approval for the move. This follows the firm's listing on the Singapore Exchange's watch-list since December 2014.

site_title: Herbal remedy
summary: Larry Lim and Nelson Kwek have created HerbBot, an indoor aquaponics system that combines aquaculture and hydroponics to grow herbs and vegetables without sunlight. The system uses LED grow lights and a bacteria process to convert fish waste into natural fertilizer. Each handmade unit costs around $200, and an advanced version uses solar power and a moisture sensor system. HerbBot aims to provide fresh organic herbs and vegetables at home while promoting sustainability and reducing food waste.

site_title: Why over-insuring is not that assuring
summary: The MediShield Life Review Committee's report revealed that three in five Singaporeans covered under MediShield purchased Integrated Shield Plans (IPs), with seven in 10 choosing lower ward classes in public hospitals despite having IPs targeting Class A wards. This suggests that many consumers are over-insuring, as they opt for lower-cost treatment options instead of the more comprehensive coverage offered by IPs. The finding highlights the potential for overbuying of IPs and underscores the need for consumers to carefully consider their healthcare needs and costs.

site_title: Having a swinging good time
summary: PwC Singapore is participating in the League, a golf tournament, as part of the social category. The team of seven is focusing on enjoying the game and building relationships with fellow business community members. Team captain Soh Kok Leong emphasizes the event's well-organized nature and the opportunity for social interaction. This marks PwC's first League participation in its inaugural year.

site_title: SIA plane in near miss at Houston airport
summary: A near miss incident occurred at Houston's George Bush Intercontinental Airport on Thursday night, where a Singapore Airlines plane failed to level off at 4,000 feet, resulting in a less-than-2,000-foot separation from a Delta Air Lines plane. The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) is investigating the incident, which happened about 10 miles north-east of the airport. The FAA stated that a loss of required separation occurred in airspace controlled by the Houston Terminal Radar Approach Control.

site_title: Hiap Hoe and Aspial to launch luxury apartments in Melbourne
summary: Singapore property developers Hiap Hoe and Aspial are launching luxury apartments in Melbourne, Australia. Hiap Hoe's Marina Tower Melbourne has 461 freehold units, priced from A$400,000 to A$2 million, while Aspial's 319-meter-tall skyscraper will offer one-bedroom apartments starting at A$450,000. The move reflects a growing trend of overseas expansion for Singapore developers, driven by the less favorable Singapore property market and Australia's buoyant market.

site_title: All signs point to Brazil-Argentina exciting final
summary: The 2014 World Cup is down to its final four, with Brazil, Germany, Argentina, and the Netherlands set to face off in the semifinals. Brazil, without injured Neymar, aims to win a record sixth World Cup title, while Germany seeks its fourth straight semi-final appearance. The Netherlands, after a thrilling 1-0 win over Costa Rica, will meet Argentina in the other semifinal. Whoever advances will face the other team in the final, with the winner likely to rewrite history and claim the championship.

site_title: Property prices could dip further: Tharman
summary: Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam has raised the possibility of a further correction in Singapore's property market. He stated that a crash in the market is unlikely, but further correction would not be unexpected. Tharman emphasized the need for more emphasis on supervising banks and financial institutions, citing the need for stricter regulations to mitigate risks. He also expressed concerns that excessive regulation may hinder growth, and called for a balance between regulation and service expectations, encouraging customers to take more initiative and not rely on others for services.

site_title: China firms help punters bet on World Cup
summary: China's internet giants Alibaba and Tencent have linked up with state-owned provincial lotteries to enable online betting on the World Cup, bypassing the country's strict betting laws. The platforms offer odds betting on most game aspects and have attracted over 10 billion yuan in bets, dwarfing the 2.3 billion yuan from the 2010 finals. However, insurance firms have found their attempts to offer World Cup-related policies meeting official disapproval, and most Chinese sports betting takes place through outlawed websites. The issue of illegal gambling is serious, with estimates suggesting 500 billion yuan was spent during the 2006 tournament.

site_title: Another step forward for APS transformation plan
summary: APS Strategic Investments, a Singaporean firm, has sold its entire interest in HMS Capital Sdn Bhd, a bereavement care services firm, to executive director Heng Aik Koon for RM10.7 million. This sale is part of APS's transformation plan to shift into the mining industry, following a $500 million reverse takeover of Coeur Gold Armenia. The disposal is expected to result in a deficit of RM98.5 million, but is seen as a step towards enhancing shareholder value through potential cash flow and expansion in the mineral mining business.

site_title: A safe and friendly Brazil invites you
summary: A traveler who recently visited Sao Paulo, Brazil, disagrees with concerns over the city's safety and infrastructure during the World Cup. The city has a palpable police presence, and security measures, such as ticket checks and military deployments, are in place to ensure a safe experience. The traveler found the infrastructure to be adequate, public transport to be reliable and affordable, and the taxi service to be honest and comfortable. The atmosphere in Brazil is electric, and the city's friendly and warm residents make it an ideal destination for World Cup fans.

site_title: Etihad hits back at critics of its investment policy
summary: Etihad Airways' CEO James Hogan defended the airline's investment policy, stating that European carriers would face significant job cuts and possible collapse without its support. Hogan claimed external investment is an opportunity to strengthen airlines and support employment and economic growth. He pointed out that Etihad has not received state aid, unlike European operators, and that the industry's issues predate Etihad's establishment in 2003. Hogan also criticized the impact of Gulf carriers on European aviation, attributing challenges to factors such as high labour and airport costs, under-investment in hubs, and inequitable taxes.

site_title: JES to acquire 51% stake in Scibois
summary: JES International, a Chinese shipbuilding firm, agreed to buy 51% of Scibois Co Limited for an undisclosed amount. Scibois owns a 75% stake in STE, a timber extraction company in Congo, with a forest harvesting license until 2036. The deal is expected to increase JES's revenue streams and enhance its earnings stability. JES chairman and CEO Jin Xin stated that the acquisition will provide the company with increased independence from the cyclical shipbuilding industry and bring value to its shareholders. The acquisition terms include a US$170 million guarantee and a US$450 million market capitalization target.

site_title: OCBC's takeover bid for Wing Hang now 'unconditional'
summary: OCBC Bank's takeover bid for Wing Hang Bank has become unconditional after holding over 50.4% of the Hong Kong lender's shares. This move comes after hedge-fund firm Elliott Management increased its stake to 7.8%, worth HK$3 billion. OCBC's offer, valued at HK$38.4 billion, still faces challenges, as it needs to own 90% of Wing Hang shares to delist the company, a tougher proposition with Elliott holding a larger stake.

site_title: Team Citi take early lead
summary: Team Citi took an early lead in the Business Times Corporate Golf League, scoring 105 points in the first round. Defending champions Team SunMoon came in second with 103 points, followed by SPH Sultans of Swing with 104 points. The top 10 teams are separated by only 11 points, indicating a close competition. Team Citi captain Chris Chew attributed the result to favorable rule changes and his team playing to their handicaps.

site_title: Helping hands
summary: A group of 4 volunteers in Singapore, part of the e-Nable community, have been 3D printing prosthetic hands for children in need. Led by Zhang Yuanjun, the team has printed two hands, including one for a 3-year-old child and a demonstration model. The designs are available for download on the e-Nable website, with the team planning to introduce the project to hospitals and social welfare groups. The 3D printed hands are less costly than conventional prosthetics and can be adapted as the child grows. The team aims to raise awareness and encourage more volunteers to join the project.

site_title: A great way to enjoy Formula 1 Singapore race
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) has partnered with the Singapore GP to offer Formula 1 Singapore Grand Prix packages, targeting affluent travelers and frequent-flyer members. The packages range from basic to luxurious, including F1 tickets, hotel accommodation, and exclusive experiences. The airline aims to boost traffic and promote its network during the race week. SIA has introduced special offers for its PPS Club and KrisFlyer members, and the packages are available until August 15. The partnership is seen as a strategic move for SIA to tap into the global F1 audience and capitalize on the event's popularity.

site_title: M1 wins tender for Digital TV Assistance Scheme
summary: M1 has won a tender to supply and install digital TV equipment for low-income households under Singapore's Digital TV Assistance Scheme. The contract, worth no material impact on M1's earnings, will provide set-top boxes and indoor antennas to eligible households, along with a complimentary installation service. The scheme aims to support 160,000 to 170,000 households in receiving free-to-air TV channels after the country switches to digital broadcasting by 2020. The Media Development Authority plans to launch the scheme in September.

site_title: Subianto takes fight to Widodo's turf as polls show shift
summary: Former Indonesian general Prabowo Subianto plans to campaign in Central Java, Widodo's home province, after a recent poll shows a significant shift in public opinion. Subianto, trailing behind Governor Joko Widodo, is seeking endorsements and connections to reach voters. A recent survey shows Subianto's support at 43% compared to Widodo's 46%. Subianto's campaign has raised concerns about his authoritarian bent and comments opposing "Western-style democracy". His campaign officials are moving quickly to capitalize on the shift in public opinion, with a focus on building local connections to aid his cause.

site_title: More Medisave contribution for civil servants
summary: Singapore's government will increase Medisave contributions for civil servants starting January 2015, with 85% of 82,000 civil servants receiving an additional 2% of their pay, capped at $140. Officers earning $2,500 or less will receive a minimum of $50. The move aims to help civil servants with in-patient medical needs and benefit from the new MediShield Life national health insurance scheme. Government pensioners will also receive an additional Medisave contribution, with 40% receiving an extra 1% starting in 2015.

site_title: Tembusu Partners invests US$7.5m in coal assets
summary: Tembusu Partners has invested US$7.5 million in Param Mitra Coal Resources Pte Ltd (PMCR), a Singapore-registered coal company with two operating mines in Indonesia. The investment is part of a US$20 million deal underwritten by Islamic Bank of Asia. PMCR aims to expand production to 5 million tonnes per year and plans an initial public offering. The company is backed by the Sindhu family, which has invested over US$50 million in the Indonesian coal assets.

site_title: The ultimate crossover?
summary: Lexus's NX compact SUV is the brand's first premium urban sports gear, boasting a striking design with sharp surfaces and protruding wheel arch flares. The NX200t features a turbocharged 2.0-liter engine with 235 hp and 350 Nm, offering an alternative to the hybrid powertrain. Developed by assistant chief engineer Sunao Ichihara, the turbo engine can switch between cycles automatically for greater efficiency and performance. With a 16,000 km service interval, the NX could mark a new era for Lexus, taking on models like the Audi Q5 and BMW X3 in the luxury compact crossover market.

site_title: Indonesia's Japfa planning S'pore IPO: sources
summary: Japfa Ltd, controlled by Indonesia's Santosa family, plans to raise at least $250 million through an initial public offering (IPO) in Singapore, managed by Credit Suisse Group AG and DBS Group Holdings Ltd. The company breeds and processes chicken, pork, and beef, and operates dairy farms in China. Japfa's Jakarta-listed unit has a market value of 13.1 trillion rupiah ($1.4 billion). The IPO is currently gauging investor demand and is expected to start marketing this month.

site_title: Intraco to take 70% stake in KA Group for $16.6m
summary: INTRACO Limited has entered into a deal to acquire a 70% stake in fire protection specialist KA Group for $16.6 million. The acquisition aims to expand Intraco's revenue base and improve profitability. KA Group's strong business growth and double-digit profit margins make it an attractive target. The deal will be funded by Intraco's internal resources, with the first $3.15 million paid in new shares and the balance in cash. Following the acquisition, KA Group will be reorganized and wholly owned by a new holding company, with Intraco owning 70% and vendors owning 30%.

site_title: Offshore interest in Chinese equities boosts SGX China A50 futures
summary: Singapore's SGX China A50 Index Futures saw a 21.1% surge in open interest to a 17-month high in June, reaching US$2.2 billion, driven by offshore interest in Chinese equities. Average daily turnover grew 21% to US$762 million. The move comes as China's economy may be gaining strength, with the Purchasing Managers' Index reaching its highest in six months. Liquidity conditions are expected to improve in the second half of 2014, with Chinese banks allowed to remove loans from scrutiny.

site_title: Outward bound
summary: Business Times reports on various global market developments. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription. US stocks opened lower following Trump's tariff announcement on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss in H2. London's Heathrow Airport plans to increase fees for its £10 billion upgrade. In Indonesia, a Trafigura employee was detained in a graft case. Tan Teck Long, a former DBS executive, is set to become OCBC's incoming CEO.

site_title: Dow's topping of 17,000 fails to rub off on STI
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed above 17,000 for the first time, but the impact was muted, with trading remaining in penny territory. The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 17 points to 3,289, but then drifted to a net loss of 0.9 point, with turnover being poor. Support for the STI came from United Overseas Bank, with its counter rising 30 cents to $23.80. Analysts attributed this to broking firm recommendations, with Macquarie Equities Research seeing good potential for UOB to maintain profitability.

site_title: Big on the small stuff
summary: Japanese chef Hideaki Matsuo insists on making everything from scratch, even when traveling abroad, to ensure authentic results. His three Michelin-starred restaurant Kashiwaya in Osaka is a testament to his dedication to traditional Japanese cooking. Matsuo's philosophy is influenced by his physics background and his father's restaurant, which has stood since 1868. He travels extensively to learn from other chefs and incorporates local ingredients into his dishes. Despite his global influence, Matsuo prioritizes traditional Japanese cooking and teaches his young chefs to maintain these techniques.

site_title: Global economies need structural reform
summary: Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam emphasized the need for structural reform in economies worldwide, citing Asia's transition from an "easy" growth phase to a more complex one driven by productivity gains and restructuring. He noted that Singapore, despite having a high per capita GDP, is not yet an advanced economy due to low productivity levels. Tharman highlighted the need for governments to invest in skills and ingenuity, create incentives for innovation, and address legacy issues in countries like China, India, and Indonesia. He also warned of risks in advanced economies, including prolonged subnormal growth and over-reliance on central banks, stressing the importance of structural reform to address these challenges.

site_title: Japanese-French mix
summary: Radio host Darren Wee has launched his second restaurant venture, Babette, a 64-seater French-Japanese fusion restaurant in the Parc Sovereign Hotel. The restaurant offers a range of dishes, including duck confit donburi, pork and bacon hamburg donburi, and steak and foie gras donburi. Wee aims to create a casual, unpretentious atmosphere, with a "mix and match" brunch option. The restaurant reflects Wee's passion for food and his experience hosting a local radio show, where he discussed the importance of detail in the food industry.

site_title: T-shirt festival fetes self-expression
summary: The first Singapore T-shirt Festival was launched on July 1, showcasing the T-shirt as a medium for self-expression and its influence on street culture. Organised by Joseph Chiang and Legendary Social Tees, the festival features a month-long exhibition, marketplace, talks, and workshops. 22 designers, including well-known creative directors, have contributed to the project, creating unique T-shirt designs that reflect their individual styles and perspectives. The festival runs until July 29 at the National Design Centre, with T-shirts available for sale at $50 each.

site_title: A love for all things 'ugly'
summary: Ken Tan, a creative director, has furnished his home with unusual and unattractive items he likes, despite others finding them ugly. The two-bedroom apartment features industrial elements, exposed structural beams, and raw cement flooring. Tan has incorporated his art collection, including pieces by Futura and Kaz Oshrio, into the space, which he calls "industrial pragmatism." The home's minimalist kitchen and bathroom tiles are complemented by statement pieces, such as a sleek cooker hood and a rug made from war rugs. Tan's wife, Jennifer, collects tribal and geometric rugs, adding to the eclectic decor.

site_title: Loyal League supporter gunning for Top 5
summary: TAT HONG, a team from The Crane Boomers, is competing in the League with the goal of reaching the Top 5. The team's captain, Michael Ng, emphasizes the importance of bonding and having fun during the competition. This year's team includes 11 members, each with their own handicap rating. The team's participation in the League has been consistent since its inception in 2010, driven by the challenges and opportunities it provides.

site_title: Small wonder
summary: The Volkswagen Golf 1.2 TSI boasts a punchy turbocharged engine, delivering 105 horsepower and impressive performance, especially in urban settings. The 7-speed dual-clutch gearbox and lightweight construction enable smooth acceleration, making it a competent choice. Although the engine size is small, it performs well, with minimal turbo lag. The Golf's handling and stability are also notable, making it a solid option for city driving. However, the basic interior features and limited amenities are a drawback, with some features like keyless entry and climate control missing.

site_title: Fresh F&B faces
summary: Three young entrepreneurs, including Frederick Yap, are making a name for themselves in the F&B industry, having transitioned from the fashion, music, and design industries. Their restaurants, such as Pince and Pints and Thevar 2.0, offer unique dining experiences. The entrepreneurs aim to bring new perspectives to the industry, showcasing fresh concepts and cuisine.

site_title: The BT-Coca-Cola World Cup Charity Drive
summary: A charity drive, BT-Coca-Cola World Cup, has been initiated. The Asean region has agreed that Myanmar's election is not a priority, with Malaysia expressing its stance. US weekly jobless claims have fallen unexpectedly. China urges South-east Asia to support openness amidst US tariffs. Chinese property shares surged on unverified reports of a meeting to revive the sector. Reliance Jio, led by Ambani, has delayed its India IPO beyond this year. China has unveiled new steps to aid employment amid trade tensions.

site_title: ING sets its sights on commercial banking in Asia
summary: ING Group is focusing on commercial banking in Asia, aiming for 20% of its commercial banking unit's revenue from the region in 3-5 years. The bank is building a niche position in financing complex trade transactions, setting itself apart from other banks. ING operates in 14 Asian markets and is well-placed in Europe, where it has a retail banking arm to collect deposits. The bank is also adapting to changing regulations and the rise of Asian banks in trade finance.

site_title: High potential seen for HPL's west Orchard assets
summary: OCBC analyst Eli Lee suggests that HPL's West Orchard assets are ripe for revitalization and a potential mega-development could revamp the area. The site, encompassing 212,000 square feet, could yield up to $1.25 billion in surplus net present value if transformed into a mixed-use retail development. With the upcoming completion of Orchard Boulevard MRT station in 2021, the area is expected to see increased foot traffic, and the URA Master Plan offers bonus GFA allowances and cash grant incentives for pedestrian links.

site_title: Iraq war III not a viable option
summary: US President Barack Obama is under pressure to aid Iraqi Prime Minister Nouri al-Maliki's government against the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (ISIL) but a third Iraq war is deemed unlikely due to the country's deep-seated sectarian divisions and the semi-independence of the Kurdish region. There are no signs of a deal between Shiites and Sunnis, with ISIL gaining support from Sunni minorities due to the failure of Maliki's government to provide equal opportunities in sharing power in Baghdad.

site_title: Reimagined Butterfly on a small stage
summary: Deaf actor-director Ramesh Meyyappan has been honoured with two Best Actor trophies at the Life! Theatre Awards for his performances in plays he acted in and directed himself. Despite his achievements, he remains relatively unknown compared to other LTA winners. His upcoming production, "Butterfly," will be performed by three actors at the Esplanade Theatre Studio from July 17-19, showcasing his talent in a small-scale setting. Meyyappan's low profile may be attributed to staging short-run productions, unlike his more famous peers.

site_title: Making hands meet
summary: The inaugural learning festival Makers' Block in Singapore showcased nearly 50 participants, including cardboard sculptor Bartholomew Ting, who creates robots, animals, and other structures using everyday materials. The festival celebrates the makers' culture with a focus on art and technology, featuring activities such as 3D printing and electronics soldering. Organiser William Hooi hopes the event will inspire local makers and encourage Singaporeans to work with their hands, promoting a sense of pride and individual accomplishment. The festival aims to mark the start of similar events and provide opportunities for makers to exhibit and market their work.

site_title: Michaelson hones a new voice with collaborators
summary: American singer-songwriter Ingrid Michaelson released a music video for her single "Girls Chase Boys" in February 2014, inspired by Robert Palmer's 1988 hit "Simply Irresistible." The video featured Michaelson singing in front of a row of dancing men in make-up and high heels. Despite receiving vicious YouTube comments, Michaelson remains undaunted.

site_title: Dark secrets from a desert tomb
summary: Deliver Us From Evil, a film about demonic possession and paranormal phenomena, follows New York cop-turned-demonologist Ralph Sarchie (Eric Bana) as he investigates a series of unexplained and sinister events with the help of a priest, Mendoza (Edgar Ramirez). The film, based on a real-life book, explores the concept of primary and secondary evil, but ultimately falls into standard fright-fest fare. Despite its attempts to deliver chills, the movie is deemed mediocre, with a rating of C.

site_title: Well-respected US journalist retires at 85
summary: Carol Loomis, a renowned US journalist and Warren Buffett expert, is retiring at 85 after 60 years at Fortune magazine. A trailblazer in the male-dominated field, Loomis battled gender stereotypes and became one of the most respected financial journalists in the US. She wrote extensively on Wall Street, including articles on hedge funds, derivatives, and accounting scandals, and edited the annual Berkshire Hathaway shareholder letter for nearly 40 years. Loomis will be remembered for her analytical mind, dedication to journalism, and her close friendship with Warren Buffett.

site_title: Why Asia does poorly in the World Cup
summary: Asia's poor performance in the World Cup can be attributed to the lack of a competitive international landscape in the region. Despite significant investment in youth development and increased European league presence, teams such as Japan and South Korea have regressed, citing inflexibility and a lack of drive. The root problem lies in the absence of meaningful competitive matches, with the Asia Cup offering weaker teams and few opportunities to play against major footballing nations. To improve, Japan and South Korea can create new tournaments or invest in improving the footballing infrastructure of other Asian nations, potentially benefiting from a more competitive landscape.

site_title: June job growth surges, jobless rate falls to 6.1%
summary: US employment growth surged in June, with non-farm payrolls increasing by 288,000 jobs, and the unemployment rate falling to 6.1%, its lowest level since September 2008. This strong jobs growth, combined with robust car sales and a steady manufacturing expansion, suggests that the economy's momentum is intact. The Dow Jones Industrial Average reached 17,000 points for the first time, and economists expect the labor market to continue tightening, potentially leading to a debate on the timing of the first interest rate increase by the Federal Reserve.

site_title: Keppel confirms US$735m LNG vessel conversion deal
summary: Keppel Shipyard has confirmed a US$735 million contract with Golar Hilli Corporation to convert an existing Moss LNG carrier into a floating liquefaction vessel (FLNGV). The conversion project is expected to take 31 months and be completed in the first quarter of 2017. This deal marks another collaboration between Keppel Shipyard and Golar LNG, following the delivery of the world's first floating storage and regasification unit (FSRU) in 2008. The global FLNG industry is expected to attract over US$65 billion in investments through 2020, driven by rising costs of onshore LNG terminals.

site_title: Ceramics cross cultures in rare exhibition
summary: A rare cross-border ceramic art exhibition is underway in Singapore, featuring five artists from the Asean region: Singapore's Alvin Tan Teck Heng, Thailand's Bathma Kaew-Ngok, Indonesia's Dr Ahadiat Joedawinata, the Philippines' Jon Lorenzo Pettyjohn, and Malaysia's Peter Low Hwee Min. The exhibition, titled "Ceramicship," showcases the artists' unique styles and techniques, influenced by their respective countries' cultural and artistic traditions. The show runs until July 31 and highlights the diversity of ceramic art in South-east Asia, with a growing interest in the region's potters in Europe and America.

site_title: Hitting the high notes
summary: Irish filmmaker John Carney's new indie rom-com Begin Again is a lo-fi love letter to New York, featuring Keira Knightley as a talented singer-songwriter who breaks up with her cheating boyfriend, played by Adam Levine. The film showcases Knightley's acting and vocal chops, with a tasty soundtrack. The movie follows Gretta's journey as she navigates the music industry, highlighting her growth and self-discovery. Carney's direction and the film's charm have been praised, making Begin Again a delightful and endearing musical romance.

site_title: Company Briefs
summary: Unionmet, a Singaporean metals trader, has partnered with ICES to conduct R&D in oil blending, with Spring Singapore subsidizing up to 70% of their salaries. Aspial Corporation issued $45 million in notes maturing in 2019, while Tiong Seng Holdings issued $75 million in notes maturing in 2018. GYP's acquisition of Gloria Jean's Coffees has been canceled after the vendor failed to fulfill conditions. Meanwhile, NTT DC Reit's public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times, and Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall.

site_title: New HBO series The Leftovers leaves plenty to chew on
summary: The HBO series "The Leftovers" premieres on cable, based on Tom Perrotta's novel and executive produced by Damon Lindelof. The show centers on a mysterious incident where 2% of the world's population vanishes without explanation. The pilot episode features a disturbing scene where a mother's wish is granted in a grim manner. The series explores the aftermath of the event, leaving the audience with many unanswered questions and a desire for more.

site_title: KL banker Nazir Razak loosens grip at CIMB
summary: Malaysia's second-largest bank, CIMB Group, is undergoing a leadership transition with CEO Nazir Razak stepping down on September 1 to become chairman. Razak, 48, has served as CEO for 15 years and has been succeeded by Tengku Zafrul Aziz, who joined the bank in January as CEO of its investment bank. Razak's decision to relinquish his executive role was not unexpected, as he had "loosened" his day-to-day responsibilities in recent years and had been spending more time in London. The move is seen as a healthy transition, with Zafrul bringing fresh thinking and energy to the role.

site_title: Ray of light, even in a hailstorm
summary: Hailstorms in Burgundy's 2013 harvest reduced crop yields by 25-70% in the Cote de Beaune region, with the most severely affected areas being Volnay, Pommard, and Meursault. Despite the damage, the remaining 2013 crop showed excellent quality, with many wines from the affected regions being of high quality. The region's wine producers, including Domaine Lafon, Domaine Faiveley, and Domaine Louis Jadot, reported similar features in their wines from barrel samples, including ripeness, freshness, and length. The reduced quantities of 2013 Burgundies have led to increased prices for 2010 and 2011 vintages.

site_title: Asia-Pacific air traffic volumes in May up 7.3%
summary: Air traffic volumes in the Asia-Pacific region increased by 7.3% year-on-year in May, surpassing the global industry's 6.2% growth rate. The expansion is attributed to a pick-up in China's economy, which is expected to sustain air travel growth in the coming months. The Middle East and Latin America also reported significant growth, with 13.2% and 9.1% increases, respectively. Passenger load factor in the Asia-Pacific region was 74.1%, driven by a 7.5% capacity growth.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: Malaysia's CIMB Group CEO, Nazir Razak, steps down as top banker. ING Group expects 20% of its Asian commercial banking revenue to come from the region in 3-5 years. US job growth surged in June, with an unemployment rate of 6.1%. A gas swap re-routes Indonesian piped natural gas to Singapore. DBS remains Singapore's most valuable brand, while Malaysia's construction firms secured RM7b of jobs in Q2. China's services sector expanded strongly, and the high-yield bond market is poised for a strong second half.

site_title: ECB ready for QE if current measures don't work
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is prepared to implement quantitative easing (QE) if current measures do not yield the desired results in lifting inflation and supporting bank lending. ECB President Mario Draghi stated that the bank's recent policy measures, including a negative deposit rate and extended cheap liquidity, will be reviewed. The measures are set to last until the end of 2016, and the ECB is ready to create more money if necessary to stimulate the economy.

site_title: OCBC sites 2nd largest outlet at Orchard
summary: OCBC Bank has opened its second-largest branch at orchardgateway, catering to affluent customers, youth, and young professionals. The three-storey branch features distinct spaces for each customer segment. This move comes as banks seek sticky deposits to fund operations amid a hunger for customer loyalty in Singapore.

site_title: Developers in US reviving condo-hotel concept
summary: US developers are reviving the condo-hotel concept, combining luxury homes with full-service hotels to attract financing and premium prices. The trend is driven by a rebounding hospitality market and rising demand for luxury homes. Developers like Ian Schrager and Richard LeFrak are building projects with high-end brands, offering amenities such as restaurants, concierges, and maintenance services. This concept can provide long-term cash flow for developers and create a premium for residential units associated with a hotel brand. Experts warn that overbuilding and operational risks remain, but the trend is expected to continue.

site_title: AirAsia's India venture to break even only in Dec
summary: AirAsia India, a joint venture between AirAsia, Tata Group, and Telestra Tradeplace, expects to break even in December, later than initially planned October, due to delays in plane deliveries and increased investment in the fleet. The airline had initially projected a profit in October but now anticipates a break-even point in December. This delay will make AirAsia India stand out among India's major airlines, which have struggled with high costs and low fares, resulting in rapid cash losses in a highly competitive market.

site_title: Mapletree's Viet mall evokes strong response
summary: Mapletree Investments' first shopping mall in Vietnam, SC VivoCity, has secured pre-leasing commitments for over 52% of its space ahead of its scheduled opening in the first half of next year. The mall, developed jointly by Mapletree and Saigon Co-op Investment Development Joint Stock Company, has signed agreements with 13 retailers, including CGV, BreadTalk, and Starbucks. The mall will have a gross floor area of 62,000 sq m and is part of a 4.4 ha mixed-use development in Ho Chi Minh City.

site_title: China drugmaker in US$764m IPO
summary: Luye Pharma Group, a Chinese drugmaker backed by Singapore's sovereign wealth fund, is set to raise US$764 million from a Hong Kong initial public offering. The company will sell shares at HK$5.92 apiece, with existing investors and new shareholders contributing to the offering. This will be Hong Kong's largest pharmaceutical IPO in over three years, surpassing Sihuan Pharmaceutical's 2010 offering of US$852 million.

site_title: Appy ever after
summary: Mobile dating apps are changing the way singles find partners, with many apps now gaining popularity in Singapore. Apps like Paktor, LOLA, and Kehmistry offer various features, such as curated matches and location-based dating. According to a Pew Research Centre study, one in 10 people in the US have used online dating sites or apps. Experts say the key to success lies in taking the conversation offline and building connections in person. Despite concerns from traditional dating agencies, mobile dating apps are expected to continue growing, with some founders believing they can eventually replace traditional services.

site_title: Firm linked to Tung Chee-hwa fined over exec's death
summary: Orient Overseas Container Line (OOCL), a shipping company linked to former Hong Kong government chief executive Tung Chee-hwa, has been fined 50,000 euros (S$85,079) for the 2003 death of top executive Courtenay Allan in France. The ruling followed a long campaign by Allan's sons, who claimed the company's negligence led to the lift malfunction that killed their father. The verdict was seen as a victory for the Allan family after years of investigation, but OOCL has 10 days to appeal the ruling.

site_title: Mitsubishi Estate bonds lead gains on Olympic hopes
summary: Mitsubishi Estate's bonds have led gains in Japan this year, with a 2% return, driven by expectations of a windfall from the 2020 Tokyo Olympic Games. The nation's top developers reported the highest combined annual profit since 2008, with Mitsubishi Estate's net income jumping 41% to 64.3 billion yen. The International Olympic Committee forecasts 152 billion yen in investment into Tokyo's properties, boosting land prices and urban renewal. This has bolstered balance sheets of real estate companies, generating considerable unrealised gains.

site_title: Paean to Indonesia's sea gypsies
summary: Contemporary artist Zai Kuning's solo exhibition "We Are Home & Everywhere" explores the lives of Indonesia's sea gypsies, known as Orang Laut. Through 16 artworks, Kuning comments on their nomadic lifestyle and struggle to maintain their identity amidst development and marginalization. The exhibition features a large installation resembling a ghostly ship, alongside sculptures, assemblages, and paperworks. Kuning emphasizes the importance of preserving the sea gypsies' way of life, which he believes is in danger of being erased by the Indonesian authorities' push for them to settle down.

site_title: Stock markets not bubbling over: Bank of S'pore
summary: Bank of Singapore's chief investment officer Hou Wey Fook stated that global stock markets are not in a bubble, despite historic highs. He expressed confidence in stocks reaching higher levels in the next six to 12 months, citing the bull market's ability to continue. However, Hou noted that the ride will be bumpier in the sixth year of a bull market.

site_title: Spanish artist etches his name in engraving
summary: Spanish artist Juan Ripolles, 82, is set to showcase his retrospective exhibition "Ripolles, The Colours of Life" at the Galerie Belvedere in Singapore from July 10 to July 31. The exhibition features a range of bronze and Murano glass sculptures, oil paintings, and grabados (an engraving technique) works from 1999 to 2014. Ripolles, known for his vibrant and colourful pieces, has a global exhibition schedule, including China, Paris, and Berlin, and has been exhibiting at major galleries and museums worldwide for 50 years.

site_title: Unmasking natural beauty
summary: Organic skincare may not always be as effective or environmentally friendly as it seems. While some brands, like Neal's Yard Remedies, prioritize transparency and sustainability, others may label products as "organic" without containing any organic ingredients. To ensure a truly natural product, consumers should check the ingredient list, particularly the first three ingredients, which account for 90-95% of the product. Some brands may use non-natural "functional ingredients" despite being certified organic, and the certification standards may not keep pace with advancements in cosmetic science.

site_title: Intimacy under the stars
summary: Australian choreographer Natalie Weir's new piece "Bittersweet" will be performed at Singapore Dance Theatre's Ballet Under the Stars, a world premiere as part of the annual park performance. The intimate duet, featuring a male and female pas de deux, reflects Weir's love of partner work and explores the bittersweet moments of a relationship. The piece will be performed by different dancers over two weekends, July 18-20 and July 25-27, with tickets starting from $20. Weir, who has choreographed for the Queensland Ballet and The Australian Ballet, created "Bittersweet" specifically with the dancers of Singapore Dance Theatre.

site_title: Is there wood in your burger?
summary: A Quartz article sparked concern that fast food chains like McDonald's and Burger King contain wood pulp, or cellulose, in their menu items. However, experts say cellulose is a natural dietary fiber with no nutritional value, and its presence in fast food is not a significant contributor to childhood obesity. In fact, cellulose is found in many plant-based foods, including fruits and vegetables, and may even be beneficial as a non-caloric fiber additive. The article concludes that the focus on fast food chains is misplaced and that manufacturers use cellulose in many packaged foods for thickening and texture purposes.

site_title: Noble hires Nyrstar's Barbir as it expands
summary: Noble Group Ltd, Asia's largest commodity trader, has hired Kareem Barbir from Nyrstar NV to trade industrial metals concentrates. Barbir is based in London and joins Noble's expanding industrial metals business, which has been growing beyond aluminium. Noble previously worked with Nyrstar to market part of its European output. This move is part of Noble's expansion efforts, led by Mark Hansen since 2012.

site_title: Big trade in offing as first US condensate cargo goes on sale
summary: US energy company Enterprise Product Partners has sold its first cargo of ultra-light condensate oil to a Japanese trading house, marking the start of the country's growing trade in exports. The deal follows approval from the US Department of Commerce to export minimally processed condensate, easing a 40-year ban. As much as 300,000 barrels could be exported daily by the end of the year, with potential buyers in Latin America and Asia, including China, Japan, and South Korea.

site_title: Around Town
summary: The Cats of The World exhibition is back for its eighth annual event, featuring a photo exhibition and feline-themed bazaar. The exhibition showcases photos of cats in unique settings from around the world, with artworks inspired by felines also available for sale. The event runs until July 28 at The Arts House, with free admission. The feline-themed bazaar, Purrzaar Market, takes place on July 5, 12, and 19, also at The Arts House. Proceeds from the artworks will benefit the Cat Welfare Society.

site_title: UK home prices rise at fastest rate in 9 years
summary: UK house prices rose at their fastest annual pace in 9 years, with a 11.8% increase in June, exceeding forecasts. London house prices surged 25.8% in the past year, reaching £400,000 for the first time. Average prices outside London are near their 2007 peak, while transaction levels are below historic averages. The Bank of England faces a challenge in stopping a regional housing boom from destabilizing the economy, with interest rates potentially rising to curb buyer demand.

site_title: Demand in strata-titled industrial market slows
summary: Demand in the strata-titled industrial market in Singapore slowed significantly in Q2, with 224 units changing hands, a 57% decrease from the same period last year. Average capital values and rents for conventional industrial space remained steady, while prices for industrial properties with shorter tenures declined due to higher financing costs. Rents in business parks and high-tech spaces inched up, driven by leasing queries for newer developments.

site_title: Leasing commitment for 21% of CapitaGreen
summary: CapitaGreen, a 40-storey Grade A office building in Singapore's central business district, has achieved a leasing commitment of 21% of its net lettable area. The building, developed by CapitaLand, CapitaCommercial Trust, and Mitsubishi Estate Asia, is on track for completion by year-end. Major tenants include Jardine Lloyd Thompson and Jones Day. The building's construction was accelerated using innovative technologies and design-and-build methodology, shaving off 4 months from the industry average. The development is well-positioned to capitalize on the limited office supply in the CBD.

site_title: Football fever in US looks set to stay
summary: US football enthusiasm surges, with nearly 25 million viewers tuning in to the World Cup match against Portugal, surpassing NBA finals and baseball's World Series. The US national team's group games drew thousands of fans at outdoor viewing parties across the country, with brisk sales of US$90 jerseys. The increased interest can be attributed to a generation of younger Americans who grew up playing the sport, and the US team's spirited performance in the World Cup has left a lasting impact on the sport.

site_title: Corporate treasuries in Asia still too basic in their approaches: PwC
summary: A PwC study of 117 Asian corporations found that corporate treasuries in the region are still using basic risk management techniques, despite growing economic volatility. Only 32% have real-time information on their cash position, and over half do not use hedge accounting or have a treasury management system. The study highlights the need for treasuries to adopt more sophisticated techniques, such as sensitivity analysis and gap analysis, to effectively manage financial risks and achieve strategic goals.

site_title: Vallianz strikes vessel deal with CNOOC unit
summary: Vallianz Holdings, a Catalist-listed company, has partnered with Offshore Oil Engineering Co (COOEC) in China's oil & gas sector. The three-year agreement allows Vallianz to provide offshore support vessels to COOEC, with options for charter or project sub-contracting. This collaboration is seen as a significant opportunity for Vallianz, with the company aiming to tap into China's growing O&G industry.

site_title: LionGold whiplashed by Australian units' suspension
summary: LionGold Corp, a junior gold miner, is facing pressure after its Australian-listed gold miner Signature Metals' shares were suspended from trading due to failing to lodge its annual report on time. The delay was caused by the company's inability to finalise the carrying value of its assets and liabilities. This is part of LionGold's ongoing struggles with its financial house, following the 2014 penny stock crash. The firm has until October to hold its annual general meeting and complete its full audit of FY2014 results.

site_title: China Eastern converts subsidiary into budget carrier
summary: China Eastern Airlines Corp Ltd launched its budget airline, China United, by converting its subsidiary, becoming the first state-run carrier to enter the low-cost travel segment. China United will have up to 100 planes in its fleet by 2019 and aims to offer 20-40% discount tickets to domestic cities, with potential expansion into neighboring countries. The move is seen as a response to the growing popularity of low-cost carriers in China, with industry analysts predicting other state-run carriers may follow suit, such as Air China and China Southern Airlines.

site_title: Value of June securities traded slides 37%
summary: The value of securities traded on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) in June declined 37% year-over-year to $20.5 billion, and 12% from May. Trading volume was affected by World Cup fever and a lacklustre market, with bond listings increasing by 200% year-over-year. Derivatives and commodities volumes also saw significant growth, but securities market turnover for SGX-listed companies and exchange-traded funds fell. Market observers attribute the decline to the bourse's lack of attractiveness for new share offerings following the penny stock saga and price collapse of several stocks.

site_title: Fifa sec-gen concedes match-fixing concerns
summary: Fifa secretary-general Jerome Valcke has admitted match-fixing concerns, stating it's impossible to eliminate 100% and only controls legal betting. He cited examples of potential match-fixing during the World Cup, including a June 18 Cameroon-Croatia match and a June 23 Cameroon-Brazil match. Valcke acknowledged the issue exists at all levels, from top to lower, and expressed difficulty in fighting behind-the-scenes manipulation.

site_title: Chinese developers muscle in on HK
summary: Chinese developers are aggressively entering Hong Kong's real estate market, outbidding local rivals for prime sites amid policy uncertainty and falling property prices on the mainland. Mainland companies, such as Poly Property Group, have pushed up prices with bids up to 20% above analysts' forecasts. Despite fears of a bubble, Chinese developers are attracted to Hong Kong's legal stability, brand awareness, and access to international markets. The trend has opened opportunities for mainland rivals, with some analysts warning that new entrants may have to sacrifice margins to gain a foothold in the city.

site_title: Olam CEO identifies six challenges
summary: Olam International CEO Sunny Verghese identified six key challenges for the industry to address this century, including food security, water security, climate change, and inclusive growth. He emphasized the need for integrated solutions and called on Olam to be an activist voice in raising awareness of these fundamental challenges. Verghese also highlighted the importance of sustainability, transparency, and managing risk, stating that environmental and social criteria must go hand in hand with commercial decision-making.

site_title: Homage to Filipino barbershops
summary: Manila-based artist Francis Commeyne is showcasing his series of paintings and box installations at a Singapore gallery, focusing on the often-overlooked aspect of Filipino street culture, specifically barbershops. The 26-year-old artist, with a mixed background, explores the complexities of travel, place, memory, and identity in his art. The exhibition highlights the unique aspects of Philippine culture and street life, offering a glimpse into the daily lives of Filipinos. Commeyne's work aims to bring attention to this aspect of street culture, shedding light on the mundane and often ignored aspects of Filipino life.

site_title: Hawkish Fed if unemployment beats expectations
summary: US unemployment is expected to fall faster than predicted, potentially leading to wage growth and a subsequent rise in inflation. According to Keith Wade, chief economist of Schroders, if the unemployment rate falls to 5.5% by the end of Q2 2015, the Federal Reserve may become more hawkish and raise interest rates, which could destabilize global markets. This could also lead to a decline in emerging markets, particularly those reliant on external funding.

site_title: Wilmar, First Pacific lower Goodman bid
summary: Wilmar International and First Pacific have lowered their joint takeover bid for Goodman Fielder from A$0.70 to A$0.675 per share after four weeks of due diligence revealed concerns over the investments needed to turn the debt-ridden Aussie food company around. The revised offer values Goodman Fielder equity at A$1.34 billion. The deal requires 75% investor support and regulatory approval.

site_title: Plus-sized comic's roadie romp
summary: Comedienne Melissa McCarthy stars in "Tammy," a film she co-wrote and directed with her husband Ben Falcone. The movie follows the character of Tammy, a plus-sized underdog who embarks on a road trip with her grandmother. Despite McCarthy's previous success in films like "Bridesmaids" and "The Heat," "Tammy" fails to deliver laughs, instead becoming a jumbled mix of genres. The film's tone and pacing are criticized for being out-of-sync, leaving the movie feeling unfunny and unengaging. McCarthy's signature humor is not enough to save the film from its overall disappointment.

site_title: Three-Minute Digest
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector showed mixed readings, with the PMI slipping to 50.5 in June. Corporate governance advocates call for improved governance of corporate groups. The Monetary Authority of Singapore warned financial institutions about anti-money laundering breaches. Brazil's President Dilma Rousseff is seen as a likely winner in October's elections. Wilmar International and First Pacific lowered their bid for Goodman Fielder due to concerns over investments. Singapore is exploring the use of "cold energy" from liquefied natural gas.

site_title: Rousseff gets election kick out of World Cup
summary: Brazilian President Dilma Rousseff's popularity has rebounded ahead of October's elections, thanks to the success of the World Cup. Protests that plagued her in the past have largely vanished, and the tournament has seen increased excitement and goals scored, lifting her approval rating to 44% and her lead over her opponent to 18 percentage points. The World Cup's positive news has been crucial in renewing confidence in her campaign, with analysts saying it's a break from social tensions that helps the government. Rousseff remains the favorite to win re-election.

site_title: Starburst launches IPO at 31¢ a share
summary: Starburst Holdings, a Singapore-based engineering group, has launched its initial public offering (IPO) at 31 cents a share. The company aims to raise $13.5 million to expand its fabrication facility and pursue growth opportunities in the South-east Asia and Middle East markets. Starburst designs and manufactures anti-ricochet ballistic protection systems for firearm shooting ranges and tactical training mockups, with net profit increasing by 33.8% to $8.7 million in the 2013 financial year. The IPO is expected to start trading on July 10, with DBS Bank serving as sponsor and issue manager.

site_title: More governance effort needed for group's units
summary: A new report by CPA Australia and the Iclif Leadership & Governance Centre finds that corporate governance of group entities, such as parent companies and subsidiaries, needs more attention to prevent failures and reputational harm. The report studied 150 of the largest listed companies in Singapore, Malaysia, and Australia, and found that most group entities contribute significantly to the financial performance and risks of the listed entity. To minimize risks, the report proposes a framework for the board and management of the ultimate parent company to govern group entities, including forming a formal group governance program and improving disclosures of governance measures.

site_title: 'Smart nation' vision calls for collaboration
summary: Singapore aims to become a "Smart Nation" by 2050, leveraging technology to improve the quality of life for its citizens. The country has launched a test bed in the Jurong Lake District with 15 "smart" solutions, including real-time traffic management and energy monitoring. A Smart Nation Platform is being developed to manage and share data, and the government is working on open standards for seamless connectivity. Collaboration between the government, industry, and citizens is crucial for the successful implementation of the smart nation vision, with governance frameworks and data protection being key considerations.

site_title: Rakuten's reasons for airline adventure are far from clear
summary: Rakuten, a Japanese e-commerce giant, has taken a 18% stake in AirAsia Japan for US$12 million, citing a boost to its travel website. However, the investment's financial impact is limited, and Rakuten's patchy investment record raises concerns. The company's reasons for diversifying into the airline business are unclear, and investors should be wary of its willingness to spend outside its core business. This investment may be a stretch, and Rakuten's true motivations remain unclear.

site_title: Australand shares advance on FCL's offer
summary: Australand Property Group shares rose 0.9% to A$4.48 after Frasers Centrepoint Ltd announced a A$2.6 billion off-market takeover offer. Frasers will acquire Australand's office and industrial properties and developments, giving it control of A$2.3 billion and A$9.3 billion assets. The offer is set to open on July 7 and close on Aug 7, pending acceptances from more than 50% of Australand shareholders and approval from Australia's Foreign Investment Review Board. Australand shareholders will retain their expected first-half dividend.

site_title: Company Briefs
summary: United Envirotech, a US$1 billion water treatment company, is in talks with a potential buyer. KKR China Water Investment Holdings is its biggest shareholder. GMG Global expects a Q2 loss due to a weaker rubber price, while Metro Holdings acquired a 25% stake in a Manchester-based group for £5.7 million. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Meanwhile, Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case, and Singapore's MAS and PBOC are deepening cooperation in green finance.

site_title: Mixed manufacturing readings cloud outlook
summary: Singapore's overall manufacturing PMI in June slipped to 50.5, below May's 50.8 reading, amid mixed performance. The electronics PMI rose to 50.7, but underlying weaknesses remain. Economists attribute the dip to lower new orders and production, with inventory expansion for the eighth consecutive month. Despite the mixed reading, economists say the manufacturing sector is showing a relatively flat performance, reflecting current global economic conditions, and do not consider it a dire situation.

site_title: For sale: Canada's railway hotels
summary: Canada's historic railway hotels, built to resemble castles, are being sold by Ivanhoé Cambridge, a Quebec-based investment fund, after the company decided to exit the hotel business. The Fairmont Chateau Laurier in Ottawa, the Fairmont Empress in Victoria, and the Fairmont Royal York in Toronto are among the properties on the market, with the Empress being sold to a real estate developer. The hotels' unique architecture and historical significance are attracting buyers who see them as opportunities to invest in properties with a "story" beyond their financial returns.

site_title: Idle seized vessel giving bondholders a windfall
summary: A Mexican corporate bond defaulted on a US$400 million loan, and the bonded vessel OSA Goliath, worth an estimated US$245 million, is being sold to compensate bondholders. The ship's value has soared 35% to 115 cents on the dollar, more than seven times the average gain for Mexican corporate debt. The trustee plans to liquidate the ship, potentially generating enough funds to cover the US$160 million of defaulted bonds, with remaining proceeds going back to the company.
